• The IEEE 802.15.4 standard is designed for low-power and low-data-rate wireless personal area networks (WPANs) and is targeted for wireless body area networks (WBANs). The standard provides a low-cost, low-power, and reliable protocol for wireless monitoring of patient health. It defines the physical layer and MAC sublayer.

• The IEEE 802.15.4 network supports two types of topologies, star topology and peer-to-peer topology, and two modes of operation, beacon-enabled (slotted) and non-beacon-enabled (unslotted). The standard also supports three distinct frequency bands, with 2.4 GHz being the most important. The 2.4 GHz band is the same as IEEE 802.11b/g and Bluetooth.

• The MAC protocol plays an important role in the overall performance of a network, and it is defined in two categories: contention-based and schedule-based MAC protocols. In contention-based protocols like CSMA/CA, each node contends to access the medium, while in schedule-based protocols like TDMA, each node transmits data in its pre-allocated time slot. The CSMA/CA protocol is used in this paper.

• The paper focuses on the analysis of the IEEE 802.15.4 standard with non-beacon-enabled mode configured in a star topology, and sensor nodes using CSMA/CA protocol to access the channel data. The authors consider a star topology at 2.4 GHz with up to 10 body-implanted sensors. The long-term power consumption of devices is the main aim of their analysis.

• The authors perform an extensive analysis based on simulations and real measurements to investigate the unreliability in the IEEE 802.15.4 standard. They find out that, with an appropriate parameter setting, it is possible to achieve the desired level of reliability. The unreliability in the MAC protocol is the basic aspect for the evaluation of reliability for a sensor network.

• A traffic-adaptive MAC protocol (TAMAC) is introduced by using traffic information of sensor nodes. TAMAC protocol is supported by a wakeup radio, which is used to support emergency and on-demand events in a reliable manner. The authors compare TAMAC with beacon-enabled IEEE 802.15.4 MAC, Wireless Sensor MAC (WiSeMac), and Sensor MAC (SMAC) protocols.

• The authors examine the use of the IEEE 802.15.4 standard in ECG monitoring and study the effects of the CSMA/

<summary>
* The Multiple Optimised Parameter Estimation and Data Compression (MOPED) algorithm is a patented method for compressing data and speeding up likelihood function evaluations in astronomical data analysis. It is particularly useful when the noise covariance matrix depends on the model parameters and must be calculated and inverted at each likelihood evaluation. However, MOPED only guarantees maintaining the Fisher matrix of the likelihood at a chosen point, which can lead to problems with multimodal and degenerate distributions.

* MOPED works by compressing the data into a set of independent and unit-variance values, one for each parameter of the model, which simplifies the likelihood calculation. The compression is done by generating a set of weighting vectors from the theoretical model and data, which must be computed at some assumed fiducial set of parameter values. The weighting vectors are generated in a specific order to ensure orthogonality.

* The MOPED algorithm can create additional peaks in the likelihood function equal in magnitude to the true one, which can be problematic for parameter estimation. This occurs when the contours of the compressed values intersect at multiple points, resulting in multiple peaks of equal likelihood. The set of intersections of contour surfaces determines where these additional peaks are located.

* To determine the validity of degenerate peaks in the MOPED likelihood function, one can compare the original likelihoods of the peak parameter values with each other. A possible solution to this problem is to use multiple fiducial models to create multiple sets of weighting vectors and average the log-likelihood across these choices. This maintains the true peaks but decreases the likelihood at incorrect values.

<summary>
* The cosmological constant problem (CCP) is a major puzzle in particle physics, consisting of several pieces, including the vacuum energy density, radiative corrections, and the experimental value of the cosmological constant. The CCP is not resolved within the framework of Einstein gravity and the standard model of particle physics.

* The vacuum energy density can receive large radiative corrections, including a cutoff scale, and can be estimated from various sources, such as zero-point energy, Higgs potential, and chiral symmetry breaking. The experimental value of the cosmological constant is estimated to be around 2.4 x 10^(-47) GeV^4.

* The CCP is replaced by the problem of disclosing the essence of new physics, and a principle, assumptions, and/or a framework beyond common sense of accepted physics may be necessary. The article studies the CCP in the framework of effective field theory and suggests that a dominant part of dark energy can originate from gravitational corrections of vacuum energy.

* The classical gravitational fields do not couple to a large portion of the vacuum energy effectively, and external gravitons can couple to gravitational corrections of vacuum energy involving internal gravitons. This assumption is difficult to understand in the framework of ordinary local quantum field theory.

* The article presents a conjecture on a candidate of dark energy, which is the gravitational correction of vacuum energy involving internal gravitons, and suggests that physics around the terascale is relevant to the dark energy of our universe. The zero-point energy of some scalar field or superpartners can dominate the dark energy density.

* The evolution of dark energy is studied, and it is found that the logarithmically changing energy density is described by the equation of state, which may cause instability if not fulfilled by the requirements of matter stability and a time scale of instability longer than the age of the universe.

* The paper presents a two-color modulation transfer spectroscopy method for studying atomic properties in excited states, which overcomes the limitations of traditional spectroscopic techniques.
* The method uses two lasers, a pump and a probe, to create a non-linear interaction that "burns a hole" in the atomic ground state population, allowing for precise measurements of energy separations.
* The technique is demonstrated in two ladder systems, with the amplitude of the probe laser modulated in one system and the frequency of the pump laser modulated in the other, and is shown to produce high-quality spectra with characteristic sidebands.
* The method has the potential to stimulate further studies of atomic properties in excited states and to push the experimental precision and theoretical work in this area.

* The physics potential of forward proton tagging at the LHC has attracted significant attention in recent years, with a focus on central exclusive production (CEP) processes. The CEP process involves the production of a central system, such as a Higgs boson, with the protons remaining intact and separated from the central system by a large rapidity gap.

* The CEP process allows for a direct observation of the quantum numbers of the produced particle, and the detection of outgoing protons can provide a measurement of the mass of the centrally produced particle. The FP420 collaboration has proposed installing detectors at 420m from the interaction points of ATLAS and/or CMS.

* The detectors would allow for the detection of central systems in the mass range of 70-200 GeV, and proposals also exist to upgrade the capabilities of ATLAS and CMS to detect protons in the 220m region. The acceptance of the forward detectors is governed by the distance of the active edge of the detector from the beam.

* The distance of the active edge of the detector from the beam depends on the beam size at each detector location, and the aperture of the LHC beam elements between the interaction point and the forward detectors. The primary uncertainties in the predicted CEP cross section come from the parton distribution functions (PDFs) and the soft survival factor.

* The CEP cross section for a Standard Model Higgs boson decaying to b-quarks varies from 1.86 fb to 7.38 fb depending on the PDF choice. The soft survival factor, which is the probability that there are no additional hard scatters in a single pp collision, is expected to vary from 0.03 to 0.1.

* The backgrounds to central exclusive Higgs production can be broken down into three categories: central exclusive di-jet production, double pomeron exchange, and overlap events. The most difficult backgrounds to deal with are the central exclusive di-jet backgrounds, which are suppressed at leading order by the Jz=0 selection rule.

* The overlap events are defined as a coincidence between an event that produces a central system of interest and one or more diffractive events which produce protons in the acceptance range of a forward detector in the same bunch crossing. The cross section for overlap events increases by two orders of magnitude from low to high luminosity.

* The analysis presented in the paper shows that the central exclusive production of the lightest scalar Higgs boson can be observed with a significance of at least 5

<summary>
* The paper discusses the zero-field Hall effect in chiral p-wave superconductors, which is possible due to the broken time-reversal symmetry.
* The Hall effect is studied near the Kosterlitz-Thouless (KT) transition, where vortex-antivortex pairs unbind and free vortices emerge.
* The dynamics of vortex motion is described using the Fokker-Planck equation, which includes a convective term due to the broken symmetry.
* The pair polarization is tilted away from the direction of the force field, resulting in both longitudinal and transverse components of the response function.
* The transverse response function has a peak structure and a dip-recouping shape, which determines the sign of the Hall conductivity.
* The sign of the Hall conductivity depends on the net electric field generated by all pairs, and can be positive or negative depending on the temperature and frequency.
* The Hall conductivity shows a sign reversal and peak structure above the KT transition temperature, and the power dissipation has a peak structure around the transition temperature.
* The results are interpreted in terms of the asymmetric pair motion in opposite angular directions, which gives rise to the Hall anomaly.

* The Orion dwarf galaxy is a suitable candidate to investigate the nature of dark matter (DM) and its distribution relative to baryonic components. The galaxy's kinematics are dominated by the dark component, making it an ideal test for DM density profiles. The galaxy's rotation curve (RC) is a powerful tool to study DM, and its measurement can be used to test the Cold Dark Matter (CDM) numerical simulations. The Orion dwarf's RC is well-suited for this purpose due to its high inclination and regular gas kinematics.

* The galaxy's stellar surface photometry and gas kinematics are presented, and the total gas mass is estimated to be (4.7±0.7) × 10^7 M. The RC is derived by fitting a tilted ring model to the intensity-weighted mean velocity field, and the resulting RC is steep and dominated by DM at nearly all galactocentric radii. The asymmetric drift correction is applied to the RC, and the presence of non-circular motions is investigated using a harmonic decomposition of the velocity field. The results show that the gas flow is dominated by circular kinematics.

* The galaxy is modeled using two different parametrizations of the DM halo: the NFW profile and the cored profile of the halo universal rotation curve (URCH). The cored profile fits the data extremely well, with a best-fitting core radius of 0.58 kpc and a central halo density of 0.11 GeV/cm^3. The NFW profile, on the other hand, overestimates the observed circular velocity at galactocentric radii r > 2 kpc. The baryonic fraction is estimated to be 0.05, and the gas fraction is 0.67.

* The Modified Newtonian Dynamics (MOND) formalism is also tested, and the results show that the model fails to match the observed kinematics if the literature galaxy distance and gas mass are adopted. However, the kinematic data can be reproduced in the MOND formalism if significant adjustments are made to the distance and/or gas mass. The authors conclude that the Orion dwarf is a decisive benchmark for the MOND formalism and a promising target for further studies.

* The trihydrogen dication, H3+, is a simple Coulomb system consisting of three protons and one electron, and its stability has been studied extensively in the 1960s and 1970s. Conroy investigated the potential energy surfaces of the electronic ground state and lowest excited states at linear and isosceles triangular configurations. He employed a variational approach and concluded that H3+ is not stable. His results were later questioned by other researchers.

* Schwartz and Schaad, and Somorjai and Yue reported single-point calculations of H3+ at the supposed equilibrium equilateral triangular configuration, but did not address the stability problem. Berkowitz and Stocker searched for H3+ through charge-stripping experiments, but could not find evidence of stable H3+. Later, Shoucri and Darling, and Hernndes and Carb re-examined the issue using different theoretical approaches.

* Johnson and Poshusta reported another single-point calculation in the context of Gaussian basis set optimization for some one-electron systems. About twenty years later, Ackermann et al. revisited the question of H3+ existence using the finite element method, which provided higher accuracy than previous methods. They excluded the possibility of stable H3+ in the electronic ground state, but reported explicit electronic energy data only for one particular equilateral triangular configuration.

* The present study aims to investigate the stability of H3+ in the equilateral triangular configuration, motivated by the possibility of its existence as a metastable state in a magnetic field. The system is studied using two methods: a specialized variational approach with physically relevant trial functions, and a standard variational approach using Gaussian trial functions as implemented in ab initio quantum chemistry packages. Both methods lead to highly accurate quantitative results for total energy versus triangle size.

* The specialized variational approach uses a trial function in the form of a linear superposition of six basis functions, each chosen to describe different physical characteristics of the system. The basis functions are symmetrized products of three Coulomb orbitals, and are designed to describe different regimes of interproton distances. The total number of parameters of the function is 15, with five linear parameters.

* The standard ab initio calculations use Gaussian basis functions centered at atoms, with coefficients determined variationally. The basis functions are built up by primitive Gaussians with contraction coefficients held fixed. The calculations were performed using the Hartree-Fock code implemented in the Molpro suite of programs with the correlation consistent cc-pV

<summary>
• The study investigates the relationship between galaxy properties and their environments, using data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) and the Two-Degree Field Galaxy Redshift Survey.
• The results show that galaxy clustering is a function of both star formation history and luminosity, with color and luminosity being more fundamental to environment than surface brightness and concentration.
• The study finds that the environments of low-luminosity, red galaxies continue to become denser as absolute magnitude increases, and that the strength of the correlation on large scales is associated with a steeper correlation function.
• The analysis suggests that only the masses of the host halos of galaxies strongly affect their properties, consistent with the "halo model" description of galaxy formation and semi-analytic models that depend only on host halo properties.
• The study resolves a discrepancy with previous work, finding that the recent star formation history of galaxies is not related to the large-scale environment, but rather only to the small-scale environment.

* The paper discusses the role of transverse spin fluctuations in the antiferromagnetic (AF) ground state of the half-filled Hubbard model.
* The authors develop a new method for evaluating transverse spin correlations and quantum spin-fluctuation corrections about the Hartree-Fock (HF) level broken-symmetry state.
* The method is applicable in the whole range of interaction strength and is illustrated with three applications involving the AF ground state of the half-filled Hubbard model.
* The authors study the effect of spin vacancies and low-U impurities on transverse spin fluctuations and find that spin vacancies enhance quantum spin-fluctuation corrections, while low-U impurities suppress them.
* The suppression of spin fluctuations by low-U impurities is found to be due to the stiffening of the magnon spectrum in the important low-energy sector.
* The authors also find that the spin-fluctuation correction is enhanced locally at the low-U impurity sites, but is suppressed on average.
* The method is tested by comparing the results with those obtained from other approaches, such as the spin-wave theory (SWT) and quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) simulations.
* The study provides new insights into the role of defects and disorder in the AF state of the Hubbard model and has implications for the understanding of magnetic impurities in antiferromagnets.

<summary>
* The paper discusses the study of nonequilibrium dynamics in quantum field theory, particularly in cosmology, focusing on multi-field models of inflation. The work is driven by the need to understand the large-scale homogeneity and isotropy of the universe, as well as the small-scale inhomogeneity and anisotropy. The authors investigate the dynamics of multi-field models, where the inflaton is coupled to another dynamical field during inflation. They also explore the subsequent phase of energy transfer between the inflaton and other degrees of freedom, leading to the standard picture of big bang cosmology.

* The authors develop a formalism for quantizing the system, using a closed-time path formalism, and construct the in-vacuum by diagonalizing the mass matrix of the system at the initial time. They expand each field in terms of all the in-state creation and annihilation operators, and define fluctuation integrals to determine the contributions to the zero-mode equations. The energy density of the system is also calculated, including the effects of fluctuations.

* The authors discuss the renormalization procedure, which involves extracting the divergent terms in the mode integrals and introducing counterterms to remove them. They adopt dimensional regularization and derive the finite corrections to the couplings and masses. The renormalized lagrangian is obtained, and the finite zero-mode equations of motion are derived.

* The authors apply their formalism to two specific models: a simple two-field model for studying parametric amplification, and a supersymmetric hybrid inflationary model. They investigate the effects of field mixing in these models, including the behavior of the fluctuation integrals and the time-dependent mixing angle. They find significant differences in the behavior of the system depending on the initial conditions and the regime of interest.

* The authors present numerical results for the two models, showing the evolution of the fluctuation integrals, the mixing angle, and the zero-mode components. They find that the mixing plays a crucial role in the evolution of the system, particularly in the broad resonance regime. They also discuss the implications of their results for our understanding of the early universe and the formation of structure.

<summary>
* The existence of dark matter (DM) has been established, and its thermal relic abundance has been determined by the WMAP experiment. The WIMP (Weakly Interacting Massive Particle) is a promising candidate for DM, and it can be accommodated economically by introducing an inert scalar field. The imposed parity ensures the stability of the DM candidate.

* The Higgs Triplet Model (HTM) is a simple extension of the Standard Model (SM) that can explain tiny neutrino masses. In the HTM, a triplet scalar field with hypercharge is introduced, and its vacuum expectation value (VEV) breaks lepton number conservation. The small triplet VEV is generated by an explicit breaking parameter of lepton number conservation.

* The HTM does not contain a DM candidate, and the smallness of the breaking parameter is not explained. To address these issues, a new model is proposed, which extends the HTM by introducing a complex singlet scalar field and an inert doublet scalar field. The model generates the breaking parameter at the one-loop level and contains a DM candidate.

* The model introduces an unbroken parity symmetry, which ensures the stability of the DM candidate. The DM candidate is a mixture of the real singlet scalar and the inert doublet scalar. The model also predicts a small breaking parameter, which is naturally explained by the loop suppression.

* The DM relic abundance is determined by the annihilation cross section, which is proportional to the square of the breaking parameter. The model predicts a small annihilation cross section, which is consistent with the WMAP experiment. The DM candidate can be light enough to be produced at the LHC.

* The model predicts a characteristic collider signature, which depends on the large breaking parameter. The signature includes a final state with jets and two charged leptons, whose invariant mass gives the mass of the triplet scalar. The model can be distinguished from the usual HTM, which predicts additional charged leptons in the final state.

* The model is a simple extension of the HTM, and it addresses the issues of DM and the smallness of the breaking parameter. The model predicts a small annihilation cross section and a characteristic collider signature, which can be tested at the LHC. The model provides a natural explanation for the smallness of the breaking parameter.

<summary>
• The paper proposes a method to quantify the effective entanglement in qubit-mode systems using homodyne measurement results and knowledge of the initial preparation. This method is particularly useful for characterizing the degree of quantumness of optical channels, especially when they introduce low noise.

• The method involves projecting the full qubit-mode state onto a two-qubit subspace and estimating the parameters of the projected state using homodyne measurements. The projected state is then used to bound the entanglement of the full state.

• The authors use a prepare-and-measure scenario, where Alice prepares a qubit in one of two states and sends the corresponding mode state through the channel, and Bob performs homodyne measurements on the output state. The measurement results are used to estimate the parameters of the projected state.

• The authors derive bounds on the overlap of the maximal eigenstates of the conditional output states, which are used to estimate the parameters of the projected state. These bounds are derived using the measured variances and first moments of the conditional states.

• The authors also derive bounds on the off-diagonal elements of the projected state, which are used to quantify the entanglement. These bounds are derived using the positivity and Cauchy-Schwarz inequality.

• The method is demonstrated using a simple channel model, where the test state is mixed at a beam splitter with a thermalized vacuum. The results show that the method can provide non-trivial bounds on the entanglement for low noise values.

• The authors conclude that their method provides a useful tool for understanding the quantum nature of optical devices and how well they preserve quantum correlations, and that it can be extended to more complex scenarios and channel models.

<summary>

* The study of dipole moments of elementary particles has provided a wealth of information on subatomic physics over the past 83 years, from the discovery of spin and radiative corrections to the development of QED and QCD. The magnetic moment of a charged particle with spin is proportional to its gyromagnetic ratio and anomaly.

* The Dirac equation shows that for spin one-half point-like particles, the gyromagnetic ratio is 2, and for orbital angular momentum, it is unity. The anomaly arises from radiative corrections, which have been calculated through eighth order for electron and muon anomalies.

* The electron anomaly is now measured to a relative precision of about four parts in a billion, which is better than the precision on the fine-structure constant. The muon anomaly is measured to 0.5 parts per million and is sensitive to higher mass scale radiative corrections.

* The standard model value of the muon anomaly has measurable contributions from three types of radiative processes: QED loops, hadronic loops, and weak loops. A significant difference between the experimental value and the standard model prediction would signify the presence of new physics.

* The hadronic contribution to the muon anomaly cannot be calculated directly from QCD, but dispersion theory gives a relationship between the vacuum polarization loop and the cross section for e+e- annihilation. The hadronic light-by-light contribution is likely to provide the ultimate limit to the precision of the standard model value.

* Supersymmetric theories predict measurable contributions to the muon anomaly, and there is a complementarity between the supersymmetric contributions to the MDM, EDM, and transition moment for the lepton-flavor violating process. The muon anomaly is sensitive to physics at the 100 GeV scale.

* The experimental method used to measure the muon anomaly is based on the fact that the spin precesses faster than the momentum vector when a muon travels transversely to a magnetic field. The spin precession frequency consists of the Larmor and Thomas spin-precession terms.

* The goal of the new experiment is to reach a precision of 0.1 ppm total error, with the goal of controlling the total systematic errors on the magnetic field and on the muon frequency measurement to 0.1 ppm each. A letter of intent for an even more precise experiment was also submitted to J-PARC.

* The EDM has two effects on the precession: the magnitude of the observed frequency is increased, and the precession plane is tipped relative to

<summary>
• The paper presents a new design for an optomechanical system consisting of a microdisk resonator coupled to a waveguide, which enables the study of reactive effects in optomechanical coupling. The origin of the reactive coupling lies in the mechanical motion dependence of the extrinsic losses of the disk resonator.

• The system is analyzed using a Hamiltonian that includes the energy of the cavity field, the energy of the waveguide, and the interactions between the waveguide and the incident fields. The time evolutions of the expectation values of the system operators are solved using the Heisenberg equation of motion.

• The normal mode splitting of the output fields is investigated by calculating their expectation values using the input-output relation. The results show that the reactive coupling between the waveguide and the cavity can result in normal mode splitting of the output fields, and the peak separation becomes larger with increasing pump power.

• The output fields are found to depend on the behavior of the roots of the denominator of the output field, and the reactive coupling can lead to the appearance of normal mode splitting in the output stokes field. The dip at the line center exhibits power broadening, and the stokes field can be amplified by the stimulated process.

• The nonlinear nature of the reactive coupling generates anti-stokes radiation, and the optomechanical system can generate an anti-stokes field with frequency due to the reactive coupling. The maximum gain for the anti-stokes field is found to be about 0.1 for a pump power of 1.3 mW.

<summary>
• The dynamics of a quantum many-body system out of equilibrium has been a topic of interest in recent times, with many studies focusing on the transport of physical quantities in low-dimensional spin systems.
• The introduction of a current of a physical quantity, such as magnetization, can render a system out of equilibrium, and its relaxation dynamics have been studied in various systems.
• In this study, the authors investigate the transport of transverse magnetization in a quantum Ising chain, where the system is prepared in an initial state with inhomogeneous magnetization.
• The system is then evolved in the presence of a homogeneous and constant transverse field, and the dynamics of the magnetization are studied.
• The authors find that the magnetization exhibits oscillatory behavior with an algebraic decay of the envelope, but the system does not reach a homogeneous magnetization state even at infinite time.
• The frequency of the oscillation changes monotonically with the transverse field in the ferromagnetic phase and becomes independent of the field in the paramagnetic phase, indicating a quantum phase transition.
• The authors also find that the exponent of the decay is independent of the field, and the system does not thermalize, which is counterintuitive to prevailing ideas.
• The study raises questions about the behavior of non-local observables in such systems and how non-integrable systems would behave starting from such inhomogeneous initial states.

<summary>
• The study of QCD at finite baryon density is crucial for understanding the structure of compact stars and the conditions near the core of collapsing stars.
• In the color superconducting phase, the behavior of quark matter is characterized by the diquark gap parameter, which is determined by the non-perturbative gluon fields.
• The chromomagnetic instability in the gapless phase is a puzzle, and it is not understood why the gluons can feel the instability by requiring electrical neutrality on the system.
• The response of the g2sc phase to an external vector current shows that the phase is unstable with respect to a net momentum for diquark pairs and a color-neutral baryon current.
• The instability of the baryon current indicates that the quark can spontaneously obtain a momentum, and the g2sc phase is also unstable with respect to the response of a net diquark momentum.
• The paramagnetic response to an external vector current naturally suggests that a vector current can be spontaneously generated in the system, which modifies the quark self-energy with a spatial vector condensate.
• The ground state of charge-neutral quark matter should be determined by solving the gap equations as well as the charge neutrality condition, and the solution of the charge-neutral LOFF state can stay everywhere in the full LOFF window.
• The stability of the neutral system should be further determined by the dynamical stability condition, i.e., the positivity of the Meissner mass square, and the polarization tensor for the gluons should be evaluated using the modified quark propagator.

<summary>
* The debate about the melting phase transition of 2D systems has been ongoing for decades, with the KTHNY theory being a widely accepted milestone, but its assumption of a dilute distribution of lattice defects has been criticized. Recent studies have focused on systems with different pair interactions, including dipole-dipole and Debye-Hückel interactions, and have reported conflicting results on the nature of the phase transition. The authors of this study aim to resolve this debate by investigating the role of equilibration time in numerical simulations.
* The authors performed microcanonical molecular dynamics simulations of a repulsive screened Coulomb pair potential and found that the velocity distribution function relaxes quickly, while the configurational temperature and long-range correlations take longer to equilibrate. The relaxation time of the velocity distribution function is independent of temperature and system size, but the configurational temperature and long-range correlations show a strong temperature and system size dependence. The authors conclude that increasing system size alone may be insufficient to reach equilibrium and that the length of the equilibration period is crucial in building up or destroying correlations.

<summary>
• The Kepler mission has discovered over 4100 planetary candidates in 3200 systems, revealing that small planets are nearly ubiquitous and common planet sizes range from Earth-sized to Neptune-sized.
• The transition from "rocky" to "non-rocky" planets occurs near a radius of 2.5 Earth radii and is very sharp, making accurate planetary radii crucial for understanding planet occurrence rates.
• Assuming all Kepler candidate host stars are single can introduce a systematic uncertainty into planetary radii and occurrence rate distributions, as undetected stellar companions can dilute transit depths and affect planetary radii.
• The presence of a stellar companion does not invalidate a planetary candidate, but it changes the observed transit depth and derived planetary radius.
• The Kepler pipeline treats each candidate host star as a single star, which may lead to underestimated planetary radii and incorrect occurrence rates.
• The authors assess the effects of undetected stellar companions on derived planetary parameters by considering six multiplicity scenarios and calculating correction factors for each.
• The mean correction factor for unvetted Kepler stars is 1.5, implying that planetary radii are underestimated by a factor of 1.5 on average.
• If Kepler stars are vetted with radial velocity and high resolution imaging, the mean correction factor decreases to 1.2, and the dependence on primary star effective temperature becomes shallower.
• For K2 and TESS stars, which are typically 10 times closer than Kepler stars, the mean correction factor for vetted stars is only 1.04, and the correction to planetary radii uncertainties is only 5%.
• Understanding the occurrence rates of Earth-sized planets is crucial, and accounting for undetected companions is essential to accurately determine these rates.

<summary>

* The range of HI column densities in nearby galaxies is similar to those in damped Lyman-alpha systems (DLAs) with N(HI) > 2 x 10^20 cm^-2. Mapping HI gas in DLAs and measuring their total gas mass, extent, and dynamics would provide a direct link between DLAs and local galaxies. However, this is currently impossible with present technology.

* The transition probability of the hyperfine splitting that causes the 21-cm line is extremely small, making it difficult to observe in emission in the distant universe. The identification of DLAs as absorbers in background quasar spectra is not distance-dependent, but the lowest redshift Lyman-alpha absorbers cannot be observed from the ground due to atmospheric opacity. The redshift number density of DLAs decreases rapidly towards lower redshifts.

* There is a wealth of information on cold gas properties in local galaxies, but little possibility to bridge this with DLA absorption profiles at intermediate and high redshift. Most observers resort to optical wavelengths to study DLAs, but attempts to directly image their host galaxies have been notably unsuccessful. A few positive identifications exist, mostly from HST imaging.

* The success rate for finding low-redshift host galaxies is better due to their expected brightness and larger separation from the quasar. Early surveys for low-redshift DLA host galaxies consisted of broad-band imaging and lacked spectroscopic follow-up. Later studies aimed to measure redshifts to determine the association of optically identified galaxies with DLAs.

* There are now around 10 DLA galaxies known at z < 1.5, spanning a wide range of galaxy properties from inconspicuous LSB dwarfs to giant spirals and early-type galaxies. It is not just luminous, high surface brightness spiral galaxies that contribute to the HI cross-section above the DLA threshold. A statistical study can be done to see if the properties of DLAs and DLA galaxies agree with our knowledge of HI in the local universe.

* Blind 21-cm emission line surveys in the local universe have resulted in an accurate measurement of the HI mass function, which can be used as a reference point for higher redshift DLA studies. The HI mass function is measured with surveys such as HIPASS. However, these surveys are not very useful in constraining the column density distribution function of HI.

* The WHISP sample of 355 galaxies observed with the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope provides high-resolution 21-cm maps, which can be

<summary>
• The majority of stars are formed in star clusters, but only a small percentage of gas is turned into stars during the collapse and fragmentation of a giant molecular cloud. The resulting cluster is made up of a combination of gas and stars, but the gas is quickly removed due to stellar winds and supernovae explosions. This removal of gas causes the cluster to be out of equilibrium.

• The effects of gas expulsion on young star clusters have been studied theoretically, but have received little attention in observational studies. Many studies have attempted to constrain the initial stellar mass function (IMF) in clusters by studying their internal dynamics, but these studies assume that the cluster is in virial equilibrium. However, this assumption may not be valid for young clusters.

• The paper presents observations of the luminosity profiles of three young massive star clusters, M82-F, NGC 1569-A, and NGC 1705-1, which show an excess of light at large radii compared to King or Elson-Fall-Freeman profiles. This excess is likely due to stars escaping during a period of violent relaxation after gas expulsion. The clusters are not tidally truncated, and the excess light is not due to background subtraction errors.

• The authors model the star clusters using N-body simulations, which show that the expulsion of gas leads to a period of violent relaxation and the ejection of stars from the cluster. The simulations reproduce the observed excess of light at large radii, and the authors conclude that the clusters are not in dynamical equilibrium. The simulations also show that virial mass estimates can be significantly wrong for several tens of Myr after gas expulsion.

• The results suggest that claims of unusual IMFs for young star clusters may be in error, as these clusters are not in virial equilibrium as assumed. The authors propose that gas expulsion is an important phase in the evolution of young clusters that cannot be ignored. The dynamical state of young clusters needs to be taken into account when constraining the IMF.

• The paper also discusses the implications of gas expulsion for the infant mortality of star clusters, where clusters with low star formation efficiencies can become completely unbound and dissolve over a few tens of Myr. The authors suggest that the rapid dissolution of these clusters may be responsible for the observed excess of young clusters in extragalactic populations.

• The authors conclude that gas expulsion is a crucial phase in the evolution of young star clusters, and that it can affect the observed luminosity profiles and dynamical state of the clusters. They propose that future studies

<summary>
• The paper investigates the influence of polychromatic perturbation on wave packet dynamics in a one-dimensional double-well potential.
• The authors numerically calculate the transition probability, time-fluctuation, uncertainty product, and phase space portrait to classify the motions in the parameter space.
• The critical value of the perturbation strength, which divides the behavior of the transition probability into regular and irregular motions, depends on the number of frequency components.
• Within the regular motion range, the period of the tunneling oscillation is reduced with an increase of the number of colors and/or strength of the perturbation.
• The growth of the uncertainty product initially increases and saturates at a certain level due to quantum interference in the irregular motion phase.
• In the stochastically perturbed case, the uncertainty product grows unboundedly because the external stochasticity breaks the quantum interference in the internal dynamics.
• The quantum fluctuation observed in the semiquantal picture is suppressed by interference effect in the fully quantum motion.
• The semiquantal picture breaks down for the chaos-induced delocalized states, and the quantum corrections to the evolution of the phase space fluctuation become more dominant for classically chaotic trajectories.
• The increase of the number of colors contributes to the increase of the width of the stochastic layer in the polychromatically perturbed cases.
• The transition observed in the quantum dynamics corresponds to quantum signatures of the KAM transition from the regular to chaotic dynamics in the classical dynamics.
</summary>

<summary>
* The paper presents a unified stochastic formalism for open quantum systems, which can be used to study the dynamics of a system interacting with a complex environment. The formalism is based on a stochastic Liouville equation, which describes the evolution of the system's reduced density matrix in terms of colored noises that represent the environmental fluctuations.
* The paper also discusses various methods for solving the stochastic Liouville equation, including a hierarchical equation of motion approach that can be used to study non-Gaussian bath models. The approach is based on a decomposition of the noise variables into a set of orthonormal functions, which allows for an efficient calculation of the system's dynamics.

<summary>
* The glass transition is a complex phenomenon that remains poorly understood, with both theoretical and experimental approaches struggling to fully capture its behavior. The mode-coupling theory (MCT) is a popular theoretical framework that attempts to explain the glass transition, but its predictions are often inconsistent with experimental results. The MCT predicts a sharp transition from a liquid to a glassy state at a critical temperature, known as the Kauzmann temperature.

* The MCT has been applied to various systems, including Lennard-Jones glass formers, but its predictions have been called into question by experimental data and simulations of polydisperse hard-core disks. The discrepancies between the reported simulated behavior of hard-disk and soft-sphere systems have sparked debate about the fundamental differences between these models. The present study aims to investigate the glass transition in a molecular dynamics (MD) simulation model of a Ni-Zr transition metal system.

* The Ni-Zr system is a well-studied glass-forming alloy, and the MD simulation model used in this study is based on the electron theoretical description of interatomic potentials for transition metal alloys. The model has no adjustable parameters and is adapted to the experimental data. The simulation results are analyzed using the MCT framework, which predicts a critical temperature (Tc) below which the system becomes non-ergodic.

* The MCT predicts that the non-ergodicity parameters, which characterize the long-time behavior of the system, should exhibit a sharp transition at Tc. The simulation results show that the non-ergodicity parameters do indeed exhibit a sharp transition, but the estimated Tc value is around 1005 K, which is lower than the value estimated from the diffusion coefficients. The diffusion coefficients, which are calculated from the mean square displacements of the atoms, exhibit a break in the Arrhenius slope around 1000 K.

* The break in the Arrhenius slope is attributed to a change in the atomic dynamics around Tc, where the system transitions from a liquid-like to a glass-like state. The simulation results are consistent with the MCT predictions, but the estimated Tc value is lower than expected. The study suggests that the Tc value may be underestimated due to the limited temperature range used in the fit procedure.

* The study also investigates the partial structure factors and partial correlation functions of the system, which are used to compute the non-ergodicity parameters. The results show that the partial structure factors exhibit a weak temperature dependence, while the partial correlation functions

<summary>

• The article discusses the analysis of longitudinal dyadic data with nonignorable dropouts, where the dropout mechanism depends on the missing outcomes. The authors propose a Bayesian approach to model the joint distribution of the longitudinal outcomes and the dropout process. The approach accounts for the interdependence between the two members of each dyad and the nonignorable missing data mechanism. The method is illustrated using a breast cancer study.

• The breast cancer study involves 191 couples, with depression measured at three time points using the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CESD) questionnaires. A substantial number of dropouts occurred, with only 73 couples completing all three measurements. The missingness of the CESD measurements is likely related to the current depression levels of the patients or spouses, making it a nonignorable missing data problem.

• The authors propose a transition model to capture the interdependence between the patients and spouses, where the current outcome of one member depends on the previous outcomes of both members. The model also accounts for the within-dyad correlation using random effects. A discrete-time survival model is used to model the dropout process, which depends on the current and previous outcomes of both members.

• The authors conducted two simulation studies to evaluate the performance of the proposed method. The first simulation study showed that the proposed method outperformed the complete-case and available-case analyses in terms of bias and coverage rates. The second simulation study demonstrated that the method is robust to misspecification of the dropout model.

• The authors applied the proposed method to the breast cancer data and found significant "partner" effects for both patients and spouses. The results suggest that the patients and spouses are highly interdependent and influence each other's depression status. The authors also found that the missing data for patients are nonignorable, while those for spouses appear to be ignorable.

• The authors compared the proposed approach with the complete-case and available-case analyses and found that the latter two approaches failed to detect some "partner" effects. The results suggest that ignoring nonignorable dropouts could lead to a failure to detect important covariate effects.

• The authors performed a Bayesian sensitivity analysis to examine how the inference changes with respect to the values of the parameters linking the missing outcome with the dropout process. The results showed that the estimates were quite stable, except for the estimate of cancer stage in the measurement model of patients.

<summary>

* According to quantum electrodynamics, quantum fluctuations of electric and magnetic fields give rise to a zero-point energy that never vanishes, even in the absence of electromagnetic sources. This energy leads to a force between two electrically neutral metallic parallel plates in vacuum, known as the Casimir force. The force is inversely proportional to the fourth power of separation and causes the plates to attract each other. The theory has been verified in several high-precision experiments.

* The Casimir-Lifshitz theory generalizes the Casimir force to isotropic dielectrics and predicts a force between two uncharged parallel plates with arbitrary dielectric functions. The theory has been experimentally confirmed, but essentially no attention has been devoted to the torque between anisotropic materials predicted by Parsegian, Weiss, and Barash. No experimental attempts to demonstrate the effect have been reported, and no numerical calculations to estimate its magnitude have been presented.

* The torque between two parallel birefringent plates is given by the derivative of the Helmholtz free energy with respect to the angle between the optical axes of the two plates. The free energy is calculated using the dielectric functions of the interacting materials at imaginary angular frequencies. The torque is proportional to the area of the interacting surfaces and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between the plates.

* The dielectric functions of many materials are well described by a multiple oscillator model, which can be written as a sum of Lorentz oscillators. The parameters that determine the dielectric properties of quartz, calcite, and Batio3 in the limit of the two-oscillator model are listed in a table. The calculated dielectric functions are shown in a figure.

* The torque expected for different angles at a distance of 100 nm is reported in a figure for both quartz-Batio3 and calcite-Batio3 configurations. The results obtained for smaller temperatures give rise to nearly identical values. The computational data were interpolated using a sinusoidal function with periodicity equal to 180 degrees.

* The maximum magnitude of the torque occurs at 45 and 135 degrees. Comparison of the results obtained with quartz and calcite shows that materials with less pronounced birefringent properties give rise to a smaller torque. The sign of the torque obtained for the quartz-Batio3 configuration is opposite to the one obtained for calcite-Batio3.

<summary>
• The paper presents a theoretical framework for analyzing topologically biased random walks (TBRW) on graphs, which can be used to explore the environment and measure distances between vertices depending on the chosen bias strategy and bias parameters.
• The authors propose a methodology for community detection using TBRW, which involves varying the bias parameters to shrink the spectral gap in the transition matrix and maximize the separation between relevant eigenvalues, and demonstrate its effectiveness on Girvan-Newman benchmark graphs.</summary>

<summary>
• The proposed system aims to defend against active P2P worms that can spread rapidly through P2P overlay networks, and consists of internal defense and external protection mechanisms. The internal defense mechanism includes detection, local isolation, alert propagation, and software patching modules to prevent internal attacks.

• The system elects a small subset of P2P nodes, called phagocytes, to perform defense and protection functions, and each phagocyte manages a group of P2P hosts. The phagocytes monitor their managed hosts' connection patterns and traffic volume to detect active P2P worm attacks.

• The external protection mechanism includes a novel adaptive and interaction-based computational puzzle scheme to prevent external hosts from attacking the P2P overlay. The scheme adjusts the puzzle difficulty based on the real-time statuses of the network environment and the external host's behavior.

• The system is evaluated using a prototype implementation and a massive-scale testbed with realistic P2P network traces. The evaluation metrics include peak infection percentage, blowup factor of latency, and percentage of successful external attacks.

• The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed system in defending against internal and external attacks, and the impact of immune phagocytes and managed P2P hosts on the system's performance.

<summary>
• Debris disk systems, like HD 32297, provide a unique opportunity to study the intermediate stage of stellar system evolution, between the formation of stars and planets and the mature stage of an evolved system like our solar system. The observed infrared luminosity of circumstellar dust in debris disks is typically several orders of magnitude larger than in our solar system. The detection of gas phase absorption in optical absorption lines is rare, with only a few edge-on debris disks showing this feature.

• The edge-on orientation of HD 32297 makes it an ideal target for gas phase absorption measurements, and observations of the D doublet were made over several epochs. The spectra were obtained using the Coudé spectrometer on the 2.7m Harlan J. Smith Telescope at McDonald Observatory. The data were reduced using IRAF and IDL routines to subtract the bias, flat field the images, and remove scattered light and cosmic ray contamination.

• Two absorption components are detected toward HD 32297, while only one is detected toward its proximate neighbors located at a comparable distance. The extra absorption component in the spectrum of HD 32297 is likely caused by circumstellar material. The radial velocities of HD 32297, BD+07 777s, and BD+07 778 are measured and differ significantly, indicating that they are likely not physically associated.

• The ism absorption is similar among HD 32297 and its two closest neighbors, and is likely due to absorption from the shell that defines the boundary of the local bubble. Some variation in local bubble absorption is detected toward 18 Ori. The physical separation of the interstellar material observed toward HD 32297 and the material toward BD+07 777s is 0.025pc, and toward 18 Ori is 8.1pc.

• The measured circumstellar feature toward HD 32297 is the strongest such absorption measured toward any nearby main sequence debris disk, 45 times greater than the column density of the prototypical edge-on debris disk, β Pictoris. The gas mass surrounding HD 32297 is estimated to be 0.40 M⊕, assuming the morphology and abundances of the stable gas component are similar to β Pictoris. This estimate should be considered an upper limit.

• Some indication of temporal variability is detected over several epochs of observations, but instrumental resolution variations and masking by the strong ism absorption make a definitive detection of circumstellar variability difficult. The redshifted variability seen between 2005 Sep and

<summary>
* The authors investigate the effects of quantum gravity on the Planck era of the universe, using various versions of the Generalized Uncertainty Principle (GUP) to derive corrections to physical quantities such as the Planck time, length, mass, energy, density, and entropy.
* The results show that the GUP corrections can significantly affect these quantities, potentially leading to observable effects in the cosmic microwave background radiation and the large-scale structure of the universe.

<summary>

* The paper discusses a new method to compute couplings in conformal field theories (CFTs) using integrability and the operator product expansion (OPE). The method involves deforming the CFT with a marginal or irrelevant operator and computing the anomalous dimension matrix. This matrix is used to relate the couplings to the deformed anomalous dimensions and renormalized operators.

* The authors consider a CFT with action S and deform it with a dimensionless deformation parameter ε at the cut-off scale Λ. The beta function for the coupling ε has a specific form, and the anomalous dimension matrix is defined in terms of the deformed correlation functions. The matrix is diagonalized using the renormalization matrix, and its eigenvalues are independent of the cut-off.

* The authors show that the anomalous dimension matrix can be used to compute the couplings in the 3-point function of the deformed theory. They provide a general formula for the couplings in terms of the anomalous dimension matrix and the renormalized operators. The formula is valid for any value of the coupling constant and can be used to compute the couplings at strong coupling.

* The authors apply their method to the case of N=4 supersymmetric Yang-Mills theory (SYM) deformed by the Lagrangian operator. They use integrability techniques to compute the anomalous dimension matrix and the couplings in the 3-point function. The results are compared to previous computations using the AdS/CFT duality.

* The authors also consider the case of irrelevant deformations and show that their method can be used to compute the couplings in this case as well. They provide a general formula for the couplings in terms of the anomalous dimension matrix and the renormalized operators.

* The authors discuss the normalization of operators and show that their method can be used to compute the normalized couplings. They also discuss the relation between their method and the Callan-Symanzik equation.

* The authors apply their method to the case of two-magnon operators in N=4 SYM and compute the couplings in the 3-point function. They compare their results to previous computations using the AdS/CFT duality.

* The authors discuss the strong coupling limit of their results and show that they agree with previous computations using the AdS/CFT duality. They also discuss the possibility of using their method to compute higher-point functions and to study the behavior of the couplings at strong coupling.
