• The study presents a comprehensive DFT investigation of the magnetic phase of iron pnictides, focusing on the anisotropy of the electronic structure and its connection to the magnetic ordering, and finds good agreement with experimental ARPES data.
• The results show that the detwinned, antiferromagnetic Fermi surface obtained by the calculations agrees well with experiment, and the anisotropic features are preserved independent of the photon energy, indicating a strong connection to the underlying magnetic structure.

<summary>
* XB158 is a high-inclination neutron star low-mass X-ray binary (LMXB) associated with the M31 globular cluster B158. It exhibits deep intensity dips on a 2.78 hr period in some observations but not others, suggesting a precessing disk. The disk precession is likely caused by the "superhumping" phenomenon observed in low-mass ratio systems where the disk crosses the 3:1 resonance with the donor star. The predicted disk precession period is 29±1 times the orbital period, i.e., 81±3 hr.

* The authors conducted a month of daily monitoring of the M31 central region using Swift, resulting in 30 observations with 2.5 ks exposure each. The 0.3-10 keV luminosity varied by a factor of 15, consistent with the range of luminosities observed in the ACIS observations of the 13+ year Chandra monitoring campaign. Fitting a sinusoid to the lightcurve revealed a 5.65±0.05 day super-orbital period. The peak of the Lomb-Scargle periodogram is at 5.6 days, consistent with that obtained from least squares fitting of the lightcurve with a sinusoid.

* The suggested super-orbital period is 17% longer than predicted by the 3D SPH simulations. The longer than expected super-orbital period is likely due to the mass ratio of the donor to the accretor being lower than assumed. The mass of a Roche lobe-filling main-sequence star may be approximated as M2 ≈ 0.11 M, where M is the orbital period in hours. For the accretor, a 1.4 M neutron star was assumed.

* XB158 appears to be somewhat analogous to 4U 1916-053, a high-inclination neutron star LMXB with an X-ray period of 50.00±0.08 min and an optical period of 50.458±0.003 min. 4U 1916-053 exhibits periodic X-ray intensity dips due to absorption by material in the outer disk, with an amplitude that varies over 10-100% on a 14-day period, the precession period of the disk. The authors modeled the 2004 July 17 XMM-Newton PN spectrum of XB158 with a blackbody and a power law, finding a photon index of 2

<summary>
* The calculation of energy and lifetime of resonance states is a challenging task, and various methods have been proposed, including the complex scaling method and the density of states (DOS) method.
* The DOS method provides a host of approximate values, but it is difficult to assess their accuracy, and they do not seem to converge to the exact value when the basis set size is increased.
* The authors propose a new optimization rule to select a set of eigenvalues that have linear convergence properties for small width resonances.
* The method is tested on one- and two-particle models, and the results show that the resonance energy converges linearly with the basis set size.
* The lifetime calculation is more subtle, and the authors use a golden-rule-like formula, but the results are not unique and require further analysis.
* The authors propose a recipe to choose the most accurate value of the lifetime by selecting the set that scales closest to linearly with the basis set size.
* The method is robust and has been tested on various systems, but it may not be applicable in cases where two or more resonance energies lie very close.
* The authors conclude that the method provides a significant improvement in the calculation of resonance energies and lifetimes, but further research is needed to fully understand the convergence properties of resonance states.

<summary>
* The paper discusses the concept of parity-time (PT) symmetry in nonlinear systems, particularly in the context of 2D plaquettes with gain and loss. The authors analyze the symmetry properties of these systems and find that they can exhibit exact, spontaneously broken, or completely broken PT symmetry. The plaquettes are motivated by feasible experimental realizations in nonlinear optics. The authors also discuss the possibility of engineering PT-symmetric oligomers and lattices.

* The authors derive the equations of motion for the 2D plaquettes and analyze their linear stability. They find that the plaquettes can exhibit exceptional points, where the eigenvalues of the linearized system coalesce. The authors also find that the plaquettes can exhibit different types of PT symmetry, including exact, spontaneously broken, and completely broken symmetry.

* The authors analyze the stationary solutions of the plaquettes and find that they can exhibit different types of behavior, including stable and unstable solutions. They also find that the solutions can exhibit phase structure, but not necessarily vortex behavior. The authors analyze the stability of the solutions using numerical methods and find that some solutions are stable, while others are unstable.

* The authors discuss the implications of their results for the study of PT-symmetric systems. They note that their results can be used to engineer PT-symmetric oligomers and lattices, which could have applications in nonlinear optics. The authors also discuss the possibility of observing PT-symmetric behavior in other systems, such as electrical circuits. The authors conclude that their results provide new insights into the behavior of PT-symmetric systems and could lead to new applications in nonlinear science.

<summary>
• The cataclysmic variable HU Aqr consists of a 0.80 white dwarf and a 0.18 main-sequence companion star, with two planets orbiting the binary. The transfer of mass between the stars is mediated by gravitational waves and the strong magnetic field of the accreting star. The presence of the planets allows for a precision reconstruction of the binary's history, including the rate of mass loss in the common-envelope phase. The planets' orbits are affected by the mass loss, with the inner planet's orbit expanding adiabatically and the outer planet's orbit being more impulsive.

• The initial conditions of the binary system can be reconstructed by measuring the orbital parameters of the two planets. The eccentricity of the outer planet indicates a more impulsive response to the mass loss, which is a natural consequence of its wider orbit. The rate of mass loss can be constrained by the observed eccentricity of the inner planet, and the initial binary separation can be derived from the observed orbital separation of the planets. The reconstructed initial conditions of the binary system can be tested for dynamical stability using numerical integrations.

• The presence of two planets around HU Aqr allows for a precision reconstruction of the evolution of the system, including the initial mass of the primary star, the initial binary separation, and the orbital separations of both planets. The rate of mass loss in the common-envelope phase can be measured to within a few percent accuracy, and the initial conditions of the binary system can be derived to within a factor of 5. The consistency between the observations and theoretical analysis gives some trust to the correctness of the observations. The results can be applied to other binaries, enabling the constraint of fundamental parameters in common-envelope evolution.

• The reconstructed evolution of HU Aqr provides insights into the formation and survival of planets around cataclysmic variables. The inner planet formed at a distance of around 2.5 AU, with a best value of 2.7 AU, which is consistent with planets found to orbit other binaries. It is unlikely that more planets formed inside the orbit of the innermost planet, but additional planets may have formed further out with higher eccentricity. The results of this study demonstrate the predictive power of measuring the orbital parameters of circum-binary planets to reconstruct the evolution of complex systems.

<summary>
• The NCMS/RGM approach has been extended to treat three-body cluster states, enabling the study of nuclear systems with three-body configurations.
• The method combines a microscopic cluster technique with realistic interactions and a consistent description of nucleon clusters.
• The extension of the NCMS/RGM approach to three-body cluster states is essential for studying systems like two-nucleon halo nuclei, resonant systems, and transfer reactions with three fragments in their final states.
• The authors have developed a formalism for treating three-cluster systems formed by two separate nucleons in relative motion with respect to a nucleus of mass number A.
• The approach has been applied to the study of the 6He nucleus, which is the lightest Borromean nucleus formed by an α core and two halo neutrons.
• The results for the ground state energy of 6He within a 4He(g.s.)+n+n cluster basis are compared to NCMS calculations, showing good convergence and stability.
• The approach has also been used to study continuum states of 6He, obtaining the experimentally well-known 2+ resonance as well as a second low-lying 0+ resonance recently measured at GANIL.

<summary>

• The experimental evidence of skyrmions in non-centrosymmetric compounds with Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction has intrigued scientists, and the preparation of thin films of B20 type MnSi on silicon substrates has offered promising prospects for spintronic devices. MnSi films offer a variety of interesting magnetic phases and are easy to integrate into devices due to the use of silicon as substrate material. The benefit of thin films compared to bulk material is the existence of the skyrmion phase in an extended region of the magnetic phase diagram.

• The drawback of using MnSi films is the low magnetic ordering temperature, which is considerably below liquid nitrogen temperature. Therefore, it is the aim to find compounds with similar spin order at higher temperatures. A suitable candidate is the B20 compound MnGe with a magnetic ordering temperature of 170K.

• The magnetic ground state of MnGe is a helical spin structure with a helix length between 3 nm at lowest temperatures and 6 nm near the magnetic ordering temperature. The helix axis is due to magnetic anisotropy pinned along the [100] direction, but rotates into the field direction in an applied field. Recently, a large topological Hall effect exceeding by 40 times that of MnSi was observed in MnGe, which was attributed to a skyrmion phase in analogy to MnSi.

• The synthesis of MnGe is considerably laborious, since it forms only under high pressure and temperatures between 600 and 1000°C. However, molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) allows for thin film growth under strong non-equilibrium conditions. Nevertheless, there has been no successful attempt to grow MnGe on Ge, since Mn and Ge tend to form MnGe3.

• The use of Si(111) as a substrate offers the opportunity to prepare a seed layer of MnSi, which realizes the B20 crystal structure for MnGe growth. The lattice constant of MnGe within the (111) plane matches that of Si with a misfit of only 2%, thus, compressively strained MnGe films may be grown on Si(111) substrates. In this paper, we show a preparation method for MnGe thin films on Si substrates with the aid of a MnSi seed layer.

• The structure and morphology of the films have been investigated by reflection high-energy electron diffraction (RHEED), atomic force microscopy (AFM), and X-ray diffraction (XRD). To determine the physical properties of the samples, magnetization

<summary>
• The paper discusses the concept of core entropy of polynomials, which is a measure of the complexity of the dynamics of a polynomial map. The core entropy is defined as the topological entropy of the restriction of the polynomial to its Hubbard tree, and it is shown to be a continuous function on the Mandelbrot set. The paper also introduces a new algorithm for computing the core entropy, which is based on the construction of a matrix that encodes the transitions between postcritical angles. This algorithm is used to prove the continuity of the core entropy function.

• The paper also develops a combinatorial framework for studying the growth rates of countable graphs with bounded cycles. This framework is used to prove a theorem that relates the growth rate of a graph to the growth rate of its weak covers. The paper also introduces the concept of a labeled wedge, which is a graph that encodes the combinatorial structure of a polynomial map. The labeled wedge is used to construct a graph that has the same growth rate as the original polynomial map.

<summary>
• The detection of X-ray, optical, and radio afterglows from gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) suggests that most long GRBs are of cosmological origin. The fireball model is favored, but the puzzle of GRBs remains unresolved. The issue of beaming, or collimation, of GRBs is still debated, and three methods have been proposed to determine the degree of beaming. The first method involves analyzing the light curve of optical afterglows, but this method is not conclusive due to various factors.

• The second method involves measuring the polarization of optical afterglows, which can be observed only under specific conditions. The third method involves searching for orphan afterglows, which are afterglows not associated with any detectable GRBs. However, the absence of large numbers of orphan afterglows does not necessarily mean that GRBs are not collimated. The measurement of the GRB beaming angle using orphan searches is extremely difficult.

• The concept of "failed GRBs" (FGRBs) is introduced, which are fireballs with Lorentz factors much less than 100 but still much greater than unity. FGRBs can produce X-ray rich GRBs or fast X-ray transients, and their afterglows can be detected. The existence of FGRBs means that there should be many orphan afterglows even if GRBs are due to isotropic fireballs. The discovery of orphan afterglows does not necessarily imply that GRBs are highly collimated.

• The derivation of a satisfactory light curve for an orphan afterglow is difficult due to the uncertainty in trigger time. However, some possible solutions are suggested, such as improving the detection limit, identifying FGRBs through their X-ray rich GRBs, and observing the rising phase of the orphan afterglow. Radio observations and microlensing effects may also provide valuable information.

• The concept of FGRBs is based on the fact that most popular progenitor models for GRBs are baryon-rich. However, cases are different for progenitor models involving strange stars, which can avoid baryon contamination. The existence of FGRBs can provide valuable information for understanding GRBs and their progenitors.

• The paper proposes that fast X-ray transients or X-ray-rich GRBs should be followed rapidly and extensively in all bands to check the concept of FGRBs. The optical afterglows from two X-ray-rich GRBs, 011130 and 011211, have been observed, and their

<summary>
• The paper reports on the X-ray afterglow observations of two gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), GRB 011211 and GRB 001025, using the XMM-Newton satellite. The observations were made several hours and days after the bursts, and the data were analyzed to study the X-ray spectra and light curves of the afterglows.

• The X-ray spectrum of GRB 011211 can be described as a simple power-law with a photon index of 2.16, modified by galactic absorption, and no significant spectral evolution was found during the observation. The X-ray flux declined during the observation, providing additional evidence for the identification of the X-ray source with the GRB.

• The X-ray spectrum of GRB 001025 is also a power-law with a photon index of 2.01, and no significant flux variability was detected, supporting the identification of the source with the GRB. The lack of an optical counterpart for GRB 001025 down to R=24.5 makes it unlikely that the X-ray source is an active galactic nucleus (AGN).

• The paper also discusses the implications of the results, including the lack of significant absorption above galactic values in the X-ray spectra, which is inconsistent with the expectation of high absorption in high-density star-forming regions. The results suggest that the X-ray spectra of GRB afterglows are generated by a common physical process and do not depend much on the differences in the burst environments.

<summary>
* The layered organic material AI3 has been studied since the 1980s and has recently attracted renewed interest due to its low-energy massless Dirac fermions under hydrostatic pressure.
* AI3 is distinct from graphene, with a smaller average Fermi velocity and a larger effective coupling constant for Coulomb-type electron-electron interactions.
* The material has a low-temperature charge-ordered phase at ambient pressure, indicating the relevance of electronic correlations.
* Ab-initio band-structure calculations have revealed the presence of additional massive carriers in the vicinity of the Fermi level.
* The interplay between massless Dirac fermions and massive carriers has not been experimentally proven until now.
* The authors present magneto-transport measurements of AI3 crystals under hydrostatic pressure, showing the existence of high-mobility Dirac carriers and low-mobility massive holes.
* The measured mobilities for the two carrier types hint at scattering mechanisms due to strongly screened interaction potentials or other short-range scatterers.
* The temperature dependence of the carrier densities and mobilities is consistent with the coexistence of Dirac and massive carriers.
* The analysis of the magneto-conductivity data allows for the extraction of the mobilities, carrier densities, and effective mass of the massive carriers.
* The results support the idea that massless and massive particles coexist in a broad pressure range, and that Dirac electrons and holes have roughly the same mobilities.

<summary>
• The spin response of Fe-based superconductors (FeBS) with two different superconducting gap scales is analyzed, and it is found that the spin resonance appears in the s± state below the indirect gap scale, which is determined by the sum of gaps on two different Fermi surface sheets connected by the scattering wave vector. The indirect gap is either Δ4 or Δ5, depending on the Fermi surface geometry.

• The criterion to determine whether the experimentally observed peak in inelastic neutron scattering (INS) is the true spin resonance is proposed: if the peak frequency is less than the indirect gap, then it is the spin resonance, and consequently, the superconducting state has the s± gap structure. Comparison of energy scales extracted from INS, Andreev spectroscopy, ARPES, and other techniques for most materials gives confidence that the observed feature in INS is the spin resonance peak.

• The results are compared with experimental data on FeBS, and it is found that the peak in INS is the spin resonance peak for most materials, but sometimes it is not always clear experimentally which gaps are connected by the wave vector, and definitive conclusions can be drawn only from the calculation of the dynamical spin susceptibility for the particular experimental band structure. The analysis provides a framework for understanding the spin response of FeBS and its relation to the superconducting gap structure.

<summary>
• The authors introduce a 2D extension of the dual random dimer model (DRDM), which is a correlated disorder model that introduces delocalized states in the spectrum of a quantum system. In the non-interacting regime, the DRDM introduces delocalized states if the resonance energy belongs to the spectrum of the unperturbed system.

• In the presence of weak interactions, the 2D DRDM drives the density spatial fluctuations, and a mode-matching argument shows that the resonance energy is at the origin of these phenomena. This leads to a non-monotonic behavior of the condensate fraction as a function of the disorder strength, and its enhancement for values close to the resonance condition.

• The authors' results show that short-range correlations in a disordered potential can modify and enhance the coherence of a many-body system in the weak interacting regime, and could be measured in the context of ultracold atoms with an accurate measurement of the density and coherence. The results could also be extended to homogeneous systems with suitable impurities that are transparent for a given energy.

<summary>
• The paper studies the maximum independent set problem in generalized Petersen graphs, which is known to be NP-hard, and provides upper and lower bounds for the independence number.
• The authors prove that the independence number of generalized Petersen graphs with fixed k can be found in linear time, O(n), where n is the number of vertices of the graph.
• The paper also presents a conjecture on the independence number of generalized Petersen graphs and verifies it for certain cases using computational results.
• The authors provide a table of independence numbers for some generalized Petersen graphs and acknowledge the help of others in creating the table and providing useful comments.

<summary>
• Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) is a method of secure communication that uses quantum mechanics to encode and decode messages.
• QKD is often said to be unconditionally secure, but in practice, it is difficult to meet the requirements for security, making it vulnerable to attacks.
• The Device-Independent Security Proof is a theoretical concept that can provide unconditional security, but it is challenging to implement in practice.
• Measurement-Device-Independent QKD (MDI-QKD) is a protocol that removes the detector side-channel attacks, making it more secure than traditional QKD.
• MDI-QKD uses a third party, called the measurement unit (MU), to perform the measurement, which can be untrusted.
• The security of MDI-QKD relies on the assumption that the preparation of the quantum signal sources by Alice and Bob is almost perfect and carefully characterized.
• The paper proposes two phase-encoding MDI-QKD schemes, which are proven to be unconditionally secure against the most general attacks.
• The first scheme uses a phase-locking technique to establish a quantum correlation between Alice and Bob, while the second scheme uses a phase-to-polarization converter to convert the phase encoding to polarization encoding.
• The security proof of the schemes is based on the idea of a virtual protocol, where Alice and Bob get together and use a quantum coin to determine their basis choices.
• The paper also provides simulations of the key generation rate for each scheme, assuming typical experimental parameters, and discusses the effects of imperfect phase modulation on the key generation rate.

<summary>
* The formation of massive stars is not well understood, and it is unclear whether they form through accretion or mergers of intermediate-mass stars. Recent high-resolution observations have provided new insights into the environment surrounding massive protostellar systems, suggesting an accretion formation scenario.

* The mid-infrared window offers a powerful view of hot molecular cores, and recent observations have found that class II methanol masers exclusively trace regions of massive star formation. These masers are associated with massive, luminous, and deeply embedded cores that characterize protoclusters of young massive stars.

* The authors observed three regions at high spatial resolution using the Michelle instrument on the Gemini North telescope, uncovering embedded sources inside the cores at mid-infrared wavelengths. The observations revealed multiple point sources at close angular separations, with the methanol masers found closest to the brightest mid-infrared point source.

* The authors used Monte Carlo simulations to estimate the probability of generating the observed mass distributions from the gas in the core using a standard form of the initial mass function. The results suggest that it is difficult to generate the observed distributions for the most massive cluster members from the gas in the core.

* The study's findings have implications for our understanding of massive star formation, and further research is needed to draw general conclusions. A larger sample of young, massive protoclusters is required to determine whether the observed mass distributions are typical or anomalous.

<summary>
• The paper discusses modified theories of gravity, particularly the @xmath0 gravity, which is a promising approach to explain the accelerating expansion of the universe. The @xmath0 gravity is a modified theory of gravity that includes a coupling between curvature and matter components. This coupling leads to a non-zero divergence of the energy-momentum tensor, which is a key feature of this theory. The authors use the reconstruction scheme to reproduce some important cosmological models in the context of @xmath0 gravity.

• The authors reconstruct the de Sitter universe, power-law solutions, phantom and non-phantom eras, and the @xmath13cdm model in the context of @xmath0 gravity. They use the field equations and the continuity equation to obtain the corresponding functions for each model. The de Sitter universe is a well-known model that describes the accelerating expansion of the universe, while the power-law solutions describe the decelerated and accelerated phases of the universe. The phantom and non-phantom eras are also discussed, and the authors find that the @xmath0 model can explain these phases.

• The authors also analyze the stability of the reconstructed models against linear perturbations. They use the perturbed field equations and continuity equation to study the stability of the de Sitter universe and power-law solutions. The stability analysis is important to determine the viability of the models. The authors find that some models are stable against perturbations, while others are not.

• The paper also discusses the reconstruction of the @xmath13cdm model in the context of @xmath0 gravity. The authors find that the @xmath0 gravity fails to reproduce the @xmath13cdm model for both cases. This result is consistent with previous studies in the context of @xmath10 gravity. The authors conclude that the @xmath0 gravity is not suitable to explain the @xmath13cdm model.

• The authors use numerical techniques to solve the perturbed equations and study the stability of the models. They find that the perturbations decay in some cases, indicating stability, while in other cases, the perturbations do not decay, indicating instability. The authors conclude that the stability analysis is important to determine the viability of the models.

• The paper concludes that the @xmath0 gravity is a promising approach to explain the accelerating expansion of the universe, but it has some limitations. The authors find that the @xmath0 gravity can reproduce some important cosmological models, but it fails

<summary>

• The proposed setup involves a hybrid quantum dot-nanomechanical resonator (qd-nr) system to detect Majorana fermions (mfs) in iron chains on a superconducting Pb surface. The qd is coupled to the nearby mf and the nr, with two kinds of coupling: qd-mf and qd-nr. The qd-mf coupling is responsible for the detection of mfs, while the qd-nr coupling enhances the coherent optical property of the qd. The system is probed using an optical pump-probe technique.

• The absorption and dispersion spectra of the probe field are calculated as a function of the probe detuning under different conditions. Without considering any coupling, the spectra show normal absorption and dissipation of the qd. With qd-nr coupling, two sharp peaks appear in the spectra, corresponding to the vibrational frequency of the nr. The qd-mf coupling introduces an additional peak in the spectra, indicating the presence of mfs.

• The qd-mf coupling strength affects the peak splitting in the absorption spectrum, which can be used to determine the coupling strength. The peak splitting width increases linearly with the coupling strength, allowing for the measurement of the coupling strength. The qd-nr coupling also affects the peak splitting, but to a lesser extent. The coupled qd-nr system enhances the sensitivity of mf detection.

• The system can be used to detect mfs in both coupled and uncoupled modes. In the coupled mode, the qd-mf coupling induces a symmetric splitting in the absorption spectrum, while in the uncoupled mode, the splitting is asymmetric. The system can also be used to measure the qd-mf coupling strength and the frequency of the nr.

• The nr plays a crucial role in the hybrid system, enhancing the coherent optical property of the qd and increasing the sensitivity of mf detection. The vibration of the nr induces a resonance amplification process in the absorption spectrum, which can be used to detect mfs. The nr can be considered as a phonon cavity, enhancing the detection sensitivity of mfs.

• The system can be used for all-optically controlled topological quantum computing based on mfs. The qd-nr system provides a platform for applications in quantum computing and quantum information processing. The proposed setup is the first all-optical means to probe mfs, providing a new approach for detecting and manipulating mfs.

• The authors acknowledge support from the National Natural Science Foundation of China and other organizations. The

<summary>
* The first evidence of time reversal symmetry violation was found in the kaon system, but no other signal has been found to date.
* Studying time reversal symmetry has become a cornerstone of the search for physics beyond the Standard Model of elementary particles.
* Theories beyond the Standard Model, such as dynamical symmetry breaking and grand unified theories, imply specific ways of time reversal symmetry violation.
* To extract hadronic degrees of freedom from observables, effective one-boson exchange potentials can be introduced, which have been proven useful in treating nuclear structure and extracting effective hadronic coupling constants.
* The purpose of the paper is to give estimates on hadronic matrix elements that arise when relating quark operators to effective hadronic parameterizations of the time reversal symmetry violating interaction.
* The simplest operator that leads to an effective time reversal symmetry violating vector-type vertex is a flavored quark field operator, which can be related to effective hadronic operators using the constituent quark model.
* The evaluation of the matrix elements of the quark operators requires further consideration, and an extensive overview of different approaches to tackle this problem has been given in previous studies.
* The resulting relation between quark and hadronic time reversal symmetry violating coupling strengths is obtained, and the values for the quark structure effects are evaluated using typical quark model parameters of low-energy phenomenology.

<summary>
• Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) are used as standard candles to measure distances to remote galaxies due to their uniform light curves and high brightness. The accreting white dwarf (WD) model is a plausible explosion model for SNe Ia, where a WD in a binary system accretes material from its companion star until it reaches the Chandrasekhar mass limit and explodes. The model predicts two main evolutionary paths leading to SNe Ia, the super soft X-ray source (SSS) channel and the symbiotic channel. The companion star that remains in the vicinity of the explosion site has not been confirmed by observations.

• A direct method to identify the companion star is proposed, which involves observing the absorption lines in the spectrum of the star. The absorption lines with broad blue wings are expected to be present only in the spectrum of the companion star located inside the ejecta of SNe Ia. The amount of Fe I in the ejecta of Tycho's SNR is estimated, and the spectra of a star located at the center of the SNR are calculated. The method can identify the companion star with high probability, but there are some factors that might reduce or erase the distinct absorption features.

<summary>
• The paper discusses the dynamics of entanglement in a cascaded qubit system, where two qubits are coupled through the one-way exchange of photons. The system is open, meaning it interacts with its environment, and the authors use quantum trajectory theory to study the evolution of entanglement. They find that the system exhibits a bimodal behavior, where it either evolves into a maximally entangled bell state or enters an entangled-state cycle.

• The authors analyze the system's behavior at resonance, where the coupling between the qubits is optimal, and find that the system's evolution is characterized by a perpetual switching between two orthogonal bell states. This behavior is referred to as an entangled-state cycle, and it is a result of the system's interaction with its environment. The cycle continues indefinitely, with the system emitting a stream of photons.

• The authors also consider the case where the inter-cavity coupling is imperfect, and find that the system still exhibits entangled-state cycles, but with a distinct difference in the count rates at detector 1. The system settles into one of two cycles, involving either symmetric or antisymmetric bell states, and the choice of cycle is random and depends on the photon counting record. The decision is the outcome of a competition between the periods of evolution between quantum jumps and the jumps themselves.

• The paper concludes by discussing the implications of the results for our understanding of entanglement dynamics in open systems. The authors note that the ensemble average state of the system is mixed, and that the entanglement between the qubits is not fixed, but rather depends on the specific realization of the photon counting record. The study provides new insights into the complex behavior of entangled systems and has implications for the development of quantum technologies.

<summary>
• The paper discusses the anisotropy of infrared emission in active galactic nuclei (AGN) and its relation to the unification scheme. The authors use a sample of quasars and radio galaxies at redshift 0.4 to study the intrinsic anisotropy of the dust torus.

• The sample is isotropically selected and complete, covering all torus inclination angles, and the authors construct average spectral energy distributions (SEDs) for quasars and radio galaxies. The ratio of type 1 to type 2 AGN in the sample decreases from 20 to 2 at wavelengths 2 to 8 microns.

• The authors find that the intrinsic ratio between type 1 and type 2 AGN is 1.4 at 15 microns, and the anisotropy is consistent with the torus being clumpy rather than smooth. The clumpy torus model reproduces the observed type 1/type 2 ratio reasonably well.

• The study shows that the silicate feature in the sample averages exhibits a "shift" of the central peak of the silicate emission feature with respect to the center of the absorption feature. The resulting central wavelengths are in agreement with previous reports.

• The authors discuss their results in the context of other anisotropy estimators and find consistency with upper limits derived from the X-ray/mid-IR correlation of local Seyfert galaxies. However, there is some discrepancy with a similar study of nearby Seyferts.

• The difference in anisotropy between the two studies may imply that nearby, radio-quiet, lower-luminosity AGN show a higher degree of anisotropy in the IR than higher-luminosity, radio-loud sources. This could be explained by a receding torus model with luminosity-dependent obscuration.

• The authors conclude that their findings are consistent with the idea that the observed anisotropy is a measure of the intrinsic anisotropy of luminous type 1 and type 2 AGN, and that the torus is likely to be clumpy rather than smooth.

<summary>
• The paper discusses the security of Continuous Variable Quantum Key Distribution (CVQKD) systems, which are vulnerable to attacks on the local oscillator (LO) intensity.
• The traditional security analysis of CVQKD assumes a constant LO intensity, but in practice, the LO intensity can fluctuate, leaving a security loophole for Eve to exploit.
• Eve can reduce the LO intensity to hide her attack and steal the secret key without being detected by Alice and Bob.
• The paper analyzes the effect of LO intensity fluctuation on the secret key rate estimation for reverse and direct reconciliation protocols.
• The results show that even a small fluctuation of LO intensity can compromise the secret key rate severely if Bob does not monitor the LO intensity or scale his measurements with the instantaneous LO intensity values.
• The paper also discusses the challenge of accurately monitoring LO intensity and the need to scale measurements with instantaneous LO intensity values to ensure the security of CVQKD systems.
• The analysis highlights the importance of considering LO intensity fluctuation in the security analysis of CVQKD systems to prevent Eve from exploiting this vulnerability.

<summary>
• The code ADIPLS is a tool for computing adiabatic oscillation frequencies and eigenfunctions for general stellar models. It offers flexibility in the choice of integration method and can determine all frequencies of a given model in a specified range of degree and frequency. The code is based on a minimal set of dimensionless variables and provides extensive documentation. The equilibrium model is defined in terms of these variables, including mass and radius.

• The code solves the equations of adiabatic stellar oscillations, which are expressed in terms of the dimensionless variables. The equations are solved using two techniques: a shooting method and a relaxation technique. The shooting method involves integrating the equations separately from the inner and outer boundaries and matching the solutions at a fitting point. The relaxation technique involves solving the equations together with a normalization condition and all boundary conditions.

• The code has options for improving the precision of the computed frequencies, including the use of a variational principle and Richardson extrapolation. The variational principle is used to determine the frequency more precisely, while Richardson extrapolation is used to cancel the leading error term in the frequency. The code also has the option to redistribute the mesh to improve the resolution of the eigenfunctions. The precision of the computed frequencies can be estimated by varying the number and distribution of mesh points.

• The code provides various outputs, including the eigenfunctions, normalized inertia, and kernels for rotational splitting. The eigenfunctions can be output in a form indicating the region where the mode predominantly resides. The code has been tested and compared with other codes, and revisions are being implemented to improve its performance. These revisions include the installation of a fourth-order integration scheme and the use of a new classification scheme for dipolar modes.

<summary>
* The authors propose a new model for the formation of HI supershells in spiral galaxies, suggesting that they are inflated by radio jets ejected from the galactic nucleus during an active phase. This model can account for the large energy requirements and symmetric features of the supershells, which are difficult to explain with traditional models involving starbursts or infalling gas clouds.
* The authors apply this model to the galaxy NGC 3556, which has two large HI supershells that are difficult to explain with traditional models. The jet-ISM interaction scenario can account for the features of these supershells, including their large energy requirements and symmetric locations at the edges of the galaxy disk.
* The model suggests that the jets inject energy into the ISM, inflating bubbles that sweep up HI gas and create the supershells. The jets may switch off after a few million years, leaving behind the supershells as a remnant of the galaxy's active phase.

<summary>
• The color-magnitude diagram (CMD) of Leo I, a dwarf spheroidal galaxy, shows a broad range of ages, from 1-15 Gyr, with a prominent red clump (RC) and a well-defined main sequence (MS) turnoff. The CMD also indicates a low metallicity, with a mean metallicity of [Fe/H] = -2.0 dex. The galaxy's stellar population is highly composite, with a large spread in age and metallicity.

• The CMD features a densely populated RC, which is more extended in luminosity than those of other dwarf spheroidal galaxies, suggesting an extended star formation history with a large intermediate-age component. The brightest stars in the MS have ages similar to those of the RC stars, and some of the variable stars found in Leo I may be classical cepheids. The galaxy's metallicity dispersion is difficult to estimate due to the large age range, but it is likely to be around [Fe/H] = -2.0 dex.

<summary>
* The paper discusses the properties of the fractional Laplacian operator with a drift term, specifically the existence of a principal eigenpair and the behavior of the corresponding eigenfunction. The authors prove that the eigenfunction is bounded and continuous, and that it decays at the boundary of the domain. They also show that the eigenvalue is simple and isolated, and that the eigenfunction is a first integral of the drift term. The results are obtained using a combination of probabilistic and analytic techniques.
* The paper also establishes a connection between the eigenvalue and the existence of a non-trivial first integral of the drift term. The authors prove that the eigenvalue remains bounded as the drift term approaches zero if and only if there exists a non-trivial first integral. They also provide upper and lower bounds for the eigenvalue, and show that it is attained. The results have implications for the study of diffusion processes with drift, and provide a new perspective on the behavior of the fractional Laplacian operator.

<summary>
• The paper explores the use of machine learning algorithms, specifically unsupervised learning, to identify phase transitions in physical systems without prior knowledge of the order parameter. The authors employ variational autoencoders, a type of neural network, to learn the underlying structure of the data and identify the order parameter. This approach is tested on the Ising model and the XY model, and the results show that the variational autoencoder can accurately identify the order parameter and the phase transition.

• The authors compare the performance of different unsupervised learning algorithms, including principal component analysis, kernel principal component analysis, and traditional autoencoders, and find that variational autoencoders outperform them. The variational autoencoder is able to learn a latent representation of the data that captures the underlying structure and correlations, allowing it to identify the order parameter and phase transition. The reconstruction loss of the variational autoencoder is also found to be a universal indicator of phase transitions.

• The paper demonstrates the ability of the variational autoencoder to handle models with continuous symmetries, such as the XY model, and to identify the order parameter and phase transition in these systems. The authors also show that the variational autoencoder can be used to identify phase transitions in systems where the order parameter is not known a priori. The approach is expected to be useful for predicting unseen phases or uncovering unknown order parameters in complex systems.

• The authors conclude that the use of machine learning algorithms, particularly variational autoencoders, provides a powerful tool for identifying phase transitions in physical systems. The approach is scalable to large datasets and can handle nonlinear features in the data. The connection between deep neural networks and renormalization group is also discussed, and the authors suggest that deep convolutional autoencoders may be useful for further exposing this connection.

<summary>
• The paper discusses the concept of "partial" quantum cloning machines (QCMs) that copy only one component of a two-partite pure state, which can be useful for eavesdropping on a quantum channel, and presents a method for constructing such QCMs for both pure and mixed states.
• The authors also explore the properties of these QCMs, including their fidelity and state-dependence, and discuss the implications of their results for quantum cryptography and informatics.

<summary>
• The nature of dark matter remains one of the biggest questions in modern astrophysics, and the cold dark matter cosmological model suggests that a major component of dark matter could be in the form of an elementary particle. However, the inventory of baryons observed locally falls short of the total inferred from cosmic microwave background fluctuations, leaving room for a significant baryonic component of dark matter. The authors investigate the possibility that cold, self-gravitating molecular clouds constitute a major component of dark matter.

• The authors use a Monte Carlo simulation code, GEANT4, to calculate the gamma-ray spectra arising from cosmic-ray interactions with dense gas clouds. They find that the emissivity of dense gas clouds is lower than previously thought, which means that the baryonic content of the galaxy's dark halo is not as tightly constrained by gamma-ray data as previously thought. The low emissivity of dense gas clouds also means that the existing gamma-ray data do not exclude purely baryonic models for the galactic dark halo.

• The authors calculate the diffuse gamma-ray emission from the galaxy using the gamma-ray production spectra obtained from their simulations. They adopt a conventional dark matter density distribution for the galaxy and a model for the cosmic-ray energy density as a function of position in the galaxy. The resulting variation of the diffuse gamma-ray emission over the sky is plotted in a figure.

• The authors revisit the published constraints on baryonic dark matter from gamma-ray data, taking into account the uncertainty in the diffuse model and the discrepancy between model and data. They find that the constraints are weaker than previously thought, and that the observed high-latitude gamma-ray intensity constrains the amount of low column-density gas to 20% of the total density of the galactic dark halo, with this fraction rising to 100% for gas clouds of column density above 100 g/cm^2.

• The authors also consider the constraints from low galactic latitudes, using the mean intensity of the inner galactic disk. They find that the emissivity of the galactic dark halo material must be, on average, around 10^-26 erg/s/atom, and that 100% of the galaxy's dark halo may be comprised of dense clouds of column density above 100 g/cm^2.

• The authors conclude that the gamma-ray spectra arising from cosmic-ray interactions with gas clouds of various column densities have been calculated using a Monte Carlo event simulator, and that the low emissivity of dense gas means that the baryonic content of the galaxy

* The study focuses on colloidal suspensions and their potential to develop novel materials through self-assembly, particularly colloidal crystals with tunable optical properties. The authors investigate the possibility of creating iridescent colors and photonic crystals using colloidal crystals. They also explore the use of external fields to control the lattice spacing of these crystals. The study combines experimental and simulation techniques to achieve this goal.

* The authors use a simple numerical treatment to predict the lattice spacing in quasi-2D crystals from the electric field strength. They consider a model system of charged colloids in a rotating electric field and calculate the effective interactions between the colloids. The interactions are treated as a combination of electrostatic repulsions and dipolar attractions. The authors use a Yukawa potential to describe the electrostatic repulsions and a dipolar potential to describe the attractions.

* The study uses Monte Carlo simulations to model the behavior of the colloidal system. The simulations are performed in the NVT ensemble, and the particles interact via the effective potential described above. The authors initialize the system in a random configuration and equilibrate it for a certain number of Monte Carlo moves. They then measure the lattice constant of the resulting crystal.

* The authors compare the simulation results with experimental data and find good agreement. They also compare the lattice constant with the minimum of the effective potential and find that it provides a good approximation. However, they note that close to melting, fluctuations lead to a larger lattice constant than the minimum of the potential. At high field strengths, the simulation results deviate from the experimental data, suggesting that higher-order terms may become important.

* The study investigates the dependence of the system on the colloid diameter. The authors find that the absolute value of the Debye length does not change significantly for different particle sizes. The contact potential has an approximately inverse cubic dependence on the particle diameter. The authors also find that the range of tunability of the lattice constant is maximized for intermediate particle sizes.

* The authors consider the possibility of using the system for display applications, where the lattice constant can be tuned to produce different colors. They find that the range of colors obtainable is governed by the lattice tunability. The study suggests that particles with diameters between 1-1.5 microns have the highest degree of tunability.

* The authors discuss the limitations of their approach, including the assumption of pairwise additivity of the interactions and the neglect of non-linear Poisson-Boltzmann contributions to the electrostatic interactions. They also

<summary>
• The outburst of Aql X-1, a soft X-ray transient, was observed to decay rapidly, with a steepening in the X-ray flux decrease, and a transition to a quiescent state, which is likely powered by a radio pulsar enshrouded by matter outflowing from the companion star.
• The observations suggest that Aql X-1 may be an old, fast-rotating neutron star that undergoes a transition to the propeller regime and then to the radio pulsar regime, providing a "missing link" between low-mass X-ray binaries and recycled millisecond pulsars.

<summary>
• The supernova SN 2006jc is a type Ib supernova that showed a bright blue continuum in its early spectra and a rapid decline in its light curve, suggesting an interaction between the supernova ejecta and circumstellar matter.
• The infrared observations of SN 2006jc indicate the formation of amorphous carbon grains in the supernova ejecta and circumstellar matter, which requires a carbon-rich environment.
• The presupernova model of SN 2006jc is a Wolf-Rayet star with a carbon-rich envelope and circumstellar matter, which is consistent with the infrared observations and the rapid decline of the light curve.
• The explosion energy and ejected mass of SN 2006jc are estimated to be around 10-20 foe and 0.1-0.2 Msun, respectively, based on the hydrodynamical and nucleosynthesis calculations.

<summary>
* The micro-quasar GRS 1915+105 is a black hole binary (BHB) exhibiting extreme variability, and a new X-ray transient source, IGR J170913-624, has been found to show similar variability patterns.
* The faintness of IGR J170913-624 is difficult to explain, even assuming a small mass and large distance, and simultaneous fitting of spectra at different phases suggests that the faintness is due to its low or negative spin.
* The results of spectral fits indicate that IGR J170913-624 is a high-inclination binary, and the lower limit on inclination angle is 76°, consistent with previous findings.
* The "heartbeat" oscillations in IGR J170913-624 can be used as a standard candle to constrain the parameters, and the observed flux during the peak of the oscillations suggests a low spin and inclination angle < 60°.
* The black hole spin in IGR J170913-624 is found to be very low or negative, in contrast to GRS 1915+105, which is known to have a very high spin.

<summary>
• The paper discusses the determination of the extinction curve, which describes how extinction changes with wavelength, and its application to astronomical objects. The extinction curve is affected by the presence of dust grains in the interstellar medium, and its characteristics differ between diffuse and dense interstellar media. The knowledge of the extinction curve is necessary to deredden magnitudes and colors of astronomical objects and to understand the physical properties of dust grains.

• The authors use the Cardelli, Clayton, and Mathis (CCM) law, which is a one-parameter family of curves that represents the UV to IR extinction law. The CCM law is very powerful because it allows one to determine the extinction in some spectral region based on the extinction in a different spectral region, given that one knows the value of the parameter R(V). The R(V) parameter ranges from about 2.0 to about 5.5, with a typical value of 3.1, and characterizes the dust properties in the region that produces the extinction.

• The authors extend the method used by previous researchers to compute R(V) values for a sample of stars with UV extinction data. They use a weighted minimization to compute R(V) values, taking into account the errors in the data, and obtain improved R(V) values for the lines of sight toward a sample of stars with known extinction data in the UV. The errors in R(V) are computed using two different methods, and the results are presented in a table.

• The authors also discuss the sky distribution of R(V) values and show that they do not differ significantly from the mean value of 3.1. They also compare their results with those obtained using a different calibration of the color excesses and find that the R(V) values obtained with the two calibrations differ by about 0.04. The authors conclude that the R(V) values obtained with their method are more accurate than those obtained with the previous method.

• The authors emphasize the importance of considering various sources of statistical and systematic errors in the determination of R(V) values. They also discuss the limitations of their method and the need for further studies to extend the analysis to other wavelength regions. The authors conclude that their method provides a more accurate determination of R(V) values and can be used to study the properties of dust grains in the interstellar medium.

• The paper provides a detailed description of the method used to compute R(V) values, including the formulae used to compute the errors, and presents the results in tables and

<summary>
• The article discusses the rank stratification of the exceptional arrangement of a weakly toric module, which is a refinement of the stratification by the rank of the associated hypergeometric system. The rank jump of the module at a parameter is computed using the combinatorics of the ranking lattices, and the rank is constant on each ranking slab. The article provides a generalization of a formula given by Okuyama in a special case.

• The article also studies the structure of the Euler-Koszul complex of maximal Cohen-Macaulay toric face modules and uses it to understand the images of maps between such modules. The Euler-Koszul homology modules of maximal Cohen-Macaulay toric modules for nested faces are described, and the article shows how images of collections of surjections overlap. This information is vital to the calculation of the rank jump of the module.

<summary>
* The paper proposes a qubit controlled by a symmetry breaking effect in a triangular triple quantum dot (tqd) system, where the qubit states are encoded in the doublet subspace and can be controlled by applied gate potentials that break the triangular symmetry. The qubit states can be manipulated by quick impulses of the electric field, allowing for Pauli X and Z gate operations.
* A new method for read-out of the qubit state is proposed, using the electric transport through tqd and the doublet blockade effect, which is compatible with pure electrical manipulations and does not require spin-to-charge conversion. The doublet blockade effect is related to an asymmetry of tunnel rates between the doublet states and the electrodes.
* The paper also considers the time-dependent electron transport in the doublet blockade regime, including the effects of leakage processes from the doublet to two-electron states, and spin-flip processes in the electrodes, which can mix the doublet subspaces with different spin orientations. The total mixing time is found to be very long, making it promising for manipulation and read-out of the qubit.

<summary>
• The symbiotic system Z Andromedae (Z And) consists of a cool giant star and a hot compact component, and has been observed to have periodic outbursts. The 1984-1986 outburst was particularly notable for its double-peaked structure and low brightness. The outburst was monitored through spectral observations, which revealed a rich number of lines that allowed for detailed modeling of the system's physical conditions.

• The wind collision model was used to calculate the line spectra, taking into account shocks, photoionization, and other factors. The input parameters included shock velocity, preshock density, and ionization parameter, among others. The model was able to reproduce the observed continuum spectral energy distribution (SED) and line ratios.

• The visual light curve of Z And during the 1984-1986 outburst showed a double-peaked structure, with a minimum between the two peaks. The minimum was accompanied by a dip in the ionization parameter, which was constrained by the detailed modeling of the UV line spectra. The sharp drop in ionization parameter was due to the sudden increase in distance between the white dwarf and the downstream nebula.

• The outburst was caused by the collision of the white dwarf wind with two ejected shells from the red giant. The collision led to the formation of a shock front, which heated and ionized the nebula. The shock front expanded at an average velocity of 130 km/s, consistent with observations.

• The distance of the nebula from the center of the system was calculated by adjusting the continuum fluxes to the observed values. The distances ranged from 1.9 x 10^14 cm to 2.7 x 10^14 cm, depending on the epoch. The filling factor was assumed to be 1.

• The 1984-1986 outburst of Z And was unique in that it did not show broad lines or collimated jets, which are typically observed in other symbiotic systems. The outburst was likely caused by the collision of the wind network with the next shell, which distorted the wind collision and prevented the outburst from reaching its maximum luminosity.

• The study's results suggest that the periodicity of the maxima in the light curve is around 300-400 days, which is consistent with the red giant pulsation period. The small peaks in the light curve before and after the 1984-1986 burst are likely due to red giant shell ejections.

• Networks of single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) are emerging as novel materials for various applications, particularly as electronic materials. The accurate determination of their fundamental electrical properties is crucial. SWCNT networks can be viewed as a two-dimensional network of conducting one-dimensional rods, with either metallic or semiconducting properties. The nanotube-nanotube junction resistance is much larger than the nanotube resistance itself, making the network a system with randomly distributed barriers for electrical transport.

• The frequency-dependent and electric-field-dependent conductivity of individual SWCNTs and some types of SWCNT networks have been investigated. Burke and co-workers measured the microwave conductivity of individual SWCNTs and investigated their operation as a transistor at 2.6 GHz. For SWCNT networks with 30 nm thickness, the ac conductivity is frequency-independent up to an onset frequency of about 10 GHz, beyond which it increases with an approximate power law behavior. The conductivities at dc and 10 GHz are almost the same for thicker films with thickness in the range of tens of micrometers.

• There is a lack of frequency and electric field dependent conductivity investigation for systematic variation of network densities, and no correlation study between the onset frequency and the length scale determined from nonlinear transport. The frequency- and electric-field-dependent conductivity investigation of different network densities is important for building a comprehensive understanding of the electrical transport properties of SWCNT networks. This knowledge is required for applications such as high-speed transistors, transparent shielding materials, and interconnects in circuits. The use of SWCNT networks as interconnects in circuits requires understanding of their electric field-dependent properties.

• In this paper, the frequency- and electric-field-dependent conductivity for SWCNT networks with systematically varying densities were investigated. The onset frequency extracted from the frequency dependence measurement increases with the film thickness, while the length scale extracted from the electric field dependent measurement decreases at the same time. Using the measured onset frequency and the extracted length scale for different films, an empirical relation between the two transport measurement methods was developed. SWCNT networks on polyethylene terephthalate (PET) substrate were prepared by the spraying method.

• The network density, defined as the number of nanotubes per unit area, was controlled by the solution concentration and the spraying time. The nanotubes formed bundles with size of 4-7 nm and length of 2-4 μm. The thicknesses of the films range from submonolayer to 200 nm, corresponding to room temperature

<summary>
• The proposed scheme implements a three-qubit Grover's algorithm using four-level superconducting quantum interference devices (SQUIDs) coupled to a single-mode superconducting resonator. The algorithm involves three-qubit phase gates and single-qubit gates, and the implementation time is significantly faster than previous proposals. The scheme does not require adjustment of level spacing during operation, slowly changing Rabi frequencies, or second-order detuning.

• The effects of imperfections in the system, including cavity decay and level decay, are considered, and the results show that the marked state can be searched with high fidelity even in the presence of these imperfections. The fidelity of the three-qubit phase gate and the success probability of the Grover's algorithm are calculated, and the results are presented in figures. The scheme is compared to previous proposals, including one using flying qubits and another using adiabatic passage.

• The physical implementation of the scheme is discussed, including the generation and absorption of single microwave photons in high-Q cavities using SQUIDs. The coupling constants of each SQUID with the resonator are different, allowing for non-uniformity in device parameters. The scheme has potential for the realization of quantum information processing and quantum computing using SQUIDs and superconducting resonators.

<summary>
* The many-body effects on XPS (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy) spectra were studied in the 1970s, particularly the effects of shake-up processes on the XPS peak. The shake-up effects result in plasmon replicas in the spectrum, which are shifted to lower kinetic energy by the plasma frequency.

* The sudden approximation is used to derive the XPS line shape, which assumes that the excitation process is very fast and the electrons do not have time to relax around the core hole. The core hole is treated as a classical particle, and the interaction with the electrons is described by a pure Coulomb potential.

* The adiabatic approximation is also discussed, which assumes that the excitation process is very slow and the electrons have time to relax around the core hole. In this case, the interaction term in the Hamiltonian is changed into a constant energy term, resulting in a shift of the XPS peak to higher kinetic energy.

* The Green's function is used to calculate the XPS spectrum, which is related to the density of states of the core electron. The Green's function is expressed in terms of the boson propagator and the dynamical structure factor of the system.

* The boson propagator is replaced by the dynamical structure factor of the system, which includes contributions from both plasmons and electron-hole pairs. The coupling constant is also modified to include the interaction between the core hole and the boson excitations.

* The XPS spectrum is calculated for doped graphene, which shows a typical 2D plasmon dispersion. The result is similar for any finite doping density.

* The final expression for the XPS spectrum is given, which includes the effects of all excitation processes in the system. The spectrum reflects the density of states of the core electron and is expressed in terms of the satellite generator and the boson propagator.

<summary>
• The article analyzes a two-genotype system with asymmetric mutation probabilities and nonlinear fitness functions, using the Moran process to model the evolutionary dynamics.
• The authors derive the Fokker-Planck equation to describe the system's behavior and find that asymmetric mutation rates can lead to the emergence of new stable points and shifting of existing ones.
• The study suggests that nonlinear frequency-dependent fitness can induce complex evolutionary dynamics, potentially leading to multiple metastable equilibria and sudden shifts in species frequencies, even in the absence of environmental changes.

<summary>
* The phase-field method is a popular approach for simulating microstructure formation during solidification, but it has limitations and challenges that need to be addressed.
* One of the main challenges is the thin-interface limit, which can lead to errors in simulations if not properly handled.
* The antitrapping current is a technique used to eliminate the temperature jump at the interface, but it is not sufficient to eliminate all thin-interface effects.
* Another thin-interface effect is the kapitza resistance, which is a surface thermal resistance that arises from the finite interface thickness.
* The kapitza resistance cannot be eliminated by the antitrapping current and requires a different approach.
* Orientation-field models are used to simulate the evolution of polycrystals, but they have their own limitations, such as not taking into account the connectivity of matter.
* The evolution equation for the angle field in orientation-field models is not consistent with the coherent crystalline structure of matter and can lead to qualitatively wrong predictions.
* Fluctuations are often included in phase-field simulations in a qualitative way, but a more quantitative approach is needed to accurately capture their effects.
* The fluctuation-dissipation theorem can be used to determine the coefficients of the Langevin terms in the field equations, but the physical meaning of the resulting expressions needs to be carefully considered.

<summary>
• The authors investigate the determination of atmospheric parameters (effective temperature, surface gravity, and metallicity) of stars using spectroscopic methods. They use a sample of metal-poor FGK stars from the RAVE survey and develop a new method that combines Balmer line analysis with non-local thermodynamic equilibrium (NLTE) corrections for iron lines. This method provides more accurate estimates of atmospheric parameters compared to traditional methods.

• The authors compare their new method with the traditional method of excitation-ionization balance of iron lines in local thermodynamic equilibrium (LTE). They find significant systematic biases in the traditional method, particularly for metal-poor stars, which can lead to errors in the determination of stellar masses, ages, and distances.

• The Balmer line method is used to determine effective temperatures, which are found to be more accurate than those obtained from photometric methods. The authors also investigate the effects of NLTE corrections on the determination of surface gravity and metallicity, and find that these corrections are necessary to eliminate discrepancies between Fe I and Fe II lines.

• The authors apply their new method to a sample of stars with interferometrically determined angular diameters and find good agreement between the two methods. They also compare their results with those obtained using other methods, such as the infrared flux method, and find good agreement.

• The authors investigate the implications of their results for the determination of stellar masses, ages, and distances. They find that the use of accurate atmospheric parameters is crucial for obtaining reliable estimates of these quantities, and that the traditional method can lead to significant errors.

• The authors conclude that their new method provides a more accurate and robust way of determining atmospheric parameters of stars, particularly for metal-poor stars. They also highlight the importance of using accurate effective temperatures and NLTE corrections for iron lines in the determination of surface gravity and metallicity.

• The authors plan to apply their method to larger samples of stars in the future, including those from the Gaia mission, and to investigate the implications of their results for our understanding of the structure and evolution of the Milky Way galaxy.

<summary>
• The paper investigates the effects of weak gravitational lensing on the observed magnitudes of type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) and finds a correlation between the magnitudes and the foreground galaxy distribution. The correlation suggests that SNe Ia are amplified by the gravitational lensing effect of foreground mass concentrations. The significance of the correlation is estimated to be better than 99.6%.

• The analysis uses a sample of 55 SNe Ia from the Supernova Cosmology Project and the High-Z Supernova Search Team, and the galaxy distribution is traced by the APM galaxy catalog. The SNe Ia are corrected for cosmological distances and extinction, and the galaxy distribution is characterized by the rank statistic. The results are robust against various tests, including changes in the galaxy magnitude limit and the radius of the circles around the SNe Ia.

• The paper also explores the possibility of galactic dust as an alternative explanation for the observed correlation, but finds that it is unlikely to be the dominant cause. The dust extinction would need to be highly correlated with the galaxy distribution, which is not supported by observations. Additionally, the correlation is seen in both the northern and southern hemispheres, making dust extinction an unlikely explanation.

• The results are consistent with the predictions of weak lensing theory, which suggests that the amplification of SNe Ia should be correlated with the foreground galaxy distribution. The observed correlation is also consistent with the expected signal from weak lensing, given the optical depth of the galaxy distribution. The paper concludes that the observed correlation is likely due to weak gravitational lensing.

• The paper also presents a simple lensing model that reproduces the observed correlation, using a probability distribution function (PDF) for the convergence of the galaxy distribution. The model assumes a standard cosmology and a biasing scheme that relates the galaxy distribution to the underlying mass distribution. The model is able to reproduce the observed correlation for a range of optical depths and biasing parameters.

• The model is tested against a range of optical depths, from 0.011 to 0.13, and the results are found to be insensitive to the specific value of the optical depth. The model is also tested against different biasing schemes, and the results are found to be insensitive to the specifics of the biasing scheme. The paper concludes that the slope of the magnitude-galaxy correlation depends on the amount and distribution of matter, but not on the specifics of the biasing scheme.

* The paper discusses the theoretical framework for studying heavy fermion (HF) metals, which are characterized by strong electron correlations and a large effective mass. The authors use the periodic Anderson model (PAM) to describe the behavior of HF metals, and employ the dynamical mean field theory (DMFT) to solve the model. The DMFT approach allows for the calculation of single-particle dynamics and transport properties, and is particularly useful for studying the strong coupling regime of HF metals. The authors also discuss the importance of the local moment approach (LMA) in capturing the physics of HF metals.

* The authors present results for the single-particle dynamics of HF metals at finite temperatures, which exhibit universal scaling behavior in terms of the low-energy lattice scale. The scaling spectra depend on the conduction band filling and the f-level asymmetry, and crossover from quasiparticle behavior at low energies to single-impurity Kondo scaling physics at high energies. The authors also discuss the behavior of the Drude weight and the dc conductivity in the strong coupling regime. The results are summarized in figures, which show the scaling spectra and the crossover behavior.

* The paper also discusses the application of the LMA to the study of transport and optical properties of HF metals. The authors present results for the dc resistivity and the optical conductivity, which exhibit universal scaling behavior in terms of the low-energy lattice scale. The results are compared to experimental data, and the authors discuss the implications of their findings for our understanding of HF metals. The paper concludes with a summary of the main results and an outlook for future research.

* The kinetics of polymer loop formation has been studied for several decades and has recently gained attention due to its importance in biology. DNA loop formation is a basic process that underlies genetic expression, replication, and recombination. The hairpin loop formation is an elementary step in protein folding and structure formation in RNA folding. A cell is crowded with various subcellular structures, including globular proteins and RNAs, which interact with DNA.

* The advance of single-molecule experiment techniques provides detailed information on DNA loop formation. Finzi and Gelles observed Laci-mediated DNA loop formation and dissociation by monitoring nano-scale Brownian motion of a micron-sized particle attached to one end of the DNA. Et al. showed that mechanical constraints such as tension and torsion play a pivotal role in Gal repressor and DNA-bending protein Hu-mediated looping. Gemmen et al. studied the effects of tension in the presence of two-site restriction enzymes.

* Theoretically, Yan et al. developed a transfer matrix method to calculate semiflexible polymer end-to-end distance distribution function and loop formation probability. They studied various effects of nonlinear elasticity arising from DNA bending protein-induced kinks or thermal-fluctuation-induced bubbles on the loop formation probability. Their study provides valuable insights to understand DNA bending on short length scales. They also studied the effects of tension on the loop formation probability.

* In this paper, the authors perform Brownian dynamics simulation of semiflexible polymers treated as extensible wormlike chains, combined with one-dimensional theory of barrier crossing over the free energy of loop formation. They use the mean-field wormlike chain model as an example to understand the effects of static tension on semiflexible polymer looping. The looping time, defined as the mean first-passage time to cross the free energy barrier, steeply increases with the applied tension.

* The authors study the effects of static tension on semiflexible polymer looping and find that the normalized looping time increases exponentially with the tension. The reason is that, for the short chain lengths considered, the free energy of the loop formation increases with the tension, so the looping time increases approximately exponentially with the tension. The theory of ref. considered that, for low tension, the looping time increases exponentially with the tension because of the Gaussian force-extension relation they used.

* The authors also study the effects of time-dependent tension on semiflexible polymer looping, considering dichotomically fluctuating tension. The looping time has a resonant minimum at an optimum flipping time, which is a nontrivial extension of the resonant
