<summary>
* The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) was established in response to the September 11 attacks, with the goal of ensuring security in all modes of transportation. TSA has made significant progress in improving aviation security, but vulnerabilities remain.

* Before September 2001, there were weaknesses in screening passengers and baggage, controlling access to secure areas, and protecting air traffic control computer systems and facilities. TSA has taken steps to address these weaknesses, including deploying federal screeners and implementing security requirements.

* TSA has implemented congressional mandates and explored options for increasing the use of technology and information to control access to secure areas and improve passenger screening. The agency has also developed initiatives to use its passenger screening resources more efficiently.

* The agency has taken steps to strengthen the security of air traffic control computer systems and facilities, including establishing an information systems security management structure and implementing a certification and accreditation process. However, challenges remain in increasing intrusion detection capabilities and accrediting all air traffic control facilities.

* Vulnerabilities remain in air cargo, general aviation, and airport perimeter security, including the potential for undetected explosive and incendiary devices in cargo and the lack of screening of general aviation pilots and aircraft. TSA is working to address these vulnerabilities, including developing a comprehensive plan for air cargo security.

* TSA faces longer-term challenges in the areas of risk management, funding, coordination, strategic human capital management, and building a results-oriented organization. The agency has adopted a risk management approach to guide its efforts and is working to develop tools to assess criticality, threats, and vulnerabilities.

* Funding is a significant challenge, with costs associated with equipment and personnel needed to screen passengers and baggage alone estimated to be huge. TSA is exploring options for paying for these costs, including the use of letters of intent with airports.

* To sustain aviation security advancements, TSA must form effective partnerships with federal, state, and local agencies, as well as the aviation community, and ensure that the terrorist and threat information gathered and maintained by law enforcement and other agencies is quickly and efficiently communicated among federal agencies and to state and local authorities.

<summary>
* The Lobbying Disclosure Act (LDA) and the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) have different definitions of lobbying, which can affect registration and reporting requirements. The LDA definition covers contacts with federal officials, while the IRC definitions cover contacts with state and local officials, as well as grassroots lobbying. The differences in definitions can result in organizations reporting different information and expenses.

* The LDA definition covers all federal officials, including executive and legislative branch officials, while the IRC definitions have different coverage depending on the subject of the lobbying contact. The IRC definitions also have exceptions for certain types of lobbying, such as nonpartisan analysis and self-defense. These exceptions can result in organizations excluding certain expenses from their reports.

* Organizations that lobby on their own behalf can choose to use either the LDA or IRC definition for reporting purposes. This can affect what information they report and whether they meet the registration thresholds. Using an IRC definition can result in organizations reporting less information and fewer expenses.

* The choice of definition can also affect which individuals are listed as lobbyists on an organization's registration. The LDA definition requires individuals to be listed if they make more than one lobbying contact and spend at least 20% of their time lobbying. The IRC definitions have different requirements for listing individuals as lobbyists.

* The reported expenses and information may not be comparable between organizations using different definitions. Organizations using the LDA definition report only federal lobbying expenses, while organizations using the IRC definitions report expenses for state, local, and grassroots lobbying. This can make it difficult to compare the lobbying efforts of different organizations.

* The differences in definitions can result in organizations not registering under LDA, even if they meet the registration thresholds. This can limit the public's ability to know about the lobbying efforts of certain organizations. The current system also allows organizations to switch between definitions from year to year, which can make it difficult to track their lobbying efforts over time.

* Options for revising the statutory framework include harmonizing the definitions, eliminating the authorization for using IRC definitions for LDA reporting, and requiring organizations to report only federal lobbying expenses when using an IRC definition. Each option has its advantages and disadvantages, and would require careful consideration of the impact on registration and reporting requirements.

<summary>
• The federal government has been slow to adopt strategic sourcing practices, despite the potential for significant cost savings, with only 5% of federal procurement spending being managed through strategic sourcing efforts in 2011. The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and other agencies have taken steps to expand the use of strategic sourcing, including issuing guidance and setting goals for agencies to strategically source certain products and services.

• Leading companies have successfully implemented strategic sourcing practices to manage services, achieving savings of 4-15% over prior year spending, and have developed category-specific procurement strategies with stakeholder buy-in. These companies focus on total cost of ownership, regularly review strategies and tactics, and tailor their approach to each service based on complexity and supplier availability.

• The federal government's reluctance to apply strategic sourcing to services stands in contrast to leading companies, which perceive services as prime candidates for strategic sourcing. Federal agencies have difficulty defining requirements for services, leveraging knowledge of contractor costs, and increasing competition for services due to overly restrictive and complex requirements.

• To improve strategic sourcing efforts, agencies need to address impediments such as obtaining and analyzing reliable data, securing expertise and leadership support, and developing metrics to measure success. By adopting leading practices, agencies can drive efficiencies and yield benefits beyond savings, such as increased business knowledge and better supplier management.

<summary>
* The current surface transportation programs in the US are not effectively addressing the nation's transportation challenges, and a fundamental transformation is needed. The programs are fragmented, with many goals and funding sources, but lack a clear vision and federal role. A new approach is required to create a more focused, performance-based, and sustainable program.

* The federal role in surface transportation should be reexamined to ensure that it is sustainable and effective in addressing national interests. This includes identifying areas of national interest, establishing clear goals and performance measures, and ensuring that funding is targeted and efficient. The federal government should also consider the role of state and local governments, as well as the private sector, in achieving national transportation goals.

* The current funding structure for surface transportation is unsustainable, with a growing imbalance between revenues and expenditures. The Highway Trust Fund, which is the primary source of funding for federal surface transportation programs, is projected to be depleted in the near future. New funding sources and financing mechanisms, such as user fees and public-private partnerships, should be explored to address the funding gap.

* The federal government should consider a range of options to improve the performance and accountability of surface transportation programs, including the use of performance measures, incentives, and penalties. The government should also promote the use of best practices and innovative technologies to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of transportation systems. Additionally, the government should ensure that transportation programs are aligned with national goals and priorities.

* The transformation of surface transportation programs will require a long-term commitment to change and a willingness to experiment with new approaches. The federal government should work with state and local governments, as well as the private sector, to develop and test new models for delivering transportation services. The government should also engage with stakeholders and the public to ensure that the needs and concerns of all users are taken into account.

<summary>
• The current funding system for the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has concerns about revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency, as the taxes collected from users do not accurately reflect the costs they impose on the system. The system's reliance on excise taxes, such as the passenger ticket tax and fuel tax, creates inequities and inefficiencies, and does not provide users with incentives to use the system efficiently.

• Alternative funding options, such as weight/distance charges, en-route charges, flight segment charges, and certification charges, have been proposed to address these concerns, but each has its own limitations and challenges, including administrative and transition issues. These options aim to create a more direct relationship between revenues and costs, but their ability to address equity and efficiency issues is limited by the complexity of the system and the need for accurate cost analysis.

<summary>
* The Institute of Medicine published a report in 1993 discussing secret US chemical weapons programs during World War II, which involved 60,000 military personnel in tests of exposure to mustard agents and lewisite. The report found that many servicemembers may have been exposed to these substances through production, transportation, and storage. In response, the Deputy Secretary of Defense issued a memo releasing individuals from nondisclosure restrictions and tasked the military departments to declassify and provide information to the VA. The Chemical Weapons Exposure Study Task Force was established to identify exposed individuals.

* The task force identified 6,400 servicemembers and civilians who were potentially exposed to chemical substances, and a database was created with information about these individuals. The task force also issued certificates of commendation to over 700 individuals for whom contact information was found. In 2000, the acting Secretary of Veterans Affairs requested assistance from the Secretary of Defense to obtain information about classified chemical and biological tests. The Defense Authorization Act for FY 2003 required DOD to submit a plan to review, declassify, and provide records to the VA.

* DOD identified 5,842 servicemembers and estimated 350 civilians who were potentially exposed during Project 112 tests, and this information was entered into a database. The act also required DOD to work with veterans and veterans service organizations to identify projects outside of Project 112 that may have exposed members of the armed forces to chemical or biological substances. However, DOD ceased actively searching for additional individuals in 2003 without a sound cost-benefit analysis. The decision was made without objective analysis of the potential costs and benefits of continuing the effort.

* The Office of Management and Budget stated that a good cost-benefit analysis should include a statement of assumptions, rationale, and review of strengths and weaknesses. DOD's decision was based on the assumption that the bulk of exposures related to Project 112 tests had already been identified. However, additional individuals have been identified since then, including 394 individuals identified by the Institute of Medicine and 39 individuals identified by the GAO. DOD's current effort to identify individuals potentially exposed to chemical or biological substances lacks clear and consistent objectives, scope of work, and information needs.

* The objectives of DOD's current effort are inconsistent, and the scope of work has expanded to include exposures resulting from immunizations, transportation, storage, and occupational accidents. The amount and type of information to be collected have also been expanded. DOD's current effort lacks adequate oversight of

<summary>
* The Mexican government has been combating criminal groups, including drug trafficking organizations (DTOs), since 2006, with a shift in emphasis towards reducing criminal violence under President Enrique Peña Nieto.
* The Mérida Initiative, a bilateral security partnership between the US and Mexico, has provided funding and support to combat organized crime, including firearms trafficking, since 2008.
* The majority of firearms seized in Mexico and traced by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives (ATF) originated in the US, with most coming from the Southwest border states.
* Firearms trafficking from the US to Mexico often involves straw purchases, where individuals buy firearms on behalf of criminals, and the use of untraceable firearms parts, such as 80% receivers.
* The ATF and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) have taken steps to improve coordination on firearms trafficking, including signing a memorandum of understanding in 2009, but challenges persist, including information sharing and role confusion.
* The Mexican government has centralized access to ATF's eTrace system and suspended meetings of the GC Armas working group, which has limited bilateral collaboration on firearms trafficking.
* Despite challenges, US and Mexican officials have reported increased cooperation on firearms trafficking in recent years, including the resumption of GC Armas meetings and joint training exercises.

<summary>
*NCHIP is a federal grant program managed by the Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS) to improve the accuracy, completeness, and accessibility of criminal history records. The program aims to build a national infrastructure to facilitate the interstate exchange of criminal history and other relevant records. Since its initiation in 1995, NCHIP has provided over $438 million in federal grants nationwide.

*NCHIP funds are used to support various activities, including improving criminal history records, implementing technology to support the automated transfer of fingerprint data, and enhancing sex offender registries. States use NCHIP funds to automate criminal history records, improve disposition reporting, and enhance protection order activities. The funds are also used to support national security and antiterrorism activities.

*The National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) is a primary system that benefits from NCHIP. NICS is used to conduct background checks on individuals purchasing firearms, and it relies on the accuracy and completeness of criminal history records. However, automated information on the disposition of felony and other potentially disqualifying arrests is not always widely available, which can lead to delays in responding to presale firearms inquiries.

*The Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS) has recognized the importance of improving access to domestic violence misdemeanor records, mental health records, and substance abuse records. However, these records are often not available nationally due to various challenges, including federal laws and state laws that prohibit sharing certain information. BJS has encouraged states to use NCHIP funds to make improvements in these areas.

*The demand for background checks is growing, driven by screening requirements for employment and other noncriminal justice purposes. The number of civil fingerprint submissions to the FBI has increased substantially in recent years, and the growth is partly attributable to federal legislation that encourages states to have procedures requiring fingerprint-based national searches of criminal history records. The FBI and BJS officials expect the number of applicant background checks to be in the millions as homeland defense laws are fully implemented.

*The future of NCHIP will depend on various factors, including the extent of cumulative progress in creating national, automated systems that cover all needed types of information. Policymakers will need to consider the demand for background checks, the need for periodic upgrades or replacements of automated systems, and the importance of long-term funding commitments from all governmental levels.

<summary>
• The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) established the Superfund program to clean up the nation's most contaminated hazardous waste sites. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) investigates and places the most highly contaminated sites on the National Priorities List (NPL) for study and cleanup. EPA selects incineration as a cleanup remedy for some sites, which involves burning substances in a controlled flame to destroy contaminants. As of 1996, EPA had selected incineration as a remedy 43 times, or about 6% of the decisions on remedies.

• EPA employs various techniques to ensure the safe operation of Superfund incinerators, including mechanical features like air monitors and operational procedures like 24-hour independent oversight. However, EPA has not followed through on opportunities to improve its oversight, such as having RCRA hazardous waste incinerator inspectors evaluate Superfund incinerators and systematically sharing lessons learned from site to site. EPA officials agree that the lessons learned should be documented, but question the benefits of preparing voluminous site-specific studies. The agency has not implemented its guidance for having RCRA inspectors evaluate Superfund incinerators, including developing a single document specifying site-specific operating requirements and procedures.

<summary>
• The Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) financial statements for fiscal years 2007 and 2006 are presented fairly and in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. However, misstatements may occur in other financial information reported by SEC due to internal control deficiencies.

• The SEC did not maintain effective internal control over financial reporting as of September 30, 2007, due to a material weakness and significant deficiencies in internal control. This material weakness relates to the period-end financial reporting process, disgorgements and penalties accounts receivable, accounting for transaction fee revenue, and preparing financial statement disclosures.

• The SEC's financial management system does not conform to the systems requirements of OMB Circular No. A-127, resulting in a lack of integration and compatibility between automated systems and the general ledger system. This leads to manual and labor-intensive accounting procedures, increasing the risk of errors and affecting the reliability of financial data.

• The SEC's process for calculating accounts receivable for disgorgements and penalties is prone to errors, and the lack of written procedures and inadequate review of spreadsheet calculations increases the risk of significant errors. Errors were found in the calculation of accounts receivable for disgorgements and penalties, which were corrected by the SEC.

• The SEC's accounting for transaction fee revenue is also prone to errors, and the lack of written procedures and inadequate review of estimates increases the risk of significant errors. An audit adjustment was proposed and posted to correct the amount of transaction fee revenue for fiscal year 2007.

• The SEC's financial statement disclosures contained numerous errors, including misstated amounts, improper break out of line items, and incorrect beginning balances. The errors were corrected by the SEC, and the cause of the errors was attributed to the lack of a documented timeline and process for completing the fiscal year 2007 financial statements and disclosures.

• The SEC has significant deficiencies in internal control over information security, property and equipment, and accounting for budgetary resources, which increase the risk of material misstatements in the agency's financial statements. These deficiencies include weaknesses in access controls, configuration management, physical security, and contingency planning, among others.

<summary>
* The Postal Service had about 765,000 career employees at the end of fiscal year 1997, with 80,238 EAS positions, which accounted for about 10% of total career-level employees. The Service's diversity program aimed to provide equal employment opportunities to all employees and compete effectively in the communications marketplace.
* The Aguirre report found that women and minorities were underrepresented in EAS 17 and above positions, and that a "glass ceiling" existed, impeding their progression to higher-level positions. However, the report's finding was based on a comparison of EAS positions with the 1990 Census Labor Force (CLF), which may not be an appropriate comparison.
* The Service developed 23 initiatives in response to the Aguirre report, aimed at strengthening its diversity program and improving diversity in its workforce. As of December 1998, the Service reported that it had completed implementation of nine of the initiatives and was on schedule for completing the remaining initiatives.
* The Service collects a variety of diversity-related data, but does not have reliable data on the flow of applicants through its promotion processes, which would help identify and remove barriers to the promotion of women and minorities. The Service is in the process of developing specific targets and measures to track its progress in meeting its diversity goals and objectives.
* The Aguirre report's finding of a "glass ceiling" was not supported by convincing evidence, and our analysis found that women and minorities were generally represented in and were being promoted to EAS 17 and above positions. However, women and minority representation was generally lower in EAS 17 and above positions than it was in EAS 11 through 16 positions.
* We recommended that the Postmaster General ensure that the Service captures EEO group data on promotion applicants and uses these data to identify barriers that might impede promotions to high-level EAS positions. The Service concurred with our recommendation and plans to reemphasize the need to enter data into the Promotion Report System.

<summary>
• The US Department of Defense (DOD) defines a Military Working Dog (MWD) as any canine bred, procured, or acquired to support operations in the protection of installations, resources, and personnel. MWDs can be deployed to assist in operations outside of their assigned military installation and are removed from service when they can no longer perform their duties due to medical or behavior problems.

• The DOD has a process for removing MWDs from service, which includes a review board that makes decisions about adoption, transfer, or euthanization, and uses three systems to track information about MWDs, including their removal from service. The number of MWDs adopted or transferred has varied over the past 5 years, with the highest numbers in 2012 and 2013, and prevalent medical conditions among adopted MWDs include skin, dental, and musculoskeletal issues.

<summary>
* The Comanche program was established in 1983 to replace the Army's light helicopter fleet with a low-cost, lightweight, advanced technology helicopter capable of performing armed reconnaissance and attack missions. The program has experienced significant cost growth, with the estimated program acquisition unit cost increasing from $12.1 million in 1985 to $34.4 million in 1995. The program has also experienced schedule delays, with the development phase extended by 3 years. The Army plans to acquire 1,292 aircraft, but the program's cost and schedule issues have raised concerns about its affordability and feasibility.

* The program's software development is a significant risk, with 1.4 million lines of code required to perform and integrate mission critical functions. The development and integration of on-board, embedded computer systems is a significant program objective, but software development problems still exist, including delays in software development and testing. The lack of a uniform, qualified compilation system among software developers could put first flight at risk. The program is also experiencing high turnover of software engineers, which has contributed to schedule slippage in several critical software development areas.

* The program's maintainability requirements are important to achieving lower operating and support costs and wartime availability goals, but key maintainability requirements such as direct maintenance man-hours per flight hour, mean time to repair, and fault isolation may not be achievable. The Army established a 2.6 direct maintenance man-hours per flight hour requirement, but this requirement has been debated and may not be realistic. The program's fault isolation requirement is also at risk, with the contractor team predicting a 69-percent fault isolation rate, which is below the required 80 percent. The program's mean time to repair requirement is also at risk due to the cure time required for composite material used on the aircraft.

* The program's weight growth is also a concern, with the empty weight increasing from 7,500 pounds to 7,883 pounds. Weight increases affect vertical rate of climb performance on the Comanche, and if the weight exceeds 8,231 pounds, the engine will have to be redesigned to produce enough power. The program's weight growth has been managed within acceptable limits, but it remains a concern. The Army's maintenance concept for the Comanche program is predicated on two levels of maintenance - unit- and depot-level maintenance.

* The program's restructuring has provided additional time and aircraft to operationally test the Comanche prior to making any production decisions, but the approach continues the risks associated with making production decisions

<summary>
• The Food Stamp Program provides eligible low-income households with paper coupons or electronic benefits to purchase food. The program is funded by the Food and Nutrition Service (FNS), which also establishes regulations and monitors state performance. States implement the program by determining eligibility, calculating benefits, and issuing benefits to households.

• Households must meet certain requirements to be eligible for benefits, including a gross income not exceeding 130% of the federal poverty level and assets not exceeding $2,000. Recipients of TANF cash assistance are automatically eligible for food stamps, and states can extend categorical eligibility to families receiving TANF-funded services or benefits. FNS offers options to allow households to own a vehicle worth more than the allowed amount and remain eligible for benefits.

• States can use various options and waivers to simplify the eligibility determination process, reduce the reporting burden on working families, and minimize payment errors. These options include quarterly and semiannual reporting, and waiving the requirement to report changes in earned income of $25 or more per month. States can also use the Transitional Benefit Alternative to provide a fixed food stamp benefit to families leaving TANF for a certain period.

• FNS monitors states' performance through a quality control system, which assesses payment errors and accuracy in determining eligibility and calculating benefits. States are penalized if their payment error rate is higher than the national average, and errors can occur due to mistakes by recipients, caseworkers, or incorrect determination of household income. States can use various strategies to minimize payment errors, such as certifying households with earnings for shorter periods and requiring more frequent reporting.

• The Simplified Food Stamp Program option allows states to merge their TANF and Food Stamp Program rules into a single set of requirements, but no state has implemented this option due to its complexity and difficulty in implementation. Some states have used parts of the simplified program, such as aligning their food stamp and TANF work requirements, to reduce the reporting burden on households. States have also suggested changes to the reporting requirements and payment error calculations to improve the program's effectiveness.

<summary>
* The Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) is the principal federal agency responsible for programs in four areas: housing assistance, community development, housing finance, and regulatory issues.
* HUD provides housing assistance through public housing authorities and private-market housing assistance under Section 8 of the U.S. Housing Act of 1937.
* The agency provides community planning and development funds for local economic development, housing development, and assistance to the homeless through various programs.
* HUD's housing finance programs include mortgage insurance and guarantees for single-family and multifamily properties.
* The agency is responsible for regulating interstate land sales, home mortgage settlement services, manufactured housing, lead-based paint abatement, and home mortgage disclosures.
* HUD's fiscal year 2000 budget proposal includes 19 new initiatives and programs, with a total budget of about $28 billion in new discretionary budget authority.
* The agency's budget proposal raises concerns about its capacity to manage the increase in new programs and initiatives while undergoing organizational reform.
* HUD's Section 8 housing assistance program is one of the largest program increases in the fiscal year 2000 budget proposal, with a request for over $3 billion in contract renewal funding.
* The agency's Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) Program provides grants for activities that benefit low- and moderate-income people, but its budget proposal includes set-asides for new initiatives that may not be sufficiently reported and considered for budget request offsets.

<summary>
• The Military Health System operated by DOD has a dual health care mission, providing medical services and support to the armed forces during contingency operations and to beneficiaries, including active duty personnel, their families, and retirees.
• The replacement medical center will serve as the only tertiary-level referral hospital for the EUCOM, Central Command, and Africa Command theaters of operation, and is being designed to accommodate contingency operations with the flexibility to expand capacity during surges.
• DOD officials used checklists and discussions with external health care providers to incorporate updated patient quality of care standards into the facility requirements, including evidence-based design and world-class standards, and environmentally friendly design standards.
• However, the planning documentation revealed gaps, inconsistencies, and calculation errors that required extensive explanation by DOD officials, and the cost estimate for the replacement facility minimally documented the data sources, calculations, and estimating methodologies used.
• The cost estimate was updated as project requirements were better defined, and was validated by an independent firm, which concluded that the cost estimate was valid and within 1 percent of the size and cost listed on the DD Form 1391.

<summary>
* ICE officers have discretion in the apprehension and removal process, but the exercise of discretion is limited by clearly prescribed policies and procedures, particularly for aliens who are investigation targets or have committed certain crimes. Officers have more latitude to exercise discretion when encountering aliens who are not fugitives or criminals and have humanitarian issues. The initial phases of the apprehension and removal process, including the decision to apprehend and detain, involve the most discretion.

* ICE guidance on the exercise of discretion is not comprehensive and has not been updated to reflect expanded worksite and fugitive operations, which has resulted in a lack of assurance that management directives will be conducted as intended. The lack of comprehensive guidance puts ICE officers at risk of taking actions that are not appropriate exercises of discretion and do not support the agency's operational objectives. ICE has recently begun to update its training curricula to better support officer decision making.

* ICE has control mechanisms in place to monitor its removal operations, including supervisory review practices and an inspection program, but these mechanisms do not provide a way to analyze information specific to the exercise of discretion across all field offices. The ability to collect and analyze data on officer decision making could provide ICE with additional assurance that it can identify and respond to areas that may require corrective action. ICE does not have a mechanism to collect and analyze data on officers' exercise of discretion in determining what removal processing option to employ.

<summary>
* Ground ambulance services are provided by a wide range of organizations that differ in organizational structure, staffing types, types of transports offered, and revenue sources. Medicare payments for ambulance services are made up of two components: a service-level payment for the type of transport provided and a mileage payment. Providers may be affiliated with an institution, such as a hospital or fire department, and share resources and operational costs, or they may be independent and freestanding. Providers may also rely heavily on volunteers, use both volunteers and paid staff, or use only paid staff.

* The costs of providing ground ambulance transports were highly variable in 2010, ranging from a low of $224 per transport to a high of $2,204, with a median cost per transport of $429. The variability of costs per transport reflected differences in certain provider characteristics, such as volume of transports, intensity of Medicare transports, and level of government subsidies received. Providers reported that personnel costs accounted for the largest percentage of their total costs in 2010 and contributed the most to increases in total costs between 2009 and 2010. The median cost per ground ambulance transport for providers in the sample was $429 in 2010.

* The Medicare margin, including add-on payments, was about positive 2 percent in 2010 for the 153 providers in the sample. When add-on payments were removed, the median Medicare margin was negative 1 percent for those providers. Ambulance transports for all Medicare fee-for-service beneficiaries in the nation increased by 33 percent from 2004 to 2010, with super-rural areas experiencing the largest increase. The increase in Medicare beneficiaries' use of ambulance services did not appear to be caused by changes in the demographic characteristics of beneficiaries.

* The study found an association between increased resources and increased costs in the ambulance industry, similar to what has been found in the hospital industry. The results of the regression analysis suggested that ambulance providers that receive a greater proportion of government subsidies tend to have higher costs. The study also found that providers' use of volunteer staff did not significantly contribute to differences in providers' total costs. The cost of fuel has increased since 2010, which likely lowered Medicare payments and increased costs for some providers.

<summary>
• The Department of Defense (DOD) has a department-wide office responsible for leading the development of supply chain policies and improving accountability, visibility, and control of critical assets, including SRC I ammunition. The Army plays a prominent role in managing SRC I ammunition, as it procures a majority of the department's ammunition and provides wholesale storage for the other military services. The Army depots ship SRC I ammunition owned by other military services to their respective locations.

• The military services have maintained accountability of SRC I ammunition at sampled locations, but gaps were identified in service-level guidance and procedures for accounting across locations. The Air Force does not track SRC I ammunition by serial number, but has plans to revise its guidance. The Army and Marine Corps generally track SRC I ammunition by serial number, but the Air Force tracks by quantities within production lot numbers.

• The military services generally recorded shipment and receipt of SRC I ammunition in their accountability systems, but there were instances where receipting was not done in a timely manner. Army and Marine Corps guidance do not specify a time frame for receipting SRC I ammunition, while Air Force guidance specifies immediate receipting. The Army and Marine Corps have not finalized guidance that addresses the required time frame for receipting SRC I ammunition.

• The Air Force and Navy have policies regarding maintaining in-transit accountability for shipped SRC I ammunition that generally adhere to DOD requirements, but the Army's policy and processes do not fully adhere. The Army does not maintain accountability for all in-transit items within the logistics records for that materiel until there is a formal acknowledgement of receipt. The Army's systems do not maintain in-transit tables that show items that have been shipped out of one location and are due in to another.

• The military services have not consistently ensured timely, complete, and accurate information to maintain full visibility of SRC I ammunition in the continental United States. The Army has taken action to improve visibility, including modifying a contract to require the prime contractor to report receipt of shipments to WARS-NT. The military services did not always enter timely, accurate, and complete information in DTTS, which limited the information available to aid the Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command's tracking of SRC I ammunition by satellite.

<summary>
• The Social Security Administration (SSA) is the largest producer, collector, and user of information in the United States, with a vast amount of personal data on individuals. SSA collects and maintains personal information such as name, date of birth, address, and Social Security numbers (SSNs) to distinguish among individuals and ensure they receive the services or benefits they are entitled to under the law. The agency is responsible for issuing SSNs and maintaining records of individuals' wages and earnings.

• SSA's disclosure policy is designed to protect individuals' privacy while permitting the exchange of records required to fulfill its administrative and program responsibilities. The policy is more restrictive than the Privacy Act and the disclosure policies of most federal agencies, with the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and the Census Bureau being exceptions. SSA's policy requires consideration of several factors before disclosing information to law enforcement agencies.

• SSA's disclosure policy allows for the sharing of limited information with law enforcement agencies under certain conditions, such as fraud or other criminal activity in Social Security programs, nonviolent crimes and criminal activity in similar benefit programs, and violent and serious crimes. The policy requires that law enforcement requests be in writing, specify the information being requested, and be signed by an official of the requesting agency. SSA officials must also determine whether the agency requesting the information has jurisdiction in the particular case.

• SSA's Office of the Inspector General (OIG) is authorized to disclose individuals' personal information to law enforcement agencies under a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with SSA. The OIG can disclose whether a given name and SSN match the name and SSN in SSA's records, and can open an investigation and participate in joint investigations with law enforcement officials. The OIG is required to submit an annual report to the Commissioner of SSA on the number of SSN verification requests received and responses made.

• The inconsistent application of SSA's disclosure policy may be due to the infrequency of law enforcement requests, the complexity of the policy, and the conflicting responsibilities of assisting law enforcement and protecting individuals' privacy. SSA field offices may not maintain records of law enforcement requests, making it difficult to assess the consistent application of the policy. The SSA OIG, however, maintains records of requests made by law enforcement agencies and reports aggregated data annually to the Commissioner of SSA.

• Law enforcement officials are generally satisfied with the information provided by SSA, although most would like more information on individuals. SSA's disclosure policy is not readily available to law enforcement, and some officials are unfamiliar with the process for obtaining information from

<summary>
• The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) aims to minimize threats to human health and the environment by regulating hazardous waste management. RCRA's requirements, however, can create disincentives for cleaning up contaminated sites, leading to increased costs and time.

• The land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and permit requirements under RCRA are particularly problematic for remediation waste. These requirements can be overly stringent and costly, leading parties to choose less aggressive cleanup methods or avoid cleanup altogether.

• EPA has established policy and regulatory alternatives to mitigate the impact of RCRA's requirements, including the "contained-in" policy, permit waivers, and the corrective action management unit (CAMU) rule. These alternatives aim to provide flexibility and reduce cleanup costs.

• However, the alternatives have limitations and are not consistently applied across the country. Some state and industry cleanup managers are unfamiliar with the alternatives or are hesitant to use them due to legal and technical uncertainties.

• EPA proposed a comprehensive regulatory reform in 1996, known as the Hazardous Waste Identification Rule for Contaminated Media (HWIR-Media), which aimed to exempt certain remediation waste from RCRA's requirements. However, stakeholders disagreed on the approach, and EPA ultimately decided to withdraw the proposal.

• The HWIR-Media proposal included two approaches: the "bright line" approach, which would exempt contaminated media below a certain concentration level, and the "unitary" approach, which would exempt all remediation waste. Stakeholders had differing opinions on the approaches, with some preferring the unitary approach and others the bright-line approach.

• EPA concluded that comprehensive reform of RCRA's requirements for remediation waste can best be achieved through legislative action, rather than regulatory changes. The agency plans to pursue narrower regulatory reforms in the meantime.

• The report recommends that EPA take steps to ensure consistent understanding and application of its policy and regulatory alternatives among regulators and cleanup managers. This could include consolidating guidance documents, providing training, and offering legal assistance.

• Ultimately, comprehensive reform of RCRA's requirements is necessary to address the barriers to cleaning up contaminated sites and to provide a more efficient and effective approach to managing remediation waste.

<summary>
* Before 1996, Medicare's program integrity activities were subsumed under its general administrative budget, leading to funding constraints and limited ability to conduct audits and review medical claims. In 1996, the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) established the Medicare Integrity Program (MIP) and provided dedicated funding for program integrity activities. MIP funding has increased over the years, from $438 million in 1997 to $714 million in 2005.

* MIP funds are allocated to five program integrity activities: audit, medical review, secondary payer, benefit integrity, and provider education. The allocation of funds among these activities has varied over the years, with audit and medical review receiving the largest shares. Provider education has received the smallest percentage of MIP funds.

* The allocation of MIP funds is based primarily on historical funding levels, with some consideration given to high-level priorities. However, this approach does not take into account data or information on the effectiveness of one activity over another in ensuring the integrity of Medicare. CMS officials acknowledge that this approach may not be optimal.

* CMS tracks the return on investment (ROI) for medical review and secondary payer activities, but not for audit, benefit integrity, and provider education. The ROI for medical review and secondary payer has been significant, with $21 and $37 returned for every dollar spent, respectively. However, the ROI for audit has been inconsistent and is currently not accurately tracked.

* CMS has not evaluated the strategies used to modify provider behavior through education to determine if they are achieving desired results. The agency has also not adjusted the amount of funding for individual contractors to educate providers based on their relative risks. This may result in inefficient allocation of funds.

* The amount of MIP funds provided to contractors to conduct benefit integrity activities is not directly tied to the amount of benefits paid in their jurisdictions. This may result in inefficient allocation of funds to areas with high risk of fraudulent billing. CMS has not adjusted the amount of funding for individual contractors based on their relative risks.

* CMS has modified its audit focus to align with changes in Medicare's payment methods, but has not evaluated whether funds within the audit activity should be reallocated to generate greater savings. The agency has also not allocated funds to audit a panel of providers, which could provide a means to highlight areas where cost reporting accuracy is problematic.

* The Medicare program is undergoing significant changes, including the addition of the prescription drug benefit and the reform of Medicare contracting. These changes will require CMS to make new choices in

<summary>
• The performance of passenger and checked baggage screeners in detecting threat objects at US airports has been a long-standing concern, with screeners failing to detect prohibited items in various tests. In 1978, screeners failed to detect 13% of potentially dangerous objects, and in 1987, they failed to detect 20%.

• The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) was established in 2001 to strengthen aviation security, and it has taken steps to improve screener training and performance. TSA has provided three categories of required screener training, including basic, recurrent, and remedial training.

• TSA has enhanced its basic screener training program by updating the curriculum, deploying a new dual-function screener training course, and allowing local staff to deliver training. The new course covers both passenger and checked baggage screening functions.

• Recurrent training is required for screeners, with a minimum of 3 hours per week averaged over a quarter year, but some airports face challenges in providing this training due to staffing shortages and lack of high-speed internet connectivity. TSA has developed online training modules and tools to support recurrent training.

• Leadership and technical training courses have been developed for Screening Supervisors, but some Field Security Directors (FSDs) have identified additional training needs, including courses on communication, supervision, and conflict resolution. TSA's Online Learning Center provides several courses that cover these topics.

• FSDs have reported challenges in providing recurrent training, including insufficient staffing and lack of high-speed internet connectivity at some training facilities. TSA has begun deploying high-speed connectivity to airports, but the process has been slow.

• TSA lacks a plan for prioritizing and scheduling the deployment of high-speed connectivity to all airport training facilities, which limits its ability to make prudent decisions about how to move forward. TSA has distributed training products using multiple delivery channels, including written materials and CD-ROMs.

• TSA has not established clear policies and procedures for monitoring completion of basic, recurrent, and remedial training, and lacks a system to facilitate review of training records. TSA's Online Learning Center provides a centralized tool for maintaining training records, but weaknesses exist in the reporting capability.

• TSA has improved its efforts to measure and enhance screener performance, but these efforts have primarily focused on passenger screening rather than checked baggage screening, and TSA has not yet finalized performance targets for several key performance measures.

<summary>
* The IRS has 10,000 customer service representatives at 25 call sites, operating 24/7 to provide toll-free service to taxpayers. The Operations Center controls the network, forecasting call demand, planning staffing, and monitoring site performance. The IRS faces challenges in determining the optimal staffing level for its toll-free operations.

* The IRS lacks a long-term, desired level-of-service goal based on taxpayer needs, instead determining staffing levels based on available funding. This approach is inconsistent with federal guidance and industry practices, which set goals based on customer needs. The IRS plans to set strategic goals and staff accordingly.

* The IRS recognizes the need to establish long-term goals and is considering adopting measures used by other organizations. For fiscal year 2001, the IRS plans to measure the percentage of callers who reach IRS within 30 seconds, with a goal of 49% and increasing to 85-90% by fiscal year 2003. The IRS is also developing a national recruiting strategy to target areas where it can be a competitive employer.

* The six call sites visited faced challenges in recruiting, training, and retaining customer service representatives. Officials cited difficulties in recruiting due to job characteristics, training representatives, and retaining skilled representatives. The IRS is refocusing its training program to provide just-in-time training targeted to specific types of questions taxpayers call about at different times of the year.

* The IRS does not actively monitor attrition or determine what steps are needed to address it. Officials do not track how many representatives leave, why they leave, or where they go, which would be key to a strategy for decreasing attrition. The IRS is working with the Office of Personnel Management to develop competency models and assessment instruments for use in training and development.

* The IRS faces challenges in effectively scheduling staff, having the right number with the right skills at the right time at each call site. Inaccurate demand forecasting and a complicated staff scheduling process contribute to the problem. The IRS is adapting an automated system to facilitate forecasting demand, scheduling staff, and tracking adherence to the schedule.

* The IRS' method for measuring site adherence to its prescribed staffing requirements is incomplete, considering only the average number of representatives available to answer calls, not the required skills. The IRS is working with a contractor to refine the automated system, which will identify individual site staffing options for meeting network requirements.

* The IRS evaluates its human capital practices to make improvements in areas such as recruiting or training, but the evaluations do not assess how individual or collective human capital policies and practices affect its

<summary>
• Ginnie Mae is a government-sponsored enterprise that guarantees mortgage-backed securities (MBS) backed by government-insured or guaranteed loans, primarily from the Federal Housing Administration (FHA) and the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). Ginnie Mae's guarantee ensures timely payment of principal and interest to investors, reducing credit risk. This allows investors to purchase Ginnie Mae MBS with confidence, providing liquidity to the mortgage market.

• Ginnie Mae's securitization process involves pooling government-backed loans into MBS, which are then sold to investors. The agency provides a guarantee of timely payment of principal and interest, and issuers pay a guarantee fee for this service. Ginnie Mae's guarantee is backed by the full faith and credit of the US government.

• Ginnie Mae's market share of government-backed loans has remained relatively constant, but its share of the overall MBS market has declined significantly since 1985. This decline is due to the growth of the conventional MBS market, which has become more attractive to investors. Despite this, Ginnie Mae remains a dominant player in the government-backed loan market.

• Ginnie Mae's securities are considered highly liquid, with a low risk of default. The agency's guarantee and the government backing of the underlying loans make its MBS attractive to investors. However, some market participants have expressed concerns about the liquidity of certain Ginnie Mae securities, particularly those with smaller issue sizes.

• Ginnie Mae faces competition from other secondary market players, such as Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, but they have not significantly eroded Ginnie Mae's market share. These entities have focused on the conventional loan market, and their products are not directly comparable to Ginnie Mae's government-backed MBS. Private label issuers have also increased their market share, but they primarily focus on non-government-backed loans.

• Ginnie Mae's outstanding volume of MBS has declined in recent years, primarily due to refinancing activity in the conventional market. This decline has reduced the agency's fee income and excess revenues, which contribute to reducing the federal budget deficit. However, Ginnie Mae's program income still exceeds its expenses, and the agency remains financially self-sufficient.

• Ginnie Mae has taken steps to respond to changes in the market and meet the needs of its stakeholders. The agency has expanded its product offerings, improved loan disclosure, and enhanced its data systems. Ginnie Mae has also worked to maintain its commitment authority and ensure adequate capacity to plan, manage, and oversee contractors.

• Ginnie

<summary>
• The Department of Defense (DOD) has made significant improvements to its controls to identify and prevent illegal and otherwise improper closed account adjustments, resulting in an 80% reduction of closed account adjustments during the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002. However, DOD still has a long way to go to resolve its financial management and contract payment problems. The DOD's implementation of controls to identify and prevent illegal and otherwise improper adjustments seems to be having a positive effect, but there is a risk that new ways may be developed to circumvent the controls. The DOD's internal controls and management commitment to this problem must be sustained to prevent illegal or otherwise improper closed account adjustments from reoccurring.

• The DOD has agreed to reverse and correct the $172 million of illegal and otherwise improper closed account adjustments identified in the report, and to review an additional $1.1 billion of fiscal year 2001 adjustments. The DOD estimates that it will take several hundred hours to correct the accounting for each of the 30 contracts that require reaudit. The DOD plans to complete the reaudits and corrections by September 30, 2004. The DOD's efforts to correct the problems will require a sustained commitment over a number of years.

• The DOD's use of numerous Allocation Control Records Numbers (ACRNs) and changes in contract payment allocation terms contribute to the need for adjustments to closed accounts. The DOD has started to write contracts with more specific payment allocation terms, which should reduce payment errors and adjustments. The DOD has also issued a policy to prohibit contract modifications that change payment terms in a way that would result in illegal or otherwise improper adjustments. The DOD's implementation of this policy should help reduce errors that require subsequent correcting.

• The Congress has two options to consider: taking no legislative action and allowing the DOD to adjust closed account records when appropriate, or amending the account closing law to prohibit any adjustments to an appropriation account after it is closed. Prohibiting all adjustments to closed accounts would eliminate the substantial time and expense associated with making them, but would also mean that known errors in accounting records could not be corrected once the account was closed. The Congress could also provide a variation of this option by allowing the DOD a limited period to adjust the accounting records for known errors.

• The DOD's financial management and contract payment problems are long-standing and complex, and there are no quick fixes. The DOD's top management team must sustain its commitment to addressing

<summary>
• The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) was established in 1998 to privatize the management of the domain name system, with the goal of increasing competition, stability, and representation.
• The Department of Commerce issued a White Paper in 1998 outlining the principles for the transition, including stability, competition, representation, and private, bottom-up coordination.
• ICANN was tasked with developing and testing procedures for managing the domain name system, including creating a new top-level domain name system, expanding the pool of available domain names, and formalizing relationships with root server operators.
• Despite progress in some areas, ICANN has faced challenges in implementing its mission, including slow progress on key tasks, controversy over its governance structure, and concerns about its ability to ensure the stability and security of the domain name system.
• The Department of Commerce has provided limited oversight of ICANN's activities, with officials stating that they do not want to direct ICANN's actions or comment on its progress, but rather allow it to develop its own capabilities.
• The transition process has reached a critical juncture, with ICANN's president calling for fundamental reform and the Department of Commerce facing a decision on whether to extend its agreement with ICANN or seek a new arrangement.

<summary>
* The Office of Special Trustee (OST) was established in 1994 to reform the management of Indian trust funds, and it has made progress in implementing trust reforms, but a timetable for completing the reforms is still lacking. The 1994 Act required OST to develop a comprehensive strategic plan, which was issued in 2003, but it did not include a timetable for completing the reforms.

* OST has implemented several key trust reforms, including the Trust Funds Accounting System (TFAS), Trust Beneficiary Call Center, and Trust Portal, which provide improved services to beneficiaries. However, the implementation of these reforms has been slow, and some are still ongoing.

* The Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) and OST are implementing the Trust Asset and Accounting Management System (TAAMS) to manage land title records and leasing activities, but the project has experienced delays and cost overruns. TAAMS is expected to be fully implemented by November 2007.

* OST has also implemented the Probate Case Management and Tracking System to manage and track probate cases, and the Appraisal Management System to centralize the appraisal process. These systems are expected to improve the management of Indian lands and resources.

* Despite progress in implementing trust reforms, OST has not developed a plan for future trust fund operations once reforms are completed. The Special Trustee believes that OST's staff will need to continue to perform their functions after trust reforms are completed.

* OST has relied heavily on contractors to implement trust reforms, with nearly 21% of its budget going to contracting in fiscal years 2004 and 2005. The majority of contracting funds went to two firms, CNI and SEI Investments.

* OST's contracting practices have been criticized, with allegations of preferential treatment of certain contractors and a lack of transparency in the contracting process. An Inspector General's report found that senior OST officials created an appearance of preferential treatment of a contractor.

* OST plans to reduce its budget by terminating contracts as reforms are completed, but it has not developed a workforce plan to reexamine staffing levels and funding needs. This may result in opportunities for realigning or further reducing expenditures and staffing levels.

* The Special Trustee is required to provide the Congress with a timetable for completing the trust fund management reforms, but this has not been done. The Congress needs this information to oversee OST's implementation of the trust reforms and plan for trust fund operations once reforms are completed.

<summary>
• The US Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) and the Department of Defense (DOD) have been working together to develop a comprehensive, lifelong medical record for each service member and veteran. They have made progress in sharing patient health data through various initiatives, including the Federal Health Information Exchange (FHIE) program, which allows for the one-way transfer of data from DOD's health information system to VA's system. The departments have also developed demonstration projects, such as the Bidirectional Health Information Exchange (BHIE) and the Laboratory Data Sharing Interface (LDSI), which enable the two-way exchange of health information between VA and DOD facilities.
• Despite progress, the departments still face challenges in achieving their long-term goal of creating a virtual medical record based on the two-way exchange of computable data between their health information systems. They need to overcome issues such as incomplete data in their repositories, develop a more detailed project management plan, and finalize security policies. The success of the initiative depends on the departments' ability to institute a highly disciplined approach to project management and overcome these challenges.

<summary>
• The Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) outlines the desired outcome of an income tax audit as determining the correct taxable income and tax liability of the person or entity under audit. The auditor has a responsibility to conduct a quality audit, and IRS uses nine audit standards to define audit quality. These standards address issues such as scope, techniques, technical conclusions, reports, and time management of an audit.

• Audit workpapers provide documentation on the scope of the audit and the diligence with which it was completed. According to the IRM, audit workpapers assist in planning the audit, record procedures applied, and provide support for technical conclusions. They also provide the basis for review by management.

• The primary tool used by IRS to control quality under the nine standards is the review of ongoing audit work by group managers. Group managers are responsible for the quality of audits done by the auditors they manage. They review audit workpapers during the audit to identify problems with audit quality and ensure corrections.

• The Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) collects information about the audit process, changes to the process, level of audit quality, and success of efforts to improve the process and quality. EQMS staff review audit workpapers and assess the degree to which the auditor complied with the audit standards. To pass a standard, the audit must pass all of the key elements.

• The workpaper standard requires that workpapers provide the principal support for the auditor's report and document the procedures applied, tests performed, information obtained, and conclusions reached. The five key elements for this workpaper standard involve fully disclosing the audit trail and techniques used, being clear and organized, ensuring tax adjustments agree with IRS forms, adequately documenting audit activity records, and protecting taxpayers' rights to privacy and confidentiality.

• The review of IRS audit workpapers found that IRS auditors did not always meet the requirements laid out under this workpaper standard. Problems included tax adjustments not agreeing, required documents or summaries missing, and workpapers not being legible or complete. IRS has historically found problems with the quality of its workpapers, with EQMS indicating that auditors met all key elements of the workpaper standard in no more than 72% of audits.

• Supervisory review of audit workpapers is a primary tool in IRS' efforts to control quality, but there was little documentation of such reviews. Group managers are required to review workpapers if taxpayers disagree with the auditor's report, but the IRM does not specifically require that all supervisory reviews be documented in the workpapers.
