* Program evaluations are systematic studies that use research methods to address specific questions about program performance, and they can provide valuable insights to improve program management and decision making. Evaluations can assess the achievement of a program's objectives and other aspects of performance in the context in which the program operates.

* The Government Performance and Results Act (GPRA) Modernization Act of 2010 (GPRAMA) established an expectation that evidence would have a greater role in agency decision making, and it changed agency performance management roles, planning, and review processes. GPRAMA also required agencies to establish agency priority goals and government-wide cross-agency priority goals.

* The Performance Improvement Council, which includes Performance Improvement Officers (PIOs) from all 24 CFO Act agencies, facilitates agencies' exchange of successful practices and the development of tips and tools to strengthen agency performance management. OMB's guidance implementing GPRAMA also directed agencies to conduct strategic reviews of annual progress toward each strategic objective in their strategic plans.

* In 2017, a survey of federal managers found that 40% of managers reported having access to recent evaluations of their programs, and about half of those managers reported that evaluations contributed to improving program management or performance and assessing program effectiveness. Evaluations can provide a valuable supplement to ongoing performance reporting by measuring results that are too difficult or expensive to assess annually.

* Managers who reported having evaluations credited them with contributing to a great or very great extent to assessing program effectiveness or implementing changes to improve program management or performance. Evaluations can help identify for whom or under what conditions a program or approach is effective or ineffective, and the reasons for change (or lack of change) in program performance.

* The primary purpose of program and policy evaluations is to provide systematic evidence on how well a program is working, whether it is operating as intended or achieving its intended results. Evaluations can be especially useful for helping improve program performance when they help identify areas where a program or approach is effective or ineffective.

* Managers who reported having access to recent evaluations of their programs rated lack of resources to implement evaluation findings as the most common barrier to evaluation use, followed by lack of leadership support for evaluation, and lack of staff knowledgeable about interpreting or analyzing program evaluation results. Managers also reported that difficulty distinguishing between the results produced by the program and results caused by other factors was a barrier to evaluation use.

* Factors that facilitate evaluation use include agency leadership support for evaluation, staff involvement, and evaluation relevance to decision makers. Experienced evaluators have told us that building a strong body

<summary>
• The federal government has taken steps to improve the hiring and retention of individuals with disabilities, but more needs to be done to achieve the goals set by the executive order. OPM has developed a framework for agencies to improve their disability hiring plans, but many agencies' plans do not meet the necessary criteria. Regular reporting on agency progress and addressing plan deficiencies are crucial to achieving the executive order's goals.
• To become a model employer of individuals with disabilities, OPM should expedite the development of mandatory training programs for hiring managers and human resource personnel, and assess the accuracy of data collected on the SF-256 form. OPM should also explore options to improve the accuracy of the data, such as encouraging employees to voluntarily disclose their disability status. By taking these steps, OPM can better measure progress towards the executive order's goals and improve the employment of individuals with disabilities in the federal government.

<summary>
• The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is developing the Automated Land and Mineral Record System (ALMRS) to manage public lands and resources, which will provide an efficient means to record, maintain, and retrieve land description, ownership, and use information. The system is expected to automate land and mineral records and case processing activities, increase public access to BLM records, and integrate multiple databases into a single geographically referenced database.

• The ALMRS project has been ongoing since the 1980s, with a total life-cycle cost estimate of $403 million, and is expected to be completed by the end of fiscal year 1996. However, the project schedule is tight, and slippages could occur due to the complexity of the tasks and the limited time available to deal with unexpected problems.

• The system will be deployed at approximately 200 BLM sites around the country, and will provide connections to the Internet, with security measures in place to protect the system from intrusion. The public will have access to selected ALMRS information in public access rooms, and the system is expected to improve the management of public lands and resources.

<summary>
• The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has strengthened its safeguards to detect and prevent the diversion of nuclear material for military purposes, but faces limitations and challenges in its ability to effectively implement these safeguards, including a lack of information on the nuclear activities of certain countries and a looming human capital crisis. The IAEA's Additional Protocol, which provides for more intrusive inspections and monitoring, has been adopted by many countries, but not all, and its effectiveness is still untested.

• The Nuclear Suppliers Group, a multilateral export control regime, has helped to curb nuclear proliferation by establishing guidelines for the export of nuclear materials and equipment, but its effectiveness is limited by the lack of sharing of complete export licensing information among member states and the need for consensus decision-making. The group is examining changes to its procedures to assist IAEA's efforts to strengthen safeguards, including requiring non-member countries to adopt the Additional Protocol as a condition of supply.

<summary>
* The Year 2000 computing crisis poses a high risk to critical services provided by the government and private sector, including financial transactions, flights, power, and national defense. The crisis is caused by the inability of many computer systems to process dates beyond the year 2000, which could lead to system failures and disruptions. The impact of these failures could be widespread and have serious consequences.

* The information and telecommunications sector is particularly vulnerable to the Year 2000 problem, as it is critical to the operations of nearly every public and private organization. The sector's failure could have a ripple effect on other industries, including finance, healthcare, and transportation. The failure of telecommunications systems could also have a significant impact on emergency services.

* The global nature of the problem is a major concern, as many countries are not adequately prepared to address the Year 2000 issue. A survey of 127 countries found that only 18 had a national Year 2000 program in place, and many others were unaware of the problem or had not started addressing it. The lack of international coordination and cooperation could exacerbate the problem.

* The federal government's progress in addressing the Year 2000 problem has been slow, with only 40% of mission-critical systems reported as compliant as of May 1998. Many agencies have not adequately assessed their systems, and those that have are still in the process of renovating and testing them. The government's lack of progress increases the risk of system failures and disruptions.

* State and local governments also face significant risks from the Year 2000 problem, as they rely heavily on computer systems to provide vital services such as benefits payments, transportation, and public safety. Many states have not adequately assessed their systems, and those that have are still in the process of renovating and testing them. The lack of progress at the state and local level increases the risk of service disruptions.

* Data exchanges between federal, state, and local governments, as well as with the private sector, are also at risk due to the Year 2000 problem. The failure of these exchanges could have a significant impact on the delivery of vital services, including healthcare and financial transactions. The lack of progress in addressing data exchanges increases the risk of system failures and disruptions.

* To address the Year 2000 problem, strong leadership and partnerships are essential. The government must take immediate action to assess, renovate, and test its systems, and must work with the private sector and international partners to ensure a coordinated response. The public must

<summary>
* The Information Quality Act (IQA) requires federal agencies to ensure the quality, objectivity, utility, and integrity of the information they disseminate. The act was enacted in 2001 and applies to all executive branch agencies. OMB developed guidelines for agencies to follow in implementing IQA, and agencies were required to develop their own guidelines by the end of fiscal year 2002. Agencies were also required to establish administrative mechanisms for correcting information.

* OMB's guidelines emphasized the importance of agencies applying IQA principles in a common-sense and workable manner, and encouraged agencies to incorporate IQA standards into their existing administrative practices. Agencies were required to post their IQA guidelines and correction mechanisms on their websites. OMB also required agencies to report annually on their implementation of IQA, including the number and nature of IQA complaints and how they were handled. However, many agencies did not fully comply with these requirements.

* Despite OMB's efforts, many agencies failed to fully implement IQA. Only 14 of 15 cabinet-level agencies had IQA guidelines in place by the deadline, and many independent agencies did not have guidelines or correction mechanisms in place. Additionally, many agencies did not make their IQA information easily accessible on their websites. OMB did not provide sufficient guidance on how to make IQA information accessible, and agencies did not receive additional funding to implement IQA.

* The number of IQA requests decreased significantly from fiscal year 2003 to fiscal year 2004, largely due to changes in how agencies classified and processed requests. Substantive requests, which required more time and resources to address, accounted for a larger proportion of requests in fiscal year 2004. Agencies were more likely to correct information in response to simple or administrative requests, while substantive requests were more likely to be appealed. Businesses, trade groups, and other profit-oriented organizations filed the majority of appeals.

* OMB and agencies do not track the costs or resources associated with implementing IQA, making it difficult to assess the impact of the law. However, evidence suggests that addressing IQA requests can be time-consuming and resource-intensive, particularly for substantive requests. OMB and agencies have opportunities to improve the implementation of IQA, including enhancing public access to IQA information and promoting greater transparency and accountability in the development and dissemination of information.

<summary>
* Mutual funds and banks are financial intermediaries that raise funds from savers and channel them back to the economy through investments and loans. The relative importance of bank loans as a source of finance has been declining since the 1960s, with companies increasingly tapping securities markets for their financial needs. As a result, corporations' reliance on bank loans as a percentage of their credit market debt declined from 28% in 1970 to 20% in 1994.

* The household sector has also become less dependent on bank loans for financing, with major portions of home mortgage portfolios being sold to financial intermediaries who use them as collateral for marketable securities. This process, known as securitization, has further diminished the importance of bank loans as a source of finance. Through securitization, banks and thrifts provide initial financing, but the securities market becomes the ultimate source of financing.

* The term securitization describes the process by which securities issuance supplants bank credit as a source of finance, even if the borrower originally received funds from a bank. Nonbank financial intermediaries, including securities firms, insurance companies, and finance companies, have also increased their provision of direct loans, further reducing the importance of bank loans. This shift has led to a decline in the relative importance of bank loans as a source of finance.

* The report examines the impact of mutual funds on deposits, including both direct withdrawals and customers' diversion of new receipts that otherwise might have been placed in deposits. The total net flows into mutual funds from all sources during 1990-1994 were $1,067 billion, but the impact on deposits had to be less than this amount since there were also flows into mutual funds from nondeposit sources. The evidence indicates that mutual funds have attracted sizable amounts of money that otherwise might have been placed in bank deposits.

* The report estimates that the total impact of mutual funds on deposits may have been sizable, but probably less than $700 billion, based on the relationship between deposits and overall economic activity. The deposit-to-GDP ratio has been pushed down by a number of factors, including a dramatic downsizing of the savings-institution industry, a decline in loans at commercial banks, and a shift by banks into greater use of nondeposit funding sources. The movement of money from bank deposits to mutual funds should have little if any effect on the total supply of loanable and investable funds available to the economy.

* Both mutual funds and banks generally invest a substantial portion of the funds they receive

<summary>
• The Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act of 2002 requires specific activities related to bioterrorism preparedness and response, including improving coordination and planning, developing priority countermeasures, and enhancing state, local, and hospital preparedness and response. The Secretary of HHS is responsible for establishing an integrated system of public health alert communications and surveillance networks among federal, state, and local public health officials, as well as health-related laboratories, hospitals, and other health care facilities.

• CDC's PHIN initiative is a national initiative to implement a multiorganizational business and technical architecture for public health information systems, which includes various applications such as Health Alerting, Epi-X, NEDSS, BioSense, and Outbreak Management System. These applications are intended to improve public health systems and networks and provide a means for exchanging data with other federal agencies, state and local government agencies, the private health care sector, and others.

• DHS is pursuing two major biosurveillance IT initiatives, the National Biosurveillance Integration System and the Biological Warning and Incident Characterization System (BWICS), which are still in the planning or development stage. The BWICS initiative is associated with three other biosurveillance programs, including BioWatch, which is operational but has interoperability and other limitations.

• Despite federal, state, and local government efforts to strengthen the public health infrastructure and improve the nation's ability to detect, prevent, and respond to public health emergencies, important challenges continue to constrain progress, including the need to integrate public health IT initiatives into the national health care IT strategy and federal health architecture, and to address specific weaknesses in IT planning and management.

<summary>
* The survey of large sponsors of defined benefit (DB) pension plans found that many have made changes to their benefit offerings over the past 10 years, including revising benefit formulas, converting to hybrid plans, and freezing plans. The changes were more common among non-bargaining employees, with 81% of respondents modifying their DB plan formulas and 52% converting to hybrid plans. The main reasons for these changes were unpredictability of funding requirements and global competitive pressures.
* The survey also found that many sponsors are not optimistic about the future of the DB system, with most stating that they would not consider forming a new DB plan. The respondents cited reasons such as increased regulatory requirements and reduced PBGC premiums as unlikely to induce them to form a new DB plan. The survey's findings suggest that the DB system is facing significant challenges and may need alternative models for retirement security.

<summary>
* The refugee resettlement process in the United States involves multiple federal agencies, voluntary agencies, and local stakeholders, with the goal of helping refugees become self-sufficient and integrated into their new communities.
* However, the process faces challenges, including inadequate communication and consultation between stakeholders, limited resources, and a focus on short-term employment outcomes that may not prioritize longer-term integration.
* Despite these challenges, some communities have developed successful strategies for resettling refugees, including formal processes for communication and consultation, and targeted services to support refugees' long-term integration and self-sufficiency.

<summary>
* The National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) was established in 1968 to provide flood insurance to homeowners and businesses, with the goal of reducing federal costs for disaster relief.
* The program is managed by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and has been modified by several pieces of legislation, including the Flood Disaster Protection Act of 1973 and the National Flood Insurance Reform Act of 1994.
* NFIP has mapped flood risks across the country and assigns flood zone designations based on risk levels, which determine premium rates.
* The program offers two types of premiums: subsidized and full-risk, with subsidized rates applying to about 22% of all NFIP policies.
* Despite efforts to mitigate flood damage, the number of repetitive loss properties has continued to grow, and the program's financial stability is threatened by catastrophic losses.
* To address these challenges, four public policy goals have been identified: charging premium rates that reflect actual risks, limiting costs to taxpayers, encouraging broad participation, and promoting private market participation.
* Increasing premium rates to reflect actual risks could reduce costs to taxpayers, but may lead to higher costs for some homeowners and potentially reduce participation.
* Mitigation efforts, such as elevation, relocation, and demolition, can reduce flood damage and costs, but may impose upfront costs on homeowners and communities.
* Congressional action is needed to address NFIP's financial challenges and operational issues, including improving strategic planning, human capital planning, and information technology.

<summary>
* The 287(g) program allows state and local law enforcement agencies to perform immigration enforcement functions, but lacks management controls, which hinders its effectiveness. The program's objective is to enhance community safety by addressing serious criminal activity by removable aliens. However, the program's rapid growth has presented resource challenges, and ICE has not documented its objectives or established clear guidance for participating agencies. As a result, participating agencies may use their 287(g) authority in a manner not intended by ICE.

* ICE has not defined the responsibilities required of ICE agents directing and supervising local officers under the 287(g) program, leading to varying perceptions of supervisory activities among ICE officials and participating agencies. The lack of defined supervision activities hampers ICE's ability to ensure management directives are carried out appropriately. ICE officials have stated that they are in the process of developing performance measures, but have not provided documentation or a timeline for completion. Without performance measures, ICE lacks a basis for determining whether the program is achieving its intended results.

* The 287(g) program has grown rapidly, with 67 state and local law enforcement agencies enrolled and 951 state and local officers trained and certified as of October 2008. However, ICE has not consistently communicated to participating agencies how and under what circumstances 287(g) authority is to be used. Participating agencies may use their authority in a manner not intended by ICE, which could further burden limited detention resources. ICE has not established a plan for developing performance measures, including a timeline for completion.

* ICE has not specified the program information or data that each agency is expected to collect regarding their implementation of the 287(g) program, or how this information is to be reported. Without clear guidance, participating agencies may not collect the necessary data, which would hinder ICE's ability to ensure the program is achieving its objectives. ICE has not established a plan for developing performance measures, including a timeline for completion. The lack of data collection and reporting guidance limits ICE's ability to evaluate the program's effectiveness.

* ICE has not documented the objective of the 287(g) program for participants, which could lead to participating agencies using their authority in a manner not intended by ICE. The program's objective is to enhance community safety by addressing serious criminal activity by removable aliens. ICE has not established clear guidance for participating agencies on how and under what circumstances 287(g) authority is to be used. Without clear guidance, participating agencies may use their authority in a manner that is not intended by ICE.

<summary>
* The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) oversees mutual funds through its Office of Compliance Inspections and Examinations (OCIE), Division of Investment Management, and Division of Enforcement. OCIE examines mutual funds to evaluate their compliance with federal securities laws and assess the effectiveness of their compliance control systems. The Division of Investment Management administers the securities laws affecting funds and advisers.

* SEC regulates mutual funds under the Investment Company Act of 1940, the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, the Securities Act of 1933, and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The Investment Company Act requires mutual funds to register with SEC and imposes requirements on their operation and structure. The act's core objectives are to ensure investors receive adequate information, protect fund assets, and prevent abusive practices.

* SEC's traditional examination approach focused on conducting routine examinations of all funds on a regular schedule, but this approach has limitations in detecting emerging compliance problems. SEC has reallocated staff to conduct targeted examinations focusing on specific risks and monitoring larger funds on a continuous basis. This revised approach offers the potential for SEC to more quickly identify emerging risks and better understand the operations of large and complex funds.

* SEC has established teams of examiners dedicated to regularly interacting with and monitoring the activities of the largest and most complex groups of affiliated advisers and mutual funds. This approach may enable SEC to more efficiently use its resources and ensure the independence and effectiveness of the monitored firms' compliance staff. The largest advisory groups account for about 85% of fund assets under management.

* SEC's Office of Risk Assessment (ORA) will analyze risk across divisional boundaries, focusing on new or resurgent forms of fraudulent, illegal, or questionable behavior or products. ORA will work with other SEC offices to identify new technologies, such as data mining systems, to help detect and track risks. ORA may help SEC be more proactive and better identify emerging risks.

* SEC's fund and adviser surveillance system is in the exploratory stage, but if properly designed and implemented, it may help the agency leverage its limited resources to augment its examinations and oversee funds and advisers. Federal bank and other regulators use off-site surveillance programs to monitor the financial condition of banks between examinations.

* SEC's revised examination priorities involve significant tradeoffs that raise important regulatory challenges, including the capacity to review the operations of firms considered lower risk and conduct risk assessments of the industry. SEC may not examine all mutual funds within a reasonable period, and its ability to assign risk ratings to all fund complexes may be limited.

<summary>
• TVA is an independent federal corporation established by the TVA Act to improve the quality of life in the Tennessee River Valley by improving navigation, promoting regional agricultural and economic development, and controlling floodwaters.
• TVA's board sets goals and policies, appoints the CEO, develops long-range plans, and approves the budget and rate changes.
• TVA's most recent strategic plan outlines its "strategic imperatives" to maintain low rates, live within its means, manage its assets, and be responsible stewards of the region's natural resources.
• TVA aims to reduce its debt from $26 billion in fiscal year 2016 to $22 billion by fiscal year 2023 through rate increases, limiting operating expenses, and reducing capital expenditures.
• TVA's plans assume the completion of capital projects will occur on time and within budget, but cost overruns or delays could require adjustments to its future financial plans.
• TVA's debt reduction plans and performance information are not reported in a manner consistent with GPRAMA requirements, which could reduce transparency and raise questions about how the agency will meet its goal.
• Several factors could affect TVA's ability to meet its debt reduction goal, including regulatory pressures, changes in demand for electricity, technological innovations, or unforeseen events.
• TVA's unfunded pension liabilities have steadily increased over the past 10 years, and the agency aims to eliminate the $6 billion funding shortfall within 20 years, but no mechanism is in place to ensure full funding.
• TVA's open amortization period for its pension plan does not ensure that contributions will adequately adjust for plan experience and does not ensure full funding of pension liabilities, which could result in future rate increases or reduced financial flexibility.

<summary>
* The First City Bancorporation of Texas, Inc. had a high concentration of loans to the energy industry in the Southwest United States and was regarded as a principal lender in that industry. In the early and mid-1980s, when the energy industry experienced financial difficulties, First City also faced financial difficulties. By 1986, First City was reporting operating losses.

* In 1988, the FDIC provided $970 million in open bank assistance to First City, which included a capital infusion and the creation of a "collecting bank" to dispose of troubled assets. The agreement also required First City to reduce its subsidiary banks from nearly 60 to about 20. First City was required to raise $500 million in private capital to restore its financial health.

* Despite the recapitalization, First City's loan portfolios continued to deteriorate, and the bank's operating expenses were high. The bank's management pursued aggressive growth policies, including high-risk lending activities, which further eroded its capital. By September 1990, problems with the quality of its loan portfolios caused operating losses and began to erode First City's capital.

* In 1991 and 1992, First City, OCC, and FDIC considered various resolution plans, including a Type A transaction, which involved the acquisition of First City banks by a stronger institution, and a Type C transaction, which involved a self-rescue by the banking organization. However, none of these plans were successful, and First City's financial condition continued to deteriorate.

* On October 30, 1992, OCC declared First City-Houston insolvent, and FDIC exercised its statutory authority to issue cross-guarantee demands on the remaining 18 First City banks, resulting in the closure of the entire First City banking organization. FDIC placed the failed banks into interim bridge banks, which were later sold to new acquirers, resulting in a surplus of over $200 million.

* The resolution of First City offers valuable lessons for FDIC and other regulatory agencies, including the importance of realistic economic assumptions, adequate safeguards, and thorough documentation of closure decisions. The events surrounding the First City resolutions highlight the need for regulatory agencies to work together to ensure the safety and soundness of the banking system.

<summary>
• The Single Audit Act of 1984 was passed to improve oversight and accountability of federal funds provided to state and local governments, but a recent study by the President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency (PCIE) found that many single audits continue to have significant quality issues. The study found that 51% of single audits had deficiencies that were severe enough to cause the audits to be classified as having limited reliability or being unacceptable. The most prevalent deficiencies related to auditors' lack of documentation and testing of internal control over compliance requirements.
• The PCIE report recommended a three-pronged approach to improve single audit quality, including revising and improving single audit standards, establishing minimum continuing professional education requirements for auditors, and enhancing disciplinary processes to address unacceptable audits. The report also emphasized the need for more effective oversight and accountability mechanisms, particularly for audits of entities expending $50 million or more in federal awards. Improving single audit quality is essential to ensure accountability and transparency in the use of federal funds.

<summary>
• Medicare is a federal health insurance program that provides coverage to elderly and disabled beneficiaries, with two main parts: hospital insurance (Part A) and supplemental medical insurance (Part B). Claims are processed by a network of 49 claims administration contractors called intermediaries and carriers. These contractors review and pay claims, maintain program safeguards, and educate providers and beneficiaries.

• The Medicare contracting process differs from that of most federal programs, with no full and open competition for contracts and a limited pool of qualified entities. The Social Security Act allows Medicare to deviate from the Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) and instead uses cost-based reimbursement contracts with no provision for profit. Contractors cannot be terminated without a public hearing, which is not the case under the FAR.

• Medicare could benefit from contracting reforms, such as allowing direct competition for contracts and expanding the pool of qualified entities. This could lead to efficiency and performance improvements, as well as addressing concerns about the dwindling number of insurers willing to contract with Medicare. Allowing contractors to specialize in specific functions could also lead to greater efficiency and better performance.

• The program has historically used health insurers to process and pay claims, but this may no longer be the most effective approach. The number of health insurers willing to contract with Medicare has declined, and the agency is limited in its ability to contract with other entities. Expanding the pool of qualified entities could help address these issues.

• The agency has proposed legislative changes to allow for more flexibility in contracting, including the ability to competitively award contracts to the best-qualified entities. This could allow for more efficient and effective management of the program. The Secretary of Health and Human Services has expressed support for these changes.

• Functional contracting, where separate contractors are used for specific claims administration activities, could also improve program management. This could allow for specialization and economies of scale, leading to better performance and service. However, this approach also has its own challenges, such as coordinating the activities of multiple contractors.

• Offering financial incentives to contractors for high-quality performance could also have benefits. Currently, contractors are paid based on costs, but allowing for performance-based contracts could lead to improved program operations and lower administrative costs. However, implementing such contracts would require significant changes to the current system.

• Terminating contractors more efficiently could also promote better program management. Currently, contractors can terminate their contracts without cause, while the agency must demonstrate a reason for termination and provide a public hearing. Allowing for more flexibility in terminating contracts could help address challenges in finding replacement contractors.

<summary>
• The Defense Science Board (DSB) estimated that the Department of Defense (DOD) could save $6 billion annually by outsourcing logistics support activities, but the estimate is overstated and lacks supporting data. The DSB's report was based on two studies that recommended outsourcing and privatization, but the estimates were not well-supported and were overly optimistic. The report also assumed that DOD would overcome legal and cultural barriers to outsourcing, which is unlikely. The DSB's estimate was based on a 25% savings rate from outsourcing, which is not supported by evidence.

• The DSB's report recommended that DOD outsource all logistics activities, including material management and depot maintenance, but this is limited by laws and regulations. For example, the 1998 DOD Authorization Act requires that DOD identify its core depot maintenance requirements, which has not been completed. Additionally, the act limits the amount of depot maintenance that can be outsourced to non-federal personnel. The DSB's report also assumed that the requirement for public-private competition would be eliminated, which is unlikely.

• The DSB's estimate of $1.5 billion in annual savings from equipment reliability improvements is overstated by at least $1.2 billion. The estimate was based on a Logistics Management Institute study that assumed an aggressive technology improvement program, but the study's assumptions were not realistic. The DSB's estimate also assumed that DOD would achieve the savings within 6 years, which is unlikely. The study's findings were also based on a limited analysis of the data.

• The DSB's report recognized that there are cultural and legal barriers to outsourcing, but the report did not adequately address these barriers. The report assumed that DOD would overcome these barriers, but this is unlikely. The report also did not provide a detailed plan for implementing the recommended changes. The DSB's report was based on a limited analysis of the data and did not consider alternative solutions.

• The Program Analysis and Evaluation (PA&E) analysis of the DSB's report found that the estimate of $6 billion in annual savings was overstated by about $1 billion. PA&E also found that another $3 billion in projected savings would be difficult to achieve or unlikely to be achieved. The PA&E analysis concluded that the remaining $2 billion of the DSB's estimate was achievable or already identified in DOD's future year defense program.

<summary>
• The Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) reduced its workforce by 1,894 FTEs between fiscal years 1993 and 1996, with the Office of Housing accounting for the largest percentage of downsizing. The Office of Housing took actions to maintain performance during downsizing, including refocusing its mission, reengineering its work processes, and building and maintaining employee skills. These actions allowed the Office of Housing to maintain, and in some cases, improve performance.

• The Office of Housing consolidated routine, location-neutral activities into fewer offices, such as consolidating single-family housing activities into the Denver Homeownership Center, which reduced processing times. The Office of Housing also implemented paperless processing of mortgage record changes, default reporting, and other record changes. These consolidations and process changes helped maintain performance during downsizing.

• The Office of Housing officials believed that employees had the skills and experience necessary to maintain performance, but union officials were less optimistic, citing staffing shortages and mismatches between skills and needs. The Office of Housing reported that it was developing performance measures in compliance with the Government Performance and Results Act. Trend data showed that the Office of Housing generally met or exceeded its performance goals during downsizing.

• The Department of the Interior (DOI) reduced its workforce by almost 10,200 FTEs between fiscal years 1993 and 1996, with the Bureau of Reclamation (BOR) accounting for a significant percentage of downsizing. BOR took actions to maintain performance during downsizing, including refocusing its mission, reengineering its work processes, and building and maintaining employee skills. These actions allowed BOR to maintain performance, although some employees expressed concerns about the future.

• BOR shifted its mission emphasis from water project construction to water resources management, including water conservation, environmental restoration, and solutions to the water problems of Native Americans and urban water suppliers. BOR reengineered its Denver facilities into the Reclamation Service Center, which provides administrative, research, scientific, and technical services to BOR and other clients. BOR also consolidated its 35 project offices into 26 area offices.

• BOR officials believed that employees had the skills and experience necessary to maintain performance, although they also believed that additional younger people needed to be hired. BOR was rotating people among functions and retraining them to develop a cadre of people to be future supervisors and managers. Employees expressed concerns about the future, including the loss of expertise and the need for more young people to be hired.

<summary>
• The IRS designed the National Research Program (NRP) to obtain accurate information about taxpayer compliance with tax laws, with a focus on voluntary filing, reporting, and payment compliance.
• The NRP process involves casebuilding, classification, and audits, with the goal of identifying areas of noncompliance and improving audit selection formulas to reduce burden on compliant taxpayers.
• IRS has made significant progress in implementing NRP, including training classifiers and auditors, building case files, and conducting audits, with a focus on quality assurance and minimizing taxpayer burden.
• The program has undergone changes and refinements based on testing and feedback, including modifications to classification guidelines and the addition of quality review teams to ensure audit accuracy.
• IRS plans to use NRP results to improve future iterations of the program, reduce taxpayer burden, and better target enforcement audits to noncompliant taxpayers.

<summary>
* The Bureau's planning for the 2010 Census has improved compared to its efforts for the 2000 Census, but certain information gaps remain. The Bureau's three-legged stool strategy is generally aligned with three of its four key goals for the 2010 Census, but it is unclear how the Bureau will achieve its goal of reducing operational risk using its current plan.

* The Bureau faces at least three key challenges, including securing congressional approval for its proposed approach, addressing methodological and other questions related to the American Community Survey (ACS), and ensuring that its design assumptions are realistic. The Bureau's efforts to ensure that ACS data will serve as a satisfactory replacement for long-form data are not yet complete.

* The Bureau's design assumes that by 2008, ACS will be in place nationwide and producing data, a GPS-aligned and modernized MAF/TIGER will be available, and all reengineering efforts will be complete to allow for a true dress rehearsal. Completing any one of these tasks would be a considerable undertaking, and the Bureau has no contingency plans other than to revert to a "traditional" census.

* The Bureau is not currently planning to develop a procedure that would allow it to adjust census numbers for purposes of redistricting, citing the insufficiency of the science to allow making statistical adjustments to population counts. The Bureau believes that it cannot both collect coverage measurement data and complete the analysis of those data's accuracy in time to deliver the information to the states to meet their redistricting deadlines.

* The estimated cost of the 2010 Census is $11.3 billion in current dollars, making it the most expensive in the nation's history, even after adjusting for inflation. The Bureau's cost projections for the 2010 decennial census continue an escalating trend, with the average cost per housing unit for 2010 expected to increase by approximately 29 percent from 2000 levels.

* The Bureau's ability to maintain the level of quality reported for the 2000 Census is far from guaranteed, and it will be important for the Bureau to research procedures that would allow adjustment, if necessary, for those purposes for which it is both legal and appropriate to do so. The Bureau should conduct this effort on a timetable that allows it to adequately test and refine those procedures.

* Greater fiscal transparency is critical to better reflect the magnitude of the government's long-term spending on the census and signal unanticipated cost growth, and the Bureau could benefit from providing more robust information on the likelihood that the values it assigned to

<summary>
• The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has established a framework to ensure the privacy and security of Medicare beneficiaries' protected health information (PHI) when used for purposes other than direct clinical care. This framework includes regulations, guidance, and enforcement activities to protect PHI.

• The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) and the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act require HHS to establish standards for the privacy and security of PHI. The HIPAA Privacy Rule and Security Rule set forth requirements for covered entities and business associates to protect PHI.

• The Office for Civil Rights (OCR) is responsible for enforcing HIPAA's privacy and security requirements, and has developed guidance and outreach efforts to assist covered entities and business associates in complying with the rules. OCR also investigates complaints and conducts audits to ensure compliance.

• OCR has established a process for conducting investigations in response to complaints and breach notifications, and has developed audit procedures to assess compliance with HIPAA requirements. The office has also developed a pilot audit program to assess the effectiveness of its audit process.

• The HITECH Act requires OCR to issue guidance on de-identifying PHI, but the office has not yet issued this guidance. OCR officials stated that the guidance will explain and answer questions about de-identification methods and clarify guidelines for conducting the expert determination method.

• OCR has not fully established a capability to proactively monitor covered entities' compliance through periodic audits, as required by the HITECH Act. The office has not determined how to include auditing business associates in its audit program.

• The HHS Assistant Secretary for Legislation agreed with the report's recommendations, but provided qualifying comments. The Assistant Secretary noted that covered entities have been operating under the existing de-identification standards for almost 10 years and that OCR has not found significant compliance issues.

• The report recommends that the Secretary of HHS direct the Director of OCR to issue guidance on properly implementing the HIPAA Privacy Rule requirements for de-identification of PHI and establish plans for conducting periodic audits to ensure covered entities and business associates are complying with HIPAA rules.

<summary>
• The main mission of the Military Health Service System (MHSS) is medical readiness, which requires providing medical support to active-duty military personnel and maintaining the health of the active-duty force during peacetime. The MHSS also supports non-active-duty beneficiaries, such as dependents and retirees, when resources are available. The role of psychiatrists and clinical psychologists in meeting the MHSS medical readiness mission is to provide mental health care that helps military personnel perform their duties.

• The Psychopharmacology Demonstration Project (PDP) was established to increase the scope of practice of clinical psychologists in the military by training them to prescribe psychotropic medication. The project was created in response to a 1988 conference report that recommended establishing a demonstration pilot training program for military psychologists to issue psychotropic medications under certain circumstances. The Army's Office of the Surgeon General designed and implemented the PDP.

• The PDP training program consisted of 2 years of classroom training and 1 year of clinical experience, followed by 1 year of proctored practice. The program was designed to provide clinical psychologists with the knowledge and skills necessary to prescribe a limited formulary of psychotropic medications. The program faced several problems, including a lack of clearly defined purpose, difficulty recruiting participants, and delays in granting prescribing privileges.

• The MHSS has no current or upcoming need for clinical psychologists who can prescribe medication, as it has more psychiatrists than needed to meet medical readiness requirements. The cost of producing 10 prescribing psychologists was substantial, and spending resources to produce more providers than needed is hard to justify. The PDP has demonstrated that training psychologists to prescribe drugs can reduce psychiatrists' workloads in some cases.

• The PDP has increased the number of MHSS mental health care providers who can prescribe drugs, which may reduce psychiatrists' workloads. However, the cost-effectiveness of having MHSS psychologists prescribe psychotropic medication is unclear. Determining the cost-effectiveness of this effort would require information on the proportion of time prescribing psychologists would spend performing functions that psychiatrists would normally perform.

• The PDP has faced several implementation problems, including a lack of clearly defined purpose, difficulty recruiting participants, and delays in granting prescribing privileges. The project has also faced concerns about the quality of care provided by prescribing psychologists and the level of supervision they require. The MHSS has not decided who should supervise prescribing psychologists or how they should be used in the MHSS.
