* The Iranian Ministry of Health and Medical Education introduced clinical governance (CG) in 2009 as a framework for improving quality and safety in hospitals, with seven interlocking components. The CG model consists of clinical effectiveness, clinical audit, risk management, patient and public involvement, education and training, staff and staff management, and use of information.

* Senior managers in Iranian medical universities were interviewed to explore their views on facilitators and barriers in CG implementation, and the findings demonstrated a willingness to support and positive attitude towards CG. They believed that quality improvement is a strategic goal to achieve central government targets.

* The level of enthusiasm expressed by senior managers was related to their knowledge and attitude about CG concept and components, and continuous training about CG can make a positive attitude towards the program. Those managers who had gained knowledge were more optimistic towards the success of the program.

* A culture focusing on continuous improvement, teamwork, and readiness towards change were identified as main factors influencing CG implementation, and a culture of openness in which staff are willing to bring ideas related to service quality development was also highlighted. CG components needed to be embedded in day-to-day work.

* Adequate organizational commitment towards CG, effective organizational interactions, and allocating adequate staff to undertake responsibilities were recognized as organizational factors affecting CG implementation. The necessity for development and dissemination of national standards was also emphasized.

* Managerial commitment towards CG and their executive ability in implementing the program were identified as key factors, and senior managers should demonstrate executive capabilities to motivate departments to implement CG principles. They should also provide adequate resources, facilitate staff training, and remove obstacles.

* Shortage of staff and limited dedicated resources, lack of support from physicians and medical staff, and legal challenges were identified as barriers to CG implementation. Fostering a sense of engagement among medical staff, especially physicians, was also emphasized.

* To mitigate problems, senior managers suggested creating a suitable culture for implementing quality programs, evaluating the quality of the organization, determining existing deficiencies, and setting up appropriate strategic and functional plans. They also recommended encouraging quality improvement activities continuously.

* The study's findings support the importance of supporting culture, appropriate organizational structure, and managerial commitment in CG implementation, and highlight the need for further research to track the progress of the CG policy over time.

<summary>

* Hydatid cyst disease is a zoonotic disease caused by the larval stage of the Echinococcus granulosus parasite, which infects canines as the final host and herbivores and humans as intermediate hosts. The disease is common in many parts of the world, especially in countries where animal husbandry is prevalent. The incidence rate of the disease can be as high as 50 per 100,000 person-years with a prevalence rate of 5-10% in humans.

* Iran is considered a hyper-endemic area for hydatidosis due to its close relationship with animals, traditional animal husbandry, and contact with sources of infection. The prevalence rate of the disease in intermediate hosts has been reported to be 11.5-34.6%, and in humans, it ranges from 1.1% to 13.7% in different parts of Iran. The disease is a significant public health problem with a high health and economic burden.

* This study aimed to determine the epidemiological and clinical status of human hydatidosis in Khorasan Razavi province, Iran, during 2011-2014. The study population consisted of all cases with hydatid cysts diagnosed in governmental and private laboratories, hospitals, and health centers in the province. Data collection was performed using a checklist including demographic characteristics, infected organ, diagnosis method, clinical symptoms, and risk factors.

* The study found that 357 hydatid cyst cases were registered in health centers during the study period, with the highest percentage of cases in the cities of Mashhad, Ghoochan, Neishabour, and Fariman. The mean age of women was higher than that of men, and the majority of patients were infected with a single cyst. The most common symptom was abdominal pain, followed by hepatomegaly, chest pain, and cough.

* The study found that liver involvement was reported in 59.4% of patients, and 8.4% had multiple organ involvement. The most common diagnosis methods were radiology and CT scan. The majority of patients (70.5%) were infected with a single cyst, and 24.5% had multiple cysts.

* The study found that 45.9% of patients had domestic dogs, and 64.4% washed vegetables with water alone, while 6.7% followed hygiene principles of washing. The findings suggest that education level and awareness about the disease and its risk factors need to be improved.

<summary>
* Friederich is credited with describing the first case of a ciliated hepatic foregut cyst (CHFC) in 1857 and positing their congenital origin. Wheeler and Edmonson were the first to use the term CHFC to describe the lesion and identified specific characteristics that differentiate it from other hepatic cysts.

* CHFCs are rare, with only 103 cases reported since 1857, and are thought to be the result of evagination of the foregut during embryonogenesis. The majority of cases have been reported in the last 25 years, with improved imaging techniques.

* The cyst size ranges from <1 cm to 24 cm in greatest diameter, with a mean greatest dimension of 4 cm and a median of 3 cm. The average age of presentation is 52 years, ranging from 3 months to 82 years, with a slight female predominance.

* CHFCs are most frequently located superficially in the median segments of the liver, are rarely multi-loculated or septated, and are mostly asymptomatic. They are typically solitary and unilocular, with four layers: an outer fibrous rim, a layer of smooth muscle, subepithelial connective tissue, and a lining of ciliated, pseudo-stratified, mucin-secreting columnar epithelium.

* The imaging appearances of CHFCs are variable, appearing as anechoic or hypoechoic cysts with spotty hyperechoic areas on ultrasound, and as non-enhancing, rounded lesions of varying density on CT. Typical MRI features are a hyperintense cyst on T2-weighted images and a variable appearance on T1-weighted images.

* The main differential diagnosis is bronchogenic cyst, as both cystic lesions share a common embryonic origin. Simple cysts are usually located in the right hepatic lobe and are more prevalent in women.

* Laparoscopic excision is a recommended treatment for CHFCs, especially for cysts larger than 4-5 cm, symptomatic or enlarging lesions, and asymptomatic lesions with wall abnormalities on imaging or in patients with otherwise unexplained abnormal liver function tests. The laparoscopic approach is best suited to lesions in segments II to VI, where visualization and access are easiest.

<summary>
• The oral route is a preferred route of drug administration due to its safety, ease of administration, and acceptability by patients, but conventional tablets have drawbacks such as difficulty in swallowing and low bioavailability.
• Fast dissolving tablets have been developed to overcome these issues, but they have their own limitations, including physical solid form, psychological fear of swallowing, and expensive packaging costs.
• Orally dissolving strips (ODS) are a newer and more advanced form of oral solid dosage form that offer improved flexibility and comfort, and can dissolve within a minute in the oral cavity without water or chewing.
• Clobazam, a 1,5-benzodiazepine derivative, is an ideal drug candidate for ODS formulation due to its indication in children and low-dose requirement.
• A 3-factorial design was used to optimize the ODS formulation of clobazam using polyvinyl acetate (PVA) as film forming agent and sodium starch glycolate (SSG) as disintegrant.
• The optimized formulation (F6) showed the highest dissolution rate, suitable in vitro disintegration time, and satisfactory tensile strength, and was selected for further studies.
• In vivo studies in rabbits showed that the optimized ODS formulation was comparable to the marketed tablet formulation (Frisium 5) in terms of drug plasma level-time profiles.
• The prepared ODS formulation was stable for at least 6 months under accelerated stability conditions, making it a promising alternative to fast dissolving tablet formulation for the treatment of epileptic attacks.

<summary>
* This review examined the methodological quality of studies determining the psychometric properties of outcome measures used in stroke self-management interventions according to the COSMIN checklist. The review found that many measures used in stroke self-management interventions lack robust psychometric properties, and there is a need for further development and validation of measures that capture the concept of stroke self-management. The review highlights the importance of involving users in the development of measures to ensure content validity and clinical utility. The COSMIN checklist is a valuable tool for evaluating the methodological quality of studies, but its stringent criteria may lead to a floor effect.

* The review found that physical function was the most commonly used outcome measure in stroke self-management interventions, but this may not capture the full range of concepts relevant to stroke self-management. There is a need to further conceptualize stroke self-management and develop measures that capture the experiences and priorities of people recovering from stroke. The review highlights the importance of considering the theoretical premises underlying stroke self-management interventions and selecting outcome measures that align with these premises. The development of measures that capture the patient's experience of stroke self-management is crucial.

* The review recommends that researchers and clinicians clarify the theoretical premises of stroke self-management interventions and select outcome measures that accurately reflect the expected outcomes. The selection of outcome measures developed with involvement from the target population is advocated to ensure that what is meaningful to the patient is captured. Further work is needed to examine the concept and theoretical premises of stroke self-management and develop appropriate measures. The review highlights the need for a more nuanced understanding of stroke self-management and the development of measures that capture its complexities.

<summary>
* Osteoarthritis (OA) in the knee joint is a leading cause of functional disability and lowered quality of life in older adults in India, and factors such as age, height, weight, and BMI can influence disease severity. The primary objective of this study was to investigate the correlation between the KOOS questionnaire and the 6-minute walk test (6-MWT) in patients with knee OA.

* The study included 251 patients with clinical and non-radiographic idiopathic or primary knee OA, and data was collected using the KOOS questionnaire and 6-MWT, as well as measurements of height, weight, and BMI. The results showed that the KOOS questionnaire had a strong correlation with the 6-MWT, particularly in the symptom, pain, and quality of life subscales.

* The study found that BMI had a strong correlation with the KOOS subscales, particularly pain, symptom, and quality of life, while weight had a weak correlation with the symptom, ADL, and sports subscales. Age had no correlation with any of the KOOS subscales except for a weak correlation with the quality of life subscale.

* The results of this study are consistent with previous studies that have reported a correlation between self-reported questionnaires and performance-based tests in patients with knee OA. The study suggests that both self-reported and performance-based tests should be used in knee rehabilitation settings to obtain more valid results.

* The study's findings support the use of the KOOS questionnaire in Indian patients with knee OA, and the results are in agreement with previous studies that have reported a correlation between self-reported questionnaires and performance-based tests. The study's results also highlight the importance of considering BMI and weight in the management of knee OA.

* The study's limitations include the cross-sectional design and the lack of a control group, and future studies should investigate the correlation between self-reported questionnaires and performance-based tests in a larger and more diverse population.

<summary>
• Obesity is a chronic inflammatory disease with a multifactorial etiology, including eating habits, sedentary lifestyle, and genetic predisposition, leading to excessive accumulation of body fat. Adipose tissue secretes pro-inflammatory factors like IL-6, TNF-, and leptin, and anti-inflammatory factors like IL-10 and adiponectin. A high-fat diet promotes metabolic changes, inducing the production of pro-inflammatory interleukins and chronic inflammation. The presence of large concentrations of endotoxins and saturated fatty acids in the diet activates toll-like receptor 4, triggering the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines.

• Menopause is defined as the permanent cessation of menstruation due to loss of ovarian function, leading to adverse changes in lipoprotein profile, glucose and insulin metabolism, body fat distribution, clotting, and vascular endothelium. Estrogens have anti-inflammatory properties, but controversy persists regarding their effects on inflammation. Estrogen exerts an anti-inflammatory effect on the vasculature, and its hormonal changes during menopause have a negative impact on women's health. Therefore, it is essential to investigate the effects of estrogen on the inflammatory state.

• The study evaluated the effects of a high-fat diet with or without ovariectomy on the inflammatory process in rats by assessing the production of pro- and anti-inflammatory factors and their receptors. The results showed that ovariectomy combined with a hyperlipidic diet caused an increase in body weight gain, food efficiency, and carcass lipid content. The cytokine content of the liver and gastrocnemius muscle was unchanged, but levels of all cytokines analyzed were decreased in mesenteric adipose tissue. The study demonstrated that the time period after ovariectomy may influence body weight gain and food efficiency.

• The study found that ovariectomy combined with a hyperlipidic diet promoted hyperleptinemia, which may arise as a result of the increased body weight of rats in the ovx h group. Leptin levels rise with increasing adiposity and are directly proportional to fat mass. The decrease in estrogen could potentiate the effect of a high-fat diet on leptin secretion. Hyperleptinemia may contribute to the development of resistance to leptin, a common occurrence in obese individuals.

• The study's results emphasize that, after menopause, women must decrease their consumption of fat to prevent the induction of pro-inflammatory processes associated with a high-fat diet. The presence of female hormones could modify the response to a high-fat diet

<summary>
• Hemoptysis is a significant clinical entity with high morbidity and potential mortality, and bronchial artery embolization (BAE) is a safe and effective treatment option. In this study, 344 patients underwent BAE, with an immediate control of bleeding achieved in 330 patients (96%). The procedure was successful in controlling hemoptysis immediately in most patients, with a low rate of complications. The technique can be used repeatedly, making it a valuable option for patients who are poor surgical candidates.

• The study found that the main responsible vessels for bleeding were right bronchial arteries, left bronchial arteries, combined right and left bronchial trunk, and right intercostal arteries. The distribution and frequency of embolization of the arteries were consistent with previous studies. A spinal artery was identified in three patients, with two occurring on the right side and one on the left side. The etiologies of hemoptysis included tuberculosis, bronchiectasis, malignancy, and other pulmonary diseases.

• The study showed that BAE is an effective procedure for controlling hemoptysis, with a high success rate and low rate of complications. The procedure can be performed repeatedly, making it a valuable option for patients who experience recurrent hemoptysis. The technique is relatively safe, with few patients experiencing neurologic sequelae. The most common complications were fever, chest pain, and shoulder pain, which were transient and resolved within 48 hours.

• The follow-up of patients revealed that 28 patients had died, with six deaths due to massive hemorrhage and the remainder due to their underlying disease. Twenty-one patients experienced recurrent hemoptysis after repeated BAE, but the volume of bleeding was less than 5 ml/d and was controlled with medication. One patient suffered recurrent hemoptysis and wanted to undergo surgical management, but the diffuse disease in the lung limited the management. There was no follow-up information available on 92 patients.

• The study concluded that BAE is a valuable treatment option for hemoptysis, with a high success rate and low rate of complications. The technique is relatively safe and can be used repeatedly, making it a valuable option for patients who are poor surgical candidates. The study's results were consistent with previous studies, and the technique is a useful option for obtaining immediate bleeding control. BAE may be the only life-saving treatment option in patients who are poor surgical candidates.

<summary>
• The study investigated the relationship between Helicobacter pylori (HP) infection and celiac disease (CD) in pediatric patients with lymphocytic gastritis (LG), and found that the highest prevalence of LG was in pediatric CD patients with HP infection, followed by CD patients without HP infection. The study also found that HP infection did not contribute to the number of CD8+ intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs) in CD patients.

• The study characterized the immunophenotype of the gastric mucosa in CD and HP-infected children, and found that CD8+ IELs were significantly higher in CD patients compared to controls or HP-infected patients without CD. The study suggests that the number of CD8+ IELs in the antrum may be a useful diagnostic tool to differentiate between CD and HP infection in pediatric patients with LG.

<summary>
• Angiogenesis, the process of forming new blood vessels, is essential for tumor growth, and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is a primary stimulant of angiogenesis. Inhibition of VEGF has been shown to reduce tumor size and microvessel density, and is a promising therapeutic target for cancer treatment.

• Anti-VEGF therapy has been shown to not only inhibit angiogenesis but also modulate immune cell infiltration, including reducing macrophage infiltration, and has been approved for the treatment of metastatic breast cancer. Combination therapy with chemotherapy and angioinhibitors is being explored, and preventive angioinhibitory therapy may be possible in the future.

<summary>
• The Revive survey highlights the lack of awareness and understanding of vulvar and vaginal atrophy (VVA) among postmenopausal women, with many not discussing their symptoms with healthcare providers (HCPs) and assuming that their symptoms are a natural part of aging. The survey also shows that HCPs often fail to initiate conversations about VVA, leading to delayed diagnosis and treatment.

• The survey emphasizes the need for increased vigilance by HCPs, including nurse practitioners, to proactively identify women suffering from VVA, provide essential patient education, and guide them to appropriate treatment options, including prescription therapies that can effectively treat the underlying physiological changes of VVA. By doing so, HCPs can improve patient adherence and outcomes.

<summary>
* The study examined the prevalence of folic acid (FA) and multivitamin (MV) supplement use among 5383 Danish pregnancy planners. The participants were recruited through an internet-based prospective cohort study called Snart-Gravid (Soon Pregnant) between 2007 and 2011.

* The study found that 62.1% of the participants used FA or MV supplements, with 7.7% using FA exclusively, 20.4% using MV exclusively, and 34.0% using both. The prevalence of FA or MV use was higher than in previous studies, which may be due to the prospective design and the fact that the study population was more health-conscious.

* Higher age was associated with increased prevalence of FA or MV use, and women who finished high school were more likely to use FA or MV supplements compared to those with less schooling. Women with a long vocational training (>4 years) were also more likely to use FA or MV supplements.

* Women who had a previous spontaneous abortion were more likely to use FA or MV supplements, and intercourse frequency ≥1 time/week was associated with an increased prevalence of FA or MV use. However, there was no clear association between months attempting to conceive at study entrance and FA or MV use.

* Women who had a pap smear once or more during the last 3 years were more likely to use FA or MV supplements, and women who engaged in physical activity were more likely to use FA or MV supplements than sedentary women. Women with a body mass index (BMI) ≥30 kg/m² were less likely to use FA or MV supplements.

* Smoking was associated with a decreased prevalence of FA or MV use, and women who consumed ≥15 drinks/week were less likely to use FA or MV supplements. Women with a history of hypertension, diabetes, thyroid disease, pelvic inflammatory disease, or infections with chlamydia were not more likely to use FA or MV supplements.

* The study's findings indicate that more than one-third of the pregnancy planners did not follow the preconceptional FA recommendation, and that women with other risky behaviors, such as smoking and alcohol use, obesity, and being physically inactive, are less likely to comply with the FA recommendation or use MV supplements.

* The study's results suggest that targeted interventions are needed to increase awareness and compliance with the FA recommendation, particularly among women with risky behaviors. Additionally, the study highlights the need for more research on the predictors of FA and MV use among pregnancy planners.

<summary>
• Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is a condition that results from the narrowing of arteries in the lower extremities due to atherosclerosis, and it is a predictor of substantial coronary and cerebral vascular risk. The most common symptom of PAD is intermittent claudication, and it is often associated with high blood concentrations of total cholesterol and LDL-cholesterol. Statins, which are lipid-lowering drugs, have been shown to reduce lipid levels and improve endothelial function, reducing oxidative stress and affecting lipid metabolism enzyme activities. The aim of this study was to evaluate lipid peroxidation parameters and total antioxidant capacity in patients with PAD before and after surgery, as well as in patients receiving simvastatin therapy.

• The study found that patients with PAD had enhanced oxidative stress, as demonstrated by elevated serum levels of malondialdehyde (MDA), and that simvastatin therapy reduced MDA concentrations. The total antioxidant capacity of serum, as measured by the ferric reducing antioxidant power (FRAP) assay, was similar in patients before surgery and those on simvastatin therapy, but decreased 35 and 710 days after surgery. The study also found that ceruloplasmin activity was higher in patients on simvastatin therapy and 710 days after surgery, suggesting that simvastatin may be implicated in antioxidant properties of ceruloplasmin. The results of the study support the efficacy of statin therapy in PAD.

• The study's findings are consistent with the hypothesis that lipid peroxidation may be one mechanism through which several risk factors promote PAD. The results suggest that statin therapy relieves symptoms and improves function in patients with lower extremity PAD, and that it may reduce oxidative stress by decreasing the generation of reactive oxygen species. Further studies are needed to clarify the mechanisms involved in PAD and the relative importance of the lipid-related and nonlipid-related effects of statins. The study's results have implications for the treatment of PAD and highlight the importance of antioxidant therapy in this condition.

<summary>
* The demand for herbal remedies in Nigeria has been increasing, but there is a lack of scientific data to support their medicinal claims. Many Nigerians believe that herbal medicines are natural and effective, but this has contributed to the indiscriminate use of packaged herbals, which can have toxic effects. The study aimed to assess the safety and validity of a popular herbal remedy called Fijk.

* Fijk is a mixture of 13 medicinal plants and is indicated for the treatment of various ailments, including obesity, diabetes, and high blood pressure. However, there is no scientific data to support its medicinal benefits, and a search of online research libraries revealed no empirical data on Fijk. The study aimed to determine the effect of oral and repeated exposure to Fijk on rat plasma biochemical indices and liver morphology.

* The study found that oral administration of Fijk to rats did not produce significant changes in body weight, but caused significant reductions in rat plasma protein levels and alterations in lipid profile. The exposure to Fijk also caused significant elevations in rat plasma triglyceride levels and depleted rat plasma HDL-C levels. The atherogenic index was also elevated in the groups exposed to Fijk.

* The study also found that oral administration of Fijk to rats caused significant increases in rat plasma ALT and AST levels, indicating liver toxicity. The levels of rat plasma ALP were also reduced, and the ratio of AST to ALT in plasma was less than one, indicating acute or chronic liver injury. The study also found that oral exposure to Fijk caused lipid peroxidation and oxidative stress in rats.

* The light microscopic examination of rat liver sections revealed morphological lesions, including hemorrhage, ruptured vascular channels, hyperemia, and inflammation, indicating hepatic injury. The study concluded that oral and repeated exposure to Fijk herbal mixture in rats caused lipid peroxidation, potentiated hepatic lesion, and elevated atherogenic index. The study highlights the need for scientific data on the safety and validity of herbal remedies to aid informed choices by consumers.

<summary>
* Identifying carriers of autosomal recessive or X-linked disorders before pregnancy can benefit prospective parents by allowing them to make informed reproductive decisions. Carrier screening and carrier testing are two approaches to identifying carriers, with carrier screening detecting carrier status in individuals without an a priori increased risk and carrier testing detecting carrier status in individuals with a higher a priori risk. Preconceptional carrier screening can strengthen reproductive autonomy and informed decision-making, and it can be offered individually or as an organized screening program. The goal of preconceptional carrier screening is to enable couples to make informed reproductive choices.

* Commercial companies are now offering direct-to-consumer (DTC) preconceptional carrier tests, which raise ethical concerns. These tests provide information about monogenic diseases and the risk of having affected offspring, but they may not meet traditional screening criteria. The tests may include a large number of disorders, including less severe ones, and may not provide adequate information and counseling. The companies may also not ensure informed decision-making and may not provide adequate follow-up care.

* The DTC offer of preconceptional carrier tests challenges traditional screening criteria, including the condition being an important health problem and the test being simple, safe, precise, and validated. The tests may not meet these criteria, and the companies may not provide adequate information and counseling. The tests may also include disorders with variable penetrance and expressivity, making it difficult to provide accurate information. The companies may prioritize technical and economic aspects over policy considerations.

* The DTC offer of preconceptional carrier tests also raises concerns about informed decision-making and follow-up care. The companies may not provide adequate information and counseling, and the tests may not be embedded in a medically supervised context. The companies may also not ensure that users understand the test results and the reproductive options available. The tests may also create anxiety and worry in users, and the companies may not provide adequate support.

* The implementation of preconceptional carrier tests should result in the optimization of advantages while reducing risks or adverse effects. The tests should be suitable for important health problems and have a known predictive value. The companies should ensure quality pre- and post-test information and counseling, and the testing process should lead to informed decision-making. Regulatory oversight is necessary to ensure that the companies meet these criteria and provide responsible genetic testing services to the public.

<summary>
* The study investigated the common indications for removal of internal fixation devices and highlighted potential issues. The majority of patients who needed removal of implants were men (85.5%). The mean age of patients requiring removal for infection was higher (49.33 years) than those with pain (31.6 years) or implant failure (35 years).

* Implant-associated pain or discomfort was the most common reason necessitating removal (39.75%). Brown et al. found that 31% of patients undergoing open reduction and internal fixation of ankle fractures had persistent lateral pain. In this study, all patients had at least some relief in their hardware pain at 4 months follow-up.

* The next most common indication was implant infection (about 29%). Trampuz and Widmer estimated that overall about 5% of all internal fixation devices become infected. The incidence of infections is likely to rise as more operations are performed and longevity increases.

* Implant failure was the next most common indication in symptomatic patients, but it was less common than those in whom the hardware was removed at the patient's behest. Reasons for failure of the implant include faulty implant, faulty operative technique, inadequate implant, delayed healing, and patient noncompliance. Akhtar et al. cited the most common cause of failure as poor quality of the implant.

* Seventeen patients (20.48%) had their implants removed on demand, despite being asymptomatic. During the course of their follow-up, three of these had persistent pain at the operated site. Two developed superficial wound infections which prolonged their hospital stay but responded to intravenous antibiotics and wound lavage.

* The most consistently encountered obstacle during surgery was difficulty in removing the hardware from the bone. This was seen especially in locked plates of the distal humerus and forearm, with ingrowth of bone around the plate/screws. Screw heads had to be cut off to remove the plate in two patients because of this complication, and the shank left in the bone.

* The study found that the most frequently removed implants were distal tibial/ankle plates (14.45% of implants removed), femoral IM nails (13.25%), olecranon wires and plates (12.04%), and tibial IM nails and patellar TBWs (9.53% each). All implants except one removed in the series were made of stainless steel, and all were made by Indian manufacturers. The issue of removing metallic implants used in fracture fixation has been oft discussed, and at length

<summary>
• The study investigated the effects of -aminoadipic acid (AAA) on retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) in a rat model of acute ocular hypertension (AOH), which mimics glaucoma. AAA treatment was found to rescue RGCs from apoptosis and reduce the number of TUNEL-positive cells, indicating a protective effect on RGCs. Additionally, AAA treatment attenuated Müller cell gliosis, as shown by reduced GFAP immunoreactivity in Müller cell processes across the inner plexiform layer.
• The study suggests that AAA promotes the survival of RGCs in the AOH model by inhibiting Müller cell gliosis and downregulating TNF- production. This is significant because activated Müller cells contribute to the progression of glaucoma by inducing RGC death. Overall, the findings suggest that AAA may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of neurodegeneration in glaucoma.

<summary>
* The LAEFTR-L procedure is a minimally invasive technique for resecting non-ampullary superficial duodenal neoplasms (SDNs) that combines laparoscopy and endoscopy. This method allows for complete resection without peritoneal exposure of tumor cells or severe adverse events (SAEs).
* The procedure involves mobilizing the duodenum, identifying the target lesion, ligating it with a ligation device, and then resecting it using a snare technique. The specimen is retrieved intraluminally, and the duodenal wall is closed with sutures to prevent exposure of the abdominal cavity to malignant cells.
* The LAEFTR-L procedure has several advantages over conventional full-thickness resection (FTR) procedures, including the ability to collect the resected specimen intraluminally and avoiding the risk of intraperitoneal tumor dissemination. Additionally, LAEFTR-L does not require proficient experience in endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD).
* The study suggests that LAEFTR-L may be a promising technique for the treatment of non-ampullary SDNs, but prospective studies are needed to further evaluate its efficacy and safety. The procedure may be particularly suitable for lesions smaller than 15 mm in diameter and located in areas that are easily accessible by laparoscopic mobilization.

<summary>
• Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a group of autosomal recessive conditions caused by defects in enzymes necessary for cortisol synthesis, with 90-95% of cases due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency (21-OHD). This deficiency leads to signs and symptoms of androgen excess, including ambiguous genitalia in females and rapid somatic growth with accelerated skeletal maturation in both sexes.

• The typical medical treatment for CAH consists of oral glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid administration to compensate for adrenal steroid deficiencies and suppress adrenal androgens. The aim of treatment is to suppress adrenal androgens sufficiently without impairing growth, while allowing for normal pubertal development and fertility.

• The pathophysiology of CAH due to 21-OHD is closely linked to the degree of enzyme deficiency, leading to a state of hypocortisolism, hypoaldosteronism, and hyperandrogenism combined with catecholamine deficiency and several metabolic disturbances. The consequence of 21-OHD is a compensatory increase in hypothalamic and pituitary secretion of CRH and ACTH, stimulating the adrenal cortex and resulting in hyperplastic adrenal glands.

• CAH is classified as classic (severe form) or non-classic (mild or late-onset form), with classic CAH subclassified as salt-losing or non-salt-losing (simple virilizing). Non-classic CAH may be asymptomatic or associated with signs of androgen excess developing during childhood or at puberty.

• The classic forms of CAH are characterized by a congenital decrease of cortisol and aldosterone secretion and an increase in androgen biosynthesis, with all female infants typically having ambiguous genitalia at birth. Boys with classic CAH have no signs of CAH at birth, except subtle hyperpigmentation and possible penile enlargement.

• The diagnosis of CAH can be made in newborn screening programs by screening for 17-hydroxyprogesterone in dried blood spots, with a high concentration of 17-hydroxyprogesterone in a randomly timed blood sample being diagnostic of classic 21-OHD. The gold standard for diagnosis is a corticotropin stimulation test, with measurement of 17-hydroxyprogesterone at 60 min.

• The development of adrenal adenoma or carcinoma in patients with CAH is rare, but the incidence of adrenal masses appears to be higher in CAH patients and in heterozygotes than in

<summary>
* The study examined the relationship between dietary and physical activity behaviors and self-rated health (SRH) in a population of adults from Miami-Dade County, Florida, with a majority of Hispanics and a significant proportion of Blacks. The results showed that modifiable lifestyle behaviors, such as low fruits and vegetables intake and high fat intake, were associated with poor/fair SRH in both males and females. Females who consumed 2 servings of fruits and vegetables per day were 2.1 times more likely to report poor/fair SRH compared to those who consumed 5 servings per day. Similarly, females who consumed mostly high fat foods were 1.5 times more likely to report poor/fair SRH compared to those who consumed primarily low fat foods.

* The study also found that physical activity was significantly associated with SRH in females, with those who performed 13 times a month or never of physical activity being 1.6 times more likely to report poor/fair SRH compared to those who performed 5 days per week of physical activity. In contrast, the association between physical activity and SRH was not significant for males after adjusting for confounding variables. The results suggest that gender differences may have implications in designing and monitoring lifestyle interventions to prevent cardiovascular diseases. Females who engaged in less physical activity were more likely to report poor/fair SRH compared to those who were more physically active.

* The study's findings are consistent with previous research that has shown that lifestyle behaviors, such as diet and physical activity, are associated with SRH. The results highlight the importance of promoting healthy lifestyle behaviors, particularly in minority populations, to reduce the risk of cardiovascular diseases. The study's limitations include the cross-sectional design, which precludes establishing causality between lifestyle behaviors and SRH, and the lack of data on other factors that may influence SRH, such as socioeconomic status and psychosocial factors. Overall, the study's findings suggest that targeting lifestyle behaviors may be an effective strategy for improving SRH and reducing cardiovascular disease risk in minority populations.

<summary>
* The endoscopic injection of dextranomer/hyaluronic acid (DX/HA) is a minimally invasive treatment option for vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) with a success rate of 75-80%, but it has a lower success rate compared to open surgery and may require repeat injections.
* Intraoperative cystography, including positional instillation of contrast (PIC) cystography, can detect occult VUR and prevent postoperative contralateral new onset of VUR, but it is not a reliable method to predict the success of DX/HA injection and cannot replace postoperative studies.

<summary>

* The accuracy of detecting fetal pathology using ultrasound depends on the expertise of the sonographer and is limited by factors such as maternal obesity and oligohydramnios. Fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has been used since 1989 and has become increasingly important in diagnosing prenatal anomalies, particularly central nervous system pathology. Advances in MRI technology and knowledge of fetal pathology have improved its role in diagnostic work-ups.

* Ventriculomegaly is a condition where the maximal diameter of the atrium of the lateral ventricles exceeds 10 mm, and its prevalence ranges from 0.3-1.5%. The severity of ventriculomegaly can be classified as mild, moderate, or severe, and it has a wide range of causes, including imbalance between cerebrospinal fluid production and absorption, abnormal cerebral development, and destructive disease processes. Measurement of the lateral ventricle is subject to errors, and a precise definition of reference planes and anatomical landmarks is important.

* Fetal MRI is mainly performed on 1.5 Tesla scanners, and no adverse health effects have been demonstrated for either the fetus or mother. The HASTE sequence is commonly used, combining short acquisition times with good signal-to-noise ratio, T2 contrast, and spatial resolution. T1-weighted imaging is used to detect hemorrhages or calcifications, but has a lower signal-to-noise ratio and is more susceptible to fetal and maternal motion.

* MRI has an excellent contrast resolution, enabling easy differentiation between gray and white matter, and allows direct visualization of the cortical region and fossa posterior without sonographic limitations. Knowledge of normal cerebral gyri and sulci development is important for diagnosis and counseling. The sylvian fissure and callosal sulcus are visible at 14-16 weeks, and the central sulcus is reliably seen at 24-25 weeks of gestation.

* An important role of MRI in prenatal diagnostic work-ups is the detection and characterization of additional cerebral anomalies, which can be detected in up to 70-85% of cases. Isolated ventriculomegaly has a lower incidence of peri- and postnatal morbidity and mortality, particularly in mild forms. Fetal MRI can detect additional malformations, including corpus callosum dysgenesis, cortical anomalies, and interhemispheric cysts.

* The incidence of additional malformations detected on MRI following normal ultrasound findings varies greatly between studies, depending on the severity of ventriculomegaly

* Lung cancer is the third most common cancer diagnosed and the leading cause of cancer-related death in the US, with 226,160 patients diagnosed and 160,340 deaths in 2012.
* The study analyzed a cohort of 126,123 patients aged 65 or older with lung cancer diagnosed between 1999 and 2005, using SEER and Medicare data.
* About 19.8% of patients presented with or subsequently had evidence of bone metastasis, with 51% of these patients experiencing skeletal-related events (SREs).
* The proportion of patients with bone metastasis was 21% overall, and 38% for distant stage lung cancer, within a year of diagnosis.
* Having a bone metastasis was associated with mortality among lung cancer patients, with a hazard ratio of 2.4, regardless of SREs.
* The study found no difference in mortality between patients with bone metastasis complicated by SREs and patients with bone metastasis but without SREs.
* The most common SRE was radiotherapy to bone, followed by fracture, spinal cord compression, and surgery to bone.
* The study's findings highlight the importance of considering bone metastasis and SREs in the management of lung cancer patients, particularly in the elderly.

<summary>
• The study compared the effect of different smear layer removal methods on the bond strength of self-adhesive cements used with fiber posts. The methods used were physiological saline, sodium hypochlorite, EDTA, orthophosphoric acid, and photodynamic diode laser.

• The results showed that the photodynamic diode laser and orthophosphoric acid groups had higher bond strength values compared to the other groups. The laser group showed post-cement failure, while the other groups showed mixed failures.

• The study found that the smear layer removal methods affected the bond strength of the fiber post cemented with adhesive resin to dentin. The null hypothesis was rejected, and the results suggested that different smear layer removal methods affect the bond strength.

• The photodynamic diode laser group showed higher bond strength without removing the smear layer, which may be due to the fact that collagen fibrils structure does not change after lasing. This improves the infiltration of the luting agent and increases bond strength.

• The study concluded that the photodynamic diode laser is a valuable instrument for modifying the smear layer and increasing the bond strength of self-adhesive cements used with fiber posts. The results suggest that the laser can be used as an alternative to traditional irrigation systems for smear layer removal.

<summary>
• The human gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that plays a crucial role in our overall health, and recent studies have shed light on its composition and function. The gut microbiome is composed of trillions of microorganisms, including bacteria, archaea, viruses, and fungi, which work together to maintain homeostasis. Understanding the gut microbiome is essential for developing new treatments for various diseases.

• The gut microbiome is influenced by various factors, including diet, lifestyle, and genetics, and can be classified into different enterotypes based on the dominant bacterial species present. Enterotypes are associated with different physiological properties and may influence our susceptibility to certain diseases. Further research is needed to fully understand the relationship between enterotypes and disease.

• The gut microbiome plays a crucial role in energy harvest and storage, and alterations in the gut microbiome have been linked to obesity and metabolic disorders. The gut microbiome influences the way we process and store energy, and changes in the gut microbiome can lead to metabolic changes that contribute to obesity. Further research is needed to understand the mechanisms underlying the relationship between the gut microbiome and obesity.

• Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a complex condition that is influenced by the gut microbiome, and alterations in the gut microbiome have been linked to the development of IBD. The gut microbiome plays a crucial role in maintaining immune homeostasis, and changes in the gut microbiome can lead to the development of IBD. Further research is needed to understand the mechanisms underlying the relationship between the gut microbiome and IBD.

• The gut microbiome is also influenced by the immune system, and alterations in the immune system can lead to changes in the gut microbiome. The gut microbiome and immune system interact closely, and changes in one can lead to changes in the other. Further research is needed to understand the mechanisms underlying the relationship between the gut microbiome and immune system.

<summary>
*Tazarotene, a synthetic retinoid, has been found to be effective in treating distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis, a chronic fungal infection of the nail. In a study of 15 patients, complete healing was observed in all patients after 12 weeks of treatment with tazarotene 0.1% gel.
*Tazarotene's efficacy is attributed to its ability to reduce hyperkeratinization, favoring keratinocyte differentiation, and its immunomodulating and anti-inflammatory properties, which inhibit the infective process. The drug also has a direct fungistatic activity, as demonstrated by disk diffusion assay.
*The study's results are promising, with no side effects except for mild erythema on the perionychia in two patients, and nail growth and tropism were also restored. The nails were completely healed at the follow-up visits up to 6 months.
*Tazarotene may be a useful alternative to current topical treatments for onychomycosis, which often have limited efficacy and require prolonged application. Further studies are needed to confirm the efficacy of tazarotene in a larger cohort of patients with a longer follow-up.

<summary>
• Cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) is an important treatment for patients with heart failure and left ventricular (LV) dyssynchrony, but 25-35% of patients do not respond to CRT.
• The study aimed to investigate the acute hemodynamic response to endocardial LV pacing in patients who did not respond to CRT.
• Twenty-four patients with heart failure and LV dyssynchrony who did not respond to CRT were included in the study.
• The patients underwent an acute hemodynamic study to evaluate the response to endocardial LV pacing at different locations.
• In 11 patients, endocardial LV pacing resulted in a significant increase in LV dP/dtmax, with the highest response observed in the basal and mid-posterolateral segments.
• The study found that the longest time interval between the onset of the QRS complex and LV sensing (Q-LV interval) resulted in the best hemodynamic response in 85% of patients.
• Ten patients were considered candidates for LV endocardial pacing, and 5 of them underwent implantation of an LV endocardial lead, resulting in clinical improvement in all 5 patients.
• The study suggests that endocardial LV pacing guided by acute hemodynamic studies may be a useful approach for patients who do not respond to CRT.
• The results of the study support the idea that endocardial LV pacing can be an effective alternative or addition to epicardial CRT in certain patients.

* Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) affects 1 in 500 to 1 in 1000 individuals, and its symptoms may not appear until the third or fourth decade of life. Only about half of the patients will progress to renal failure, and several risk factors are associated with a more rapid course. Complications in pregnant subjects with chronic renal failure undergoing dialysis include maternal hypertension, preeclampsia, and anemia. With careful monitoring, spinal anesthesia can be safely performed for cesarean section in patients undergoing hemodialysis.

* A 35-year-old primigravida with ADPKD was scheduled for emergency cesarean section due to oligohydramnios. She was diagnosed with ADPKD in the seventh month of pregnancy and was hospitalized and hemodialyzed thrice a week for two months. Her clinical parameters were stable, and her biochemical profile revealed mild proteinuria and pus cells in urine. Her coagulation profile was normal, and she was given spinal anesthesia for the cesarean section.

* The patient's spinal anesthesia was successfully administered, and she did not complain of pain for four hours. She maintained normal hemodynamic and biochemical parameters postoperatively and did not require any hemodialysis. There was no neurological deficit, and she was shifted to the nephrology unit after 72 hours and discharged on day 7. Women with moderate or severe antenatal renal insufficiency often experience deterioration of their renal functions during pregnancy.

* The pathophysiology of how pregnancy exacerbates renal disease is unknown, but one hypothesis is that increased glomerular perfusion causes further injury to the kidneys in patients with preexisting impairment of function. Another hypothesis suggests that preexisting renal disease may induce a cascade of platelet aggregation, microvascular fibrin thrombus formation, and endothelial dysfunction. Increased cardiac output and decreased intrarenal vascular resistance in pregnancy cause an 80% increase in renal blood flow and a 50% increase in glomerular filtration rate. Modest proteinuria also occurs during pregnancy.

* The patient presented with symptoms of renal insufficiency only in the seventh month of gestation, making it difficult to determine whether her disease progressed during pregnancy or was missed earlier. Her blood erythrocyte count and hematocrit were increased above normal, and her blood coagulation studies and platelet counts were normal. Hypertension is an early symptom of ADPKD, occurring in approximately 60% of patients

* The study analyzed the lactation curve of Karan Fries cows with and without mastitis to predict milk yield using a gamma type function. The data consisted of 11,728 fortnightly test-day milk yields from 733 cows over 12 years. The lactation curve parameters were estimated, and the model was found to be accurate in predicting milk yield with a high coefficient of determination (R²) and low root mean square error (RMSE). The study aimed to identify the pattern of milk yield and persistency of lactation in normal and mastitis-affected cows.

* The results showed that the fortnightly test-day milk yield increased till the 3rd or 4th fortnight and then declined steadily with advancing lactation. The peak milk yield was higher in normal cows than in mastitis-affected cows, and the decline in milk yield was more rapid in mastitis-affected cows. The lactation curve parameters, including initial milk yield, ascending slope, and descending slope, differed between normal and mastitis-affected cows. The study found that the gamma type function was a good fit for the lactation curve data.

* The study found that the peak milk yield was higher in the 4th parity than in the 1st parity, and the persistency of lactation declined with increasing parity. The lactation curve parameters, including initial milk yield, ascending slope, and descending slope, differed between parities. The study found that the gamma type function was a good fit for the lactation curve data in all parities. The results were consistent with previous studies on lactation curves in dairy cows.

* The study found that the lactation curve parameters, including initial milk yield, ascending slope, and descending slope, differed between normal and mastitis-affected cows. The peak milk yield was higher in normal cows than in mastitis-affected cows, and the decline in milk yield was more rapid in mastitis-affected cows. The study found that the gamma type function was a good fit for the lactation curve data in both normal and mastitis-affected cows. The results were consistent with previous studies on lactation curves in dairy cows.

* The study found that the lactation curve parameters, including initial milk yield, ascending slope, and descending slope, differed between parities in both normal and mastitis-affected cows. The peak milk yield was higher in the 4th parity than in the 1st parity, and the persistency of lactation declined with increasing parity. The study found

* The study found that NDGA, a compound found in creosote bush, extended the lifespan of male mice by 12% at a dose of 373mg/kg body weight/day.
* The same dose of NDGA also increased the incidence of liver, lung, and thymus tumors, as well as hemorrhagic diathesis, in the mice.
* In contrast, NDGA did not affect food consumption or locomotor activity in Drosophila, but did increase their lifespan by 23%.
* The study suggests that the target(s) and mechanism(s) of NDGA action may be phylogenetically conserved between mice and flies.
* The doses of NDGA that extended lifespan in mice overlapped with those that produced serious pathologies, including liver and kidney toxicity.
* The study's findings are consistent with previous reports of NDGA's inhibitory effects on growth factor signaling and tumor growth, but also suggest that it may increase tumor formation.
* The mechanisms by which NDGA extends lifespan are unclear, but may involve inhibition of mTORC1 activity, reduction of oxidative stress, or other pathways.

<summary>
* Genetic variation contributes to disease susceptibility and treatment response, and genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have enabled the discovery of genetic variants associated with complex diseases. Personalized medicine aims to improve medical decision-making by identifying the optimal drug and dosage for individual patients. This approach goes beyond just identifying the optimal treatment and may also involve withholding treatment, preventive interventions, or targeted treatment options.

* Biomarkers are characteristics that can be measured and evaluated as indicators of normal biological processes, pathogenic processes, or pharmacologic responses to therapeutic interventions. There are different types of biomarkers, including DNA biomarkers, DNA tumor biomarkers, and general biomarkers, each with its own characteristics and applications. Biomarkers can be used for diagnosis, prognosis, and prediction of treatment response.

* Diagnostic biomarkers are used to determine the diagnosis or severity of a disease, and screening biomarkers are used to discriminate between healthy individuals and those in an early stage of disease. Prognostic biomarkers predict the likely course of disease in a defined clinical population under standard treatment conditions, while predictive biomarkers predict the likely response to a specific treatment. Examples of biomarkers in current use include DNA tumor biomarkers for breast cancer prognosis and predictive biomarkers for response to treatment in patients with hepatitis C virus-1 infection.

* The development of diagnostic or prognostic biomarkers involves several phases, including discovery, assay development and validation, retrospective validation, prospective investigation, and health economics study. Each phase has its own goals and requirements, and the process can be complex and time-consuming. The use of biobanks for prospective validation of DNA biomarkers is particularly challenging due to the need to ensure that the biobank has not been used before and that the biomarker levels are not affected by sample handling and storage protocols.

* The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has issued guidance on the development and validation of companion diagnostics, which are predictive biomarkers essential for the safe and effective use of a corresponding therapeutic product. The guidance emphasizes the need for validation of the biomarker as part of the evaluation of efficacy of the experimental treatment, and information about the diagnostic is reflected in the drug's labeling. The use of biobanks for prospective validation of DNA biomarkers may play a role in pharmacovigilance and post-marketing surveillance of drug use.

* Study designs for biomarker validation include selection designs, interaction or biomarker-stratified designs, and adaptive study designs. The choice of study design depends on the research question and the goals of the study,

<summary>
• The study uses Tethered Particle Microscopy (TPM) to measure the flexural stiffness of myosin Va (MyoVa) motor protein and its subdomains. TPM involves attaching a quantum dot to a MyoVa construct and measuring its motion relative to a reference point, allowing for the estimation of flexural stiffness. The study finds that the lever arm of MyoVa has a flexural stiffness of 0.0346 pN/nm, which is critical for the motor's processive movement. The addition of calcium reduces the lever arm stiffness by 40%, which may negatively impact the motor's processivity.

• The study also estimates the flexural stiffness of the distal rod domain and the lever arm/rod junction of MyoVa. The distal rod domain has a flexural stiffness of 0.0326 pN/nm, while the lever arm/rod junction is highly compliant, allowing for the free diffusive search of the unbound leading head. The compliance of the lever arm/rod junction is critical for MyoVa to maneuver through actin-actin intersections and switch tracks on actin bundles. The study provides new insights into the structural components of MyoVa that are critical to its functional capacities.

* The study aimed to determine if clinical outcome after surgical resection of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) or esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) could be predicted by functional polymorphisms in different proto-oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes. Six single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the AURKA, ERBB2, MDM2, CDH1, CDKN2A, and TP73 genes were genotyped in 346 esophageal cancer patients.

* The study found that patients with EAC carrying the heterozygous MDM2 (rs2279744) T/G genotype had significantly improved disease-free survival (DFS) compared with patients carrying the wild-type genotype. The post-operative TNM stage of the tumor and the radicality of resection were also found to be important factors for DFS.

* Patients with EAC harboring the homozygous CDH1 (rs5030625) GA/GA genotype had a significantly reduced survival as compared with patients carrying the wild-type genotype. Only four EAC patients carried the GA/GA genotype, which may represent a chance finding.

* The MDM2 protein is a nuclear phosphoprotein that binds and inhibits the tumor suppressor TP53 as part of an autoregulatory negative feedback loop. The G variant of the MDM2 SNP is known to increase promoter-binding affinity, leading to up-regulation of MDM2 and consequent inhibition and down-regulation of the p53 pathway.

* The study suggests that the MDM2 T/G genotype may interact with the tumor TP53 status, which could modify the association between TP53 status and breast cancer survival. The tumor TP53 status was not associated with breast cancer survival among carriers of the variant MDM2 allele (T/G or G/G).

* The CDH1 GA/GA genotype has been reported to suppress CDH1 gene expression and was found to be associated with familial gastric cancer and sporadic colorectal cancer. The GA-allele has been associated with significant suppression of CDH1 promoter activity in colorectal and gastric cancer cell lines.

* The study's findings could contribute to the identification of patients who are at high or low risk for the development of disease recurrences, and may serve as hypothesis-generating for prospective studies that evaluate the prognostic significance of germ-line variants.

<summary>
• Oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC) is a common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive patients, with a prevalence of over 90% in patients with CD4+ counts below 200 cells/mm.
• The most common clinical presentation of OPC is pseudomembranous candidiasis, followed by erythematous, angular cheilitis, and a combination of these forms.
• Candida albicans is the most frequently isolated species in OPC, accounting for 92% of cases, followed by Candida tropicalis and Candida glabrata.
• The distribution of OPC lesions is associated with CD4+ cell counts, with 73% of cases occurring in patients with CD4+ counts below 200 cells/mm, indicating a decrease in immunodeficiency of the immune system.

• Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women, with approximately 1.67 million new patients diagnosed annually worldwide, and sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is a crucial step in staging and determining prognosis. The standard method for determining axillary staging in early-stage breast cancer patients is SLNB with the combined technique of radioisotope and blue dye. However, this method has drawbacks, including the use of radioisotopes, which are subject to stringent regulations and not accessible in many parts of the world. Therefore, alternative techniques are being explored, including the use of magnetic tracers.

• A magnetic technique using a superparamagnetic iron oxide (SPIO) tracer and a handheld magnetometer has been evaluated as a radiation-free alternative to the combined technique. The SPIO tracer is administered interstitially, and the magnetometer is used to detect the sentinel lymph nodes (SLNs). The magnetic technique has been found to be non-inferior to the combined technique, but with a discordance rate of 2.0-6.9%. The particle size of the SPIO tracer has been identified as a key factor influencing lymphatic uptake and lymph node retention.

• Three SPIO-based licensed formulations with a broad range of particle sizes were used in this study to evaluate their performance for SLNB. The tracers were diluted to the same iron concentration, and their hydrodynamic particle size was determined using dynamic light scattering. The tracers were injected subcutaneously into the areolas of mini-pigs, and transcutaneous magnetometer measurements were performed to identify the SLNs. The SLNs were then excised and sent for iron quantification and histopathological evaluation.

• The results showed that the 59 nm tracer had the highest iron content and magnetometer counts, and was able to detect SLNs transcutaneously within 30 minutes of injection. The 32 nm tracer had the lowest iron content and magnetometer counts, and was found to pass through the efferent system and onto higher echelon nodes. The 111 nm tracer had intermediate iron content and magnetometer counts, and was found to be deposited mainly within macrophages.

• The study found a linear relationship between the iron content of the ex vivo SLNs and the handheld magnetometer counts for all tracers. The magnetometer count was 2.8 times higher for the 59 nm tracer compared to the same amount of iron for the 111 nm tracer, and 1.3 times higher for the 32 nm tracer compared to

* The study investigated the levels of vaspin and adiponectin in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2DM) and renal insufficiency (RI). The results showed that serum vaspin levels were lower in T2DM patients than in non-T2DM individuals, but there was no significant difference between patients with RI and those without RI. Vaspin levels were found to be related to creatinine, total cholesterol, and hemoglobin A1c levels. The study also found that vaspin levels were higher in women than in men.

* The study also examined the levels of adiponectin, a hormone produced by adipose tissue, in patients with T2DM and RI. The results showed that adiponectin levels were higher in patients with RI than in those without RI, regardless of whether they had T2DM or not. Adiponectin levels were found to be related to age, systolic blood pressure, creatinine, and hemoglobin A1c levels. The study also found that adiponectin levels were higher in women than in men.

* The study's findings suggest that measuring the levels of vaspin and adiponectin may be beneficial for predicting cardiovascular events and patient survival in patients with RI. The study's results also highlight the importance of considering the complex relationships between vaspin, adiponectin, and other clinical parameters in patients with T2DM and RI. Further studies are needed to fully understand the roles of vaspin and adiponectin in these patients. The study's findings may have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for T2DM and RI.

• The study analyzed data from two multicenter, double-blind, randomized clinical trials to test surrogate variables for neuropathic diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) and explore the correlation between granulation tissue development and complete healing. The trials included 190 ulcers from 190 patients with type 1 or 2 diabetes, Wagner grade 3 or 4 DFUs, and a median age of over 60 years.

• The study used several candidate surrogate variables, including percent change in area, log healing rate, and ratio of log areas, as well as granulation tissue development at the 2nd week and end of treatment (EOT). These variables were evaluated for their ability to predict complete wound closure.

• The results showed that granulation tissue development had a high capacity to discriminate between healers and non-healers, with a correct classification rate of 79.5% at EOT and 73.7% at the 2nd week. The proportion mediated by granulation variables was very high, suggesting that almost 100% of the effect of treatment on complete healing may have been mediated by granulation tissue formation.

• The study also found that the effect of treatment on healing was lost when granulation variables were incorporated into the model, indicating that granulation tissue development is an essential part of the healing process. The odds ratios for the influence of covariates (initial area and etiology) were similar for the three dependent outcomes (2-week and EOT granulation and healing).

• The results were confirmed in a postmarketing study of 1,440 ulcers, which showed that granulation tissue development at EOT was an early predictor of final healing, with a 72.9% certainty and positive/negative predictive values of 71.7/75.8%, respectively.

• The study suggests that granulation tissue development can be used as a surrogate endpoint for complete wound closure in advanced DFUs, particularly in clinical trial design. This can be useful since it would not be necessary to wait for complete re-epithelialization due to treatment, and alternative wound closure procedures could be used after complete granulation.

• The study also found that area change-dependent candidates had a lower proportion mediated, which could be explained by a more exigent condition for these lesions. The models for final cicatrization and the granulation surrogates were adequate and fulfilled the original Prentice criteria for the definition of a surrogate endpoint.

<summary>
* Laparoscopic transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) mesh repair is a standard treatment for inguinal hernia in adults, but it is associated with early postoperative pain and chronic pain.
* The ideal mesh material is still debated, but mesh fixation with fibrin glue or self-fixating mesh with microhooks has advantages in reducing chronic groin pain.
* Modified TAPP repairs by needlescopic surgery (NTAPP) and single-incision laparoscopic surgery (STAPP) have been shown to be superior in patient outcomes over conventional TAPP repairs.
* This study compared the perioperative extent of surgical trauma and its postoperative impact on the abdominal wall after NTAPP and STAPP repair.
* The study found that NTAPP required significantly less operating time than STAPP repair, particularly in cases of direct hernia.
* The mean measured umbilical skin incision length was shorter in the NTAPP group compared to the STAPP group.
* NTAPP patients experienced less immediate postoperative pain and shorter sick leave compared to STAPP patients.
* Both groups achieved similar results in abdominal wall mobility and cosmetic satisfaction, but NTAPP patients had a shorter period of sick leave.
* The study suggests that NTAPP can further minimize surgical trauma to the abdominal wall tissue and has distinct advantages in the immediate postoperative phase.
* Randomized controlled trials are still needed to validate the benefits of needlescopic surgery.

<summary>
• The study aimed to verify the correlation between nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry in diagnosing hyperplasia of the pharyngeal tonsils in children. The results showed a regular and positive correlation between the two exams, but cephalometry tended to underestimate the size of the pharyngeal tonsils compared to nasopharyngoscopy. This suggests that nasopharyngoscopy is a more accurate exam for diagnosing nasopharyngeal obstruction.

• Nasopharyngoscopy is considered the gold standard exam for assessing the nasopharynx, providing a dynamic and tridimensional view of the region. Cephalometry, on the other hand, provides information about craniofacial growth and can complement nasopharyngoscopy in diagnosing mouth breathing. However, cephalometry has limitations, such as underestimating the size of the pharyngeal tonsils.

• The study found that most children showed grade 2 and 3 hyperplasia of the pharyngeal tonsils in the nasopharyngoscopic exam, while most children showed grade 1 hyperplasia in the cephalometric assessment. The sensitivity of cephalometry was 35%, and the negative predictive value was 72%. This suggests that a negative cephalometric exam may not provide an accurate assessment of the nasopharynx.

• Mouth breathing is a common complaint in children, and its diagnosis and treatment require a multidisciplinary approach. Cephalometry can provide early identification of alterations present in mouth-breathing patients and inform professionals about facial growth and dental occlusion. However, nasopharyngoscopy is necessary for a more accurate diagnosis of nasopharyngeal obstruction.

• The study highlights the importance of nasopharyngoscopy in diagnosing mouth breathing, as it can detect alterations that may not be visible on radiological exams. Cephalometry can complement nasopharyngoscopy, but it should not be relied upon as the sole diagnostic tool. A negative cephalometric exam should be followed up with a nasopharyngoscopic exam to rule out nasopharyngeal obstruction.

• The results of the study suggest that cephalometry can be a useful tool in the diagnosis and monitoring of mouth breathing, but it should be used in conjunction with nasopharyngoscopy. Nasopharyngoscopy is essential for an accurate diagnosis of nasopharyngeal obstruction, and cephalometry can provide additional information

<summary>
• The incidence of ipsilateral breast tumor relapse (IBTR) in patients previously treated for breast carcinoma is estimated to be less than 6%. It is necessary to distinguish between a true local recurrence (TR) of a previous tumor and the appearance of a new primary tumor (NPT) based on factors such as location, staging, and histological subtype. IBTR can be classified as either TR or NPT, with different natural histories, prognosis, and therapeutic management implications.

• The case of a 35-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer is presented, who developed a second primary tumor in the same breast four years after initial treatment. The second tumor was diagnosed as inflammatory breast cancer, and the patient received treatment with chemotherapy, trastuzumab, and breast reconstruction surgery. The patient remains in complete clinical remission four years and eight months after the last surgery.

• The risk of developing a second breast cancer is similar to the risk of developing a first breast cancer in the general population, and is influenced by factors such as ER status, period of diagnosis, and family history of breast and/or ovarian cancer. Surveillance and prevention of second cancer occurrence should consider these risk factors. The optimal systemic therapy for IBTR is unknown, and further studies are needed to determine the indications for treatment.

* Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a leading cause of severe vision loss in people aged 55 years and older in developed countries. The neovascular form of AMD, involving choroidal neovascularization (CNV) associated with fluid exudation or bleeding, accounts for the majority of cases of AMD-related severe central vision loss. Upregulation of angiogenic factors, including vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), has been implicated in the development and progression of AMD. The management of neovascular AMD has been transformed over the past decade with the development and advent of intravitreal anti-VEGF treatment.

* The study was conducted to determine and evaluate change from baseline to week 12 in Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity (CS) as the primary clinical end point in patients with recalcitrant exudative AMD, despite previous ranibizumab treatment, who were switched to aflibercept therapy. The study population included 40 randomly selected neovascular AMD patients with persistent fluid on spectral domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT) following at least three intravitreal injections of ranibizumab in the previous 6 months. The mean CS increased from 1.32 log units at baseline to 1.40 log units at week 12. There was a statistically significant decrease of 22 μm in mean central retinal thickness (CRT) from 354 μm at baseline to 332 μm at week 12.

* The study demonstrated that there is a general and immediate decreasing trend in mean CRT after treatment switch to aflibercept, while no statistically significant change from baseline visual acuity (VA) was noted. In this neovascular AMD population of suboptimal responders to ranibizumab, persistence of fluid is associated with impairment in visual function as measured by CS. The fluid reduction seen following a switch to aflibercept may be associated with improvement in CS. The study results support the argument that measurement of CS may provide a more complete understanding of the benefits of anti-VEGF treatment on vision-related functional performance in patients with neovascular AMD.

* The study suggests that CS should be considered as a significant independent parameter for determining degree of visual impairment and treatment response, as it provides predictive information on visual disability and vision-related quality of life. Switching of anti-VEGF agents in neovascular AMD patients is a viable treatment strategy to improve outcomes among initial nonresponders or for patients exhibiting recalcitrant

<summary>
• Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system, causing cognitive and physical impairments. It is a common disease among young adults, with most patients diagnosed between the ages of 20 and 40. The exact cause of MS is unknown, but genetic and environmental factors, including viruses, are thought to be involved. Researchers are trying to improve MS symptoms through behavioral changes, including exercise.

• Interleukin-25 (IL-25) is a cytokine that plays a key role in stimulating and developing T helper 2 (Th2) responses, which can regulate immune responses during inflammatory diseases like MS. A polymorphism within the IL-25 gene, c424c/a, has been associated with immune system-related diseases. This study aimed to evaluate the association between the c424c/a polymorphism and MS in an Iranian population. The study recruited 74 patients with relapsing-remitting MS and 75 healthy controls.

• The study found that the frequency distribution of the genotypes was not statistically different between patients with MS and controls. The odds ratio of MS development in patients with the ac versus cc genotypes was 0.832, and for aa versus cc genotypes was 0.936, neither of which reached statistical significance. The frequencies of a and c alleles were also not significantly different between groups. The odds ratio of MS development in patients with the a allele versus patients with the c allele was 0.907, which did not reach statistical significance.

• The study's results suggested that neither the aa, ac, and cc genotypes nor the a and c alleles were associated with MS in the Iranian population. This is consistent with a previous study that found no association between the c424c/a polymorphism and inflammatory bowel disease. However, other studies have found that other polymorphisms within the IL-25 gene are associated with MS. It may be concluded that other polymorphisms, but not the c424c/a polymorphism, regulate IL-25 expression.

• The study's limitations include the lack of evaluation of other polymorphisms within the IL-25 gene and the lack of evaluation of serum levels of IL-25. A larger sample size may be needed to understand the roles of the c424c/a polymorphism in the pathogenesis of MS. The study's results suggest that the c424c/a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene is not associated with MS and cannot be considered a risk factor for MS development.
