• The study aimed to explore the prevalence of aortic aneurysms (AAs) in elderly Korean males with hypertension and multiple risk factors for coronary heart disease (CHD) using non-contrast computed tomography (CT). The study found that the prevalence of thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA) was significantly higher than that of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in this population.

• The study identified several risk factors associated with TAA, including older age, larger body surface area, higher diastolic blood pressure, and presence of AAA. In contrast, AAA was associated with dyslipidemia, current or past smoking, and presence of TAA.

• The study found that TAA was more prevalent in patients with AAA compared to those without AAA, and that more than one-third of the study subjects had a TAA. However, most TAAs had a diameter < 50 mm, which is not large enough to indicate a need for immediate intervention.

• The study highlighted the need for further research to establish distinct screening strategies for TAA and AAA according to risk factors and ethnicity, and to clarify the relationship among TAA, AAA, dyslipidemia, serum cholesterol, and statin therapy.

• Endometrial cancer has become the most common invasive malignancy of the female genital tract in developed countries, and early screening methods have made major progress. The successful experience of cervical carcinoma screening has led to a pressing need for an effective approach to screening endometrial carcinoma and its precursor.

• Endometrial complex hyperplasia with atypia and endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN) are considered precursors of type I endometrioid adenocarcinoma, and endometrial glandular dysplasia is the precursor of type II carcinoma. These lesions take a certain period of time to develop into carcinoma.

• Traditionally, endometrial samples for histologic analysis can be obtained from D&C or under hysteroscope, but the adequacy of specimens obtained using the SAP-1 device compared to these methods is unknown. The SAP-1 device is a direct endometrial sampler designed for minimal pain during sampling.

• The aim of this study was to investigate whether liquid-based SurePath preparation for endometrial cytology test (ECT) can maintain the three-dimensional structure of the endometrium. Histology is the gold standard for evaluating the accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, positive prediction value (PPV), and negative prediction value (NPV) of ECT.

• The study was performed from November 2011 to May 2014 at the Obstetrics and Gynecology Department of Peking University First Hospital and was approved by the hospital ethics committee. The risk factors included age ≥40 years, intrinsically high estrogen, extrinsically high estrogen, high body mass index (BMI), hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and family history of cancer.

• Patients with certain conditions were excluded from the study, including those with ultrasound scanning suggesting a distorted uterus cavity or those with an intra-uterine device. The SAP-1 sampling device consists of a flexible latex loop with spines on the side and a smooth tip to prevent injury to the myometrium.

• The device is easy to operate and can be used in an outpatient setting, at health examination centers, and in community hospitals. The cytological smears were evaluated by two independent gynecological cytologists who were blinded to the study procedures.

* Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women, with nearly 1.7 million new cases in 2012, and the highest incidence rates are in Europe and North America. The mortality rate has decreased in some parts of the world, with screening mammography associated with a 50% reduction in mortality rate.

* Digital mammography (DM) is less likely to be lost or damaged and has slightly higher sensitivity than screen-film mammography (SFM), and it is now the most commonly performed procedure for breast cancer detection. DM is also less likely to be obscured by overlapping tissue, which is a limitation of conventional mammography.

* Tomosynthesis (DBT) is a 3D procedure that uses x-rays to create image slices of a tissue volume, which decreases the problem of confusing overlapping tissue. DBT is a mammography-based technique that obtains multiple low-dose images using a moving x-ray tube head rotating across the breast in an arc of 15%-50%.

* DBT has been shown to increase mammogram accuracy, with a 40% higher invasive cancer-detection rate compared to DM screening alone, and a 34% increase in cancer detection with a 17% decrease in false-positive recalls. The additional cancers detected were found in all breast densities, from fatty to dense.

* DBT can more clearly depict benign findings than routine screening views, diminishing the need for recall for additional imaging, and reducing recall rates diminishes the potential harm of recalling normal patients and decreasing the number of false-positive biopsies. DBT appears to increase cancer detection, and the additional cancers detected are invasive malignancies missed by conventional mammography.

* DBT shows promise in demonstrating the same or higher accuracy as digital spot-compression mammography, and it may eliminate the need for additional mammogram views to identify the exact location of a breast lesion. DBT also may decrease the necessity to perform extra mammogram views, which would benefit radiation dose and patient comfort.

* The radiation dose for the combined examination of conventional mammography and DBT is slightly more than twice the dose of mammography alone, but synthetically reconstructed 2D images can be made from the DBT data, eliminating the need for double exposures. This eliminates the need to do an exposure for a DM, and also drops the radiation dose to that of conventional mammography.

* Large population studies are in progress, and incorporating DBT with other modalities, such as contrast-enhanced tomosynthesis, automated breast ultrasound, and computer-assisted

<summary>
• Diphenhydramine, a common antihistamine, has been shown to inhibit cough reflex sensitivity in subjects with acute viral upper respiratory tract infection (URI).
• The study found that diphenhydramine was more effective in suppressing cough reflex sensitivity than dextromethorphan, another common cough suppressant.
• The study used a capsaicin cough challenge test to measure cough reflex sensitivity and found that diphenhydramine increased the concentration of capsaicin required to induce coughing.
• The study's results suggest that diphenhydramine may be a useful treatment for acute cough due to URI, and further clinical trials are needed to fully evaluate its efficacy.
• The study's findings contradict the common criticism that over-the-counter (OTC) cough and cold medications, including diphenhydramine, lack evidence supporting their efficacy.

<summary>
• The global population is aging, and this trend is expected to continue, leading to an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, which is the most common cause of death among the elderly.
• Endothelial dysfunction, characterized by reduced vasodilator substance output and increased vasoconstrictor factors, is a key contributor to cardiovascular disease and is exacerbated by aging.
• Oxidative stress, an imbalance between reactive oxygen species and antioxidant systems, interferes with endothelial function, reducing nitric oxide bioavailability and promoting atherosclerosis.
• Exercise training has been shown to improve endothelial function, increase antioxidant defenses, and reduce oxidative stress, thereby mitigating the risk of cardiovascular disease.
• Regular exercise also reduces systemic inflammation, which is a key feature of aging, by decreasing pro-inflammatory cytokines and increasing anti-inflammatory cytokines.
• The benefits of exercise on endothelial function are thought to be mediated by increased shear stress, which upregulates endothelial nitric oxide synthase expression and activity, leading to increased nitric oxide production.
• Overall, exercise training is a powerful tool for preventing and restoring age-related impairment of endothelial function, reducing the risk of cardiovascular disease and promoting overall health.

• The axillary lymph node status is the most important prognostic factor in breast carcinoma, and the prognosis worsens with an increasing number of metastatic lymph nodes.
• The number of metastatic lymph nodes depends on the number of removed lymph nodes, and it is difficult to assess the axillary lymph node status reliably without removing sufficient numbers of lymph nodes.
• The lymph node ratio (LNR) provides more useful prognostic information compared to nodal disease classification according to the number of metastatic lymph nodes.
• In patients with 1-3 metastatic lymph nodes, LNR is a more powerful prognostic factor than the number of metastatic lymph nodes for disease-free survival, locoregional recurrence-free survival, and distant metastasis-free survival.
• The study found that LNR threshold values of 0.20, 0.30, and 0.15 separated patients into low- and high-risk groups with significant survival differences for disease-free survival, locoregional recurrence-free survival, and distant metastasis-free survival, respectively.
• The removal of at least 10 lymph nodes may be sufficient to obtain locoregional control, and removal of more lymph nodes may not be related to locoregional recurrence in patients with 1-3 metastatic lymph nodes.
• LNR can be used to separate breast carcinoma patients with 1-3 metastatic lymph nodes into low- and high-risk prognostic groups, providing more detailed and useful prognostic information than TNM nodal disease classification.

• The traditional method of activating hydroxy groups involves converting them into ester derivatives using strong acids, but this approach has poor atom economy and generates large amounts of waste. Enzymatic phosphorylation using kinases and sulfotransferases is an alternative, but it requires molar equivalents of cofactors, which can be problematic for scale-up. Phosphatases can be used as an efficient alternative, circumventing the need for cofactor recycling. They display a broad substrate spectrum and produce environmentally benign byproducts.

• Phosphatases have been used for synthetic applications since the 1940s, with early examples including transphosphorylation using phosphatase-enriched extracts and p-nitrophenyl phosphate as a donor. Later, acid phosphatases from enteric bacteria were applied to the phosphorylation of nucleosides, and mutants with reduced hydrolytic activity were designed. Phosphatases from Shigella flexneri and Salmonella enterica ser. Typhimurium LT2 were found to have a broad substrate spectrum and were applied in combination with aldolases to synthesize natural and unnatural sugar molecules. These enzymes were also used in drug discovery to enhance the accessibility of drug candidates.

• In this study, a set of phosphatases were evaluated as potential candidates for synthetic applications, with a focus on enhancing product titers and minimizing hydrolytic reaction. Enzyme candidates were selected from the family of acid phosphatases, which have been shown to transfer efficiently a phosphate moiety from high-energy inorganic di/tri/polyphosphate onto various hydroxylated compounds. The selected enzymes were overexpressed in E. coli and purified to homogeneity. A common mechanistic feature of phosphatetransferring phosphatases is the formation of a covalent phosphoenzyme intermediate.

• The activity of the recombinant proteins was verified using a spectrophotometric assay based on the hydrolysis of p-nitrophenyl phosphate. A range of alcohols was investigated, including primary and secondary mono- and dihydroxy compounds, as well as cyclic substrates. Phytase showed no transphosphorylation activity under the assay conditions, while aphast showed only marginal activity. Phonsf, phonse, and piacp proved to be efficient catalysts in the phosphorylation of various alcohols.

* Non-native biological invaders have been noted for centuries, with examples including the phylloxera that destroyed grapevines in Europe in the 1860s and the chestnut blight that devastated North America in the early 20th century. Charles Elton's 1958 book on the topic did not inspire a broad research thrust or public response. It wasn't until the 1980s that an international project engaged over 100 scientists and triggered an explosion of research on invasions. This research recognized invasions as one of the great ongoing global environmental changes.

* The research surge included studies on how non-native invaders eat native species, compete with them, or infect them, and sometimes do all three. Examples include the brown tree snake in Guam, the hemlock woolly adelgid in the eastern US, and the killer alga in the Mediterranean. Two new lines of research have become prominent, indicating that impacts of introduced species are more varied and widespread than previously thought. These lines of research focus on ecosystem-level impacts and genetics and evolution.

* Peter Vitousek's contributions to the SCOPE program described impacts at the ecosystem level, such as affecting nutrient cycles and other ecosystem-level processes. Research on such impacts has increased greatly, showing how a single introduced species can change processes or the physical structure of an ecosystem. This can affect a large fraction of resident species, as seen in the study by Fukami et al. on impacts. The phenomenon of ecosystem-level impacts is now recognized as a major concern.

* Molecular genetic research has revealed a great number of cases of the "stealth" impact of invaders, hybridization, and introgression with native species. This phenomenon was previously detected almost exclusively phenotypically, but many phenotypic responses are subtle and hidden amidst normal variation. Introgression can occur even between native species that never hybridize when a newly introduced species constitutes a genetic bridge between them. Introgression can also cause substantial evolution of native species.

* Hybridization between native and introduced species can even produce new, more invasive species, such as the common cordgrass that arose in England from hybridization between native and introduced species. Molecular genetic features have been used to trace sources and routes of invasions, and a major finding is that introduced populations often combine genes derived from multiple source populations. This produces novel genetic combinations, and some introduced populations have more genetic variation than any single source population. Environmental DNA is increasingly used to detect invaders.

• Schwannomas of the vidian canal are extremely rare tumors that can present with symptoms such as headaches, facial pain, facial muscle paralysis, decreased lacrimation, and nasal dryness, or as an incidental finding.
• The treatment options for vidian canal schwannomas include endoscopic surgical resection, single-fraction stereotactic radiosurgery, conventional fractionated radiotherapy, and conservative management, with the choice of treatment depending on patient choice, functional status, and tumor characteristics.

• The study investigated the biomechanical performance of short-segment pedicle screw fixation with and without intermediate screws in unstable burst fractures of the lumbar spine. The experiment used 12 fresh-frozen calf lumbar specimens, divided into two groups: monoaxial pedicle screw (MPS) and polyaxial pedicle screw (PPS). The specimens were tested for flexion, extension, lateral bending, and axial rotation as an intact spine, as a fractured spine, and as a fractured spine fixed by either a 4-screw or 6-screw construct. The results showed that the addition of intermediate screws decreased the range of motion (ROM) of the L2-L4 segments in both the MPS and PPS groups.

• The study found that the short-segment construct with intermediate screws provided a smaller ROM in flexion, extension, lateral bending, and torsion compared to the standard short-segment construct. The addition of intermediate screws increased the stiffness of the short-segment pedicle fixation, regardless of whether monoaxial or polyaxial pedicle screws were used. However, the increase in stiffness was more significant for the MPS construct. The results suggest that the intermediate screw provides a 3-point fixation of the fractured segment, which increases the stability of the construct.

• The study's limitations include that the data only pertained to results immediately after surgery and did not take into account early bone resorption or the cyclical loading effect, which have long-term impacts on outcome. The use of a calf spine model may not accurately represent human spine biomechanics. The study's findings provide a biomechanical rationale for using an intermediate screw at the level of fractured vertebrae with posterior short-segment fixation, especially when using monoaxial screws for fixing unstable burst fractures of the lumbar region. The results support the use of intermediate screws in clinical practice to improve the stability of short-segment pedicle fixation.

• The discovery of electrochemical self-assembly (ESA) of nanostructured hybrid thin films of inorganic semiconductors and organic dyes has opened a new synthetic route for obtaining photoanode materials for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). The ESA method bypasses the high-temperature sintering required for nanoparticulate TiO2 electrodes, allowing for the use of conductive plastic substrates. This method has been successfully applied to the construction of photoanodes using ZnO structures.

• The authors have developed a method for ESA of hybrid CuSCN (CUSCN) / rhodamine B (RB) nanoporous films, where RB serves as a structure-directing agent (SDA) and can be nearly completely removed to create a highly porous structure. The addition of RB to the bath causes a change in the crystallographic orientation of the CUSCN, and the loaded RB molecules can be extracted by soaking the film in a mild alkaline solution. The resulting porous CUSCN films have a high surface area and can be used as dye-sensitized photocathodes.

• The authors have also investigated the fluorescence quenching of various dye molecules attached to CUSCN, including RB, fluorescein isothiocyanate (FLTC), cresyl violet (CV), nile blue (NB), 3,4,9,10-perylene tetracarboxylic acid diimine (PTCDI), and quinacridone (QC). Strong fluorescence quenching was observed for RB and FLTC, indicating hole injection from the excited state of the dye to the valence band of CUSCN. The authors suggest that the strong chemical affinity of RB and FLTC to CUSCN is crucial for hole injection to occur.

• The nasopharyngeal bursa originates from the area of communication between the notochord and the foregut, and it is believed to be a remnant of embryonic communication between the notochord and the roof of the pharynx. It normally disappears during the second month of intrauterine fetal development, but if it becomes obstructed, it can form a cyst or crust. The cystic type is more common and should be part of the differential diagnosis of nasopharyngeal abscesses and cysts.

• The symptoms of nasopharyngeal bursitis can be either a space-occupying lesion or rhinitis, and may include nasal obstruction, eustachian tube obstruction, dysphagia, cranial nerve paralysis, choanal discharge, halitosis, pharyngitis, laryngitis, bronchitis, and gastritis. The incidence of nasopharyngeal bursitis is approximately 4% in adults, but it can appear at any age, with a peak incidence between 15 and 30 years and a Caucasian predominance. There is no gender predilection.

• The aim of the study was to identify the incidence of nasopharyngeal bursa disease, its different types, and its clinical presentation over two years in a single rhinology practice. The study was a two-year clinicoanatomical audit of nasopharyngeal bursitis at a rhinology practice in a university unit during 2008-2009. All patients diagnosed with nasopharyngeal bursitis confirmed by endoscopic examination and computed tomography scan/magnetic resonance imaging were asked about symptoms of Tornwaldt's syndrome.

• The results of the audit indicated that six patients were diagnosed with nasopharyngeal bursitis, with an incidence of less than 1% of all rhinitis patients seen during the study period. Two patients had classical Tornwaldt's cyst, one had a fibrosed Tornwaldt's cyst, and three had crust-type bursitis. The classical cyst type presented with postnasal discharge, throat irritation, and cough, while the fibrosed type was discovered incidentally in a patient who complained of snoring.

* The incidence of melanoma skin cancer has been increasing over the past few decades, with 76,250 new cases diagnosed in the USA in 2012, resulting in 9,180 deaths. Early diagnosis is crucial for the prognosis of the disease. Dermoscopy is a non-invasive diagnostic technique that links clinical dermatology and dermatopathology. It enables the visualization of morphological features that are not discernible by the naked eye.

* Dermoscopy enables better diagnosis compared to unaided eye, with an improvement in diagnostic sensitivity of 10-30%. However, it requires great deal of experience to differentiate skin lesions. Experts have achieved 90% sensitivity and 59% specificity in skin lesion diagnosis, while less trained doctors have a significant drop in accuracy. The diagnosis is highly dependent on subjective judgment and is scarcely reproducible.

* Several scoring systems and algorithms have been proposed to improve the diagnostic performance of less experienced clinicians. The ABCD-E rule, seven-point checklist, and Menzies method are some of the commonly used algorithms. However, these systems have limitations, and the within- and between-observer concordance is very low, even for expert observers. Automated analysis of digitized images obtained by dermoscopy can assist clinicians in differentiating early melanoma from benign skin lesions.

* Computational intelligence methods can help physicians in faster data processing and provide more reliable diagnoses. Studies on automated classification of pigmented skin lesion images have been reported since 1987. Machine vision and computerized analysis are becoming increasingly important every year. A comprehensive review of automatic diagnostic models for skin lesions is not available, and new classification algorithms and techniques for dermoscopic image analysis are emerging.

* Dermoscopy images often contain artifacts such as uneven illumination, dermoscopic gel, black frames, ink markings, rulers, air bubbles, and intrinsic cutaneous features. These artifacts complicate the border detection procedure, resulting in a loss of accuracy and increased computational time. Preprocessing steps such as image resizing, masking, cropping, hair removal, and conversion from RGB color to intensity grey image can facilitate image segmentation.

* Image segmentation is a crucial early step in the analysis of lesion images, and many algorithms and segmentation techniques are available in the literature. The goal of segmentation is to simplify and/or change the representation of an image into something that is more meaningful and easier to analyze. Several comparative studies have been conducted to evaluate the performance of different segmentation algorithms.

* Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a chronic disease characterized by high blood glucose levels, insulin resistance, and relative insulin deficiency, and it is a significant burden to society. The International Diabetes Federation reported that there were 366 million people with diabetes in 2011, and this number is expected to rise to 552 million by 2030 if no action is taken. T2D is caused by a combination of lifestyle and genetic factors, and 90% of patients with diabetes have T2D. The peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma coactivator 1 (PGC-1) gene is a multifunctional regulatory factor involved in mitochondrial biosynthesis, fatty acid oxidation, and glucose transport.

* The PGC-1 gene has been associated with T2D in different populations, and estrogen-related receptor alpha (ESRRa) protein binding to PGC-1 protein can regulate the expression of mitofusin-2 (MFN2) gene. ESRRa is an orphan nuclear receptor involved in mitochondrial biogenesis, oxidative metabolism, and lipid metabolism. MFN2 is a mitochondrial fusion protein that regulates mitochondrial morphology and distribution, and it is highly expressed in tissues with high energetic requirements such as skeletal muscle and heart. MFN2 also plays a role in oxidative metabolism and ER-mitochondria juxtaposition.

* The study examined the associations between MFN2 and ESRRa genetic polymorphisms and T2D in a Han Chinese population. The study included 1204 unrelated subjects, including 555 patients with T2D and 649 non-diabetic control subjects. The clinical characteristics of the study population are summarized in Table 1. The study used the International HapMap Project SNP database to search for SNPs in MFN2 and ESRRa genes.

* The study found that the A allele and C allele frequencies of rs873458 and rs2878677 of MFN2 gene were lower in the diabetic group than in the control group, suggesting that these alleles confer protection against T2D. The study also found that the genotype distributions of rs873458 and rs2878677 of MFN2 gene were significantly different in case-control subjects. The study replicated the two associated SNPs in stage 2 populations and found that the C allele of rs2878677 of MFN2 gene was lower in the diabetic group than in the control group.

* The study examined the impact of CYP2C19*2 and PON1 Q192R polymorphisms on clopidogrel platelet inhibition in patients with coronary artery disease. The study included 151 patients who were on dual antiplatelet therapy with clopidogrel and aspirin. The patients were genotyped for CYP2C19*2 and PON1 Q192R polymorphisms, and platelet function was assessed using light transmittance aggregometry and VerifyNow P2Y12 assay. The study found that CYP2C19*2 carrier status was associated with reduced platelet inhibition and increased on-treatment platelet reactivity.

* The study found no association between PON1 Q192R polymorphisms and platelet inhibition by clopidogrel. The PON1 Q192R polymorphisms were not associated with increased platelet aggregation or reduced platelet inhibition, even after adjusting for CYP2C19*2, diabetes, obesity, smoking, and proton pump inhibitor therapy. The study's findings are consistent with previous studies that did not find an association between PON1 Q192R polymorphisms and clopidogrel response. The study's results suggest that PON1 Q192R polymorphisms may not be a significant predictor of clopidogrel response.

* The study confirmed the association between CYP2C19*2 polymorphisms and reduced platelet inhibition by clopidogrel. CYP2C19*2 carrier status was associated with higher platelet aggregation and higher VerifyNow P2Y12 reactivity, and lower platelet inhibition. The study's findings are consistent with previous studies that have shown that CYP2C19*2 polymorphisms are associated with reduced active clopidogrel metabolite formation and increased on-treatment platelet reactivity. The study's results support the clinical importance of CYP2C19*2 polymorphisms in predicting clopidogrel response.

* The study's findings have implications for personalized medicine and the use of genetic testing to predict clopidogrel response. The study suggests that CYP2C19*2 polymorphisms may be a useful predictor of clopidogrel response, but PON1 Q192R polymorphisms may not be. The study's results support the use of genetic testing to identify patients who may be at risk of reduced clopidogrel response and to guide treatment decisions. * Toxoplasmosis is caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii, which can infect humans as an intermediate host, and most people with toxoplasmosis are asymptomatic. However, if a pregnant woman is infected, the parasite can enter the fetal circulation and cause congenital toxoplasmosis in the fetus. Congenital toxoplasmosis can present with a broad spectrum of clinical manifestations, ranging from mild chorioretinitis to severe central nervous system (CNS) involvement. The symptoms may include hydrocephalus, mental retardation, seizures, and intracerebral calcifications.

* The patient in this case report is a 34-year-old Arabian female who presented with medically intractable seizures and had a history of hydrocephalus and right ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunting at 1 month old. She also complained of decreased visual acuity in both eyes and had no history of febrile seizure, metabolic disease, or head trauma. Her family had no history of seizure, and her mental status was evaluated using the Mini-Mental State Examination, which suggested memory impairment and inattention. Ophthalmologic evaluation revealed macular inferior chorioretinal scar in the right eye and a large gray-whitish retinal necrotic lesion on the posterior pole in the left eye.

* The patient's seizures started with psychic aura, such as anxiety, and then secondarily generalized with right eyeball deviation and head version. The frequency of her seizures increased over time, and despite increasing the dose of antiepileptic drugs (AEDs), the frequency of seizures was not reduced. She was referred to the epilepsy clinic for further evaluation and management of her seizures. Video/EEG monitoring was performed for 6 days, during which 5 complex partial seizures (CPS) were observed, and 2 of those 5 CPS led to generalized tonic-clonic (GTC) seizures.

* The patient underwent 3.0 T high-resolution brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), which showed multifocal encephalomalacic change related to VP shunt, left hippocampal sclerosis (HS), and left amygdala hypertrophy, and multifocal parenchymal calcification including the left perihippocampal region. • Approximately 20 million people in the US have gallstones, and 1 million new cases are diagnosed every year, making cholelithiasis the most costly digestive disease with an annual cost of over $5 billion. The National Institute of Health convened a consensus development conference in 1992 to discuss the treatment of cholelithiasis and laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The conference concluded that laparoscopic cholecystectomy offered substantial advantages over traditional open cholecystectomy with no apparent increase in morbidity or mortality. The treatment costs were found to be equal to or slightly less than open cholecystectomy.

• The disability and loss of income following standard open cholecystectomy increase costs, but these items are generally not measured by traditional appraisal methods. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy has greatly reduced the convalescent period and costs. This example of cost analysis should be requested by business and patients, as they are impacted the most. Indeed, charges for laparoscopic cholecystectomy often surpass those of open cholecystectomy.

• The charges for equipment and other technical requirements for laparoscopic procedures probably explain the excess charges noted in laparoscopic cholecystectomies. Surgeons at Maricopa Medical Center identified excessive length of stay and charges by comparing the cholecystectomy DRG with 16 other hospitals in the region. Little could be done to reduce charges except to either lessen the conversion rates or costs for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. In order to get a precise estimate of laparoscopic charges, match pair comparisons from the same data base of charges between open cholecystectomy and converted laparoscopic cholecystectomy were accomplished.

• The comparisons matched age, sex, and similar diagnosis, eliminating many confounding variables. This suggested that the only reasons for the increased charges were the charges for laparoscopy. Other reasons for conversion, such as intraoperative complications, were eliminated because none of the matched pairs had serious complications or concomitant disease. Therefore, this comparison provided a relatively straightforward technique for statistical comparison to determine the charges for laparoscopy.

• A retrospective review of 70 cholecystectomy patients was conducted from a four-year data base of 633 patients who had undergone cholecystectomy. Thirty-five patients with converted laparoscopic cholecystectomies and thirty-five patients with open cholecystectomies were selected from the data by matching for age, sex, and similar diagnosis.

• The study analyzed the characteristics and determinants of partial remission (PR) in 242 children with type 1 diabetes, with a focus on the relationship between PR and long-term disease evolution. PR was defined as insulin-dose-adjusted A1c (IDAA1c) ≤ 9. The study found that 56.2% of patients experienced PR, with a mean duration of 9.2 months. No complete remission was observed.

• The study found that the absence of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) at diagnosis was associated with a higher frequency of PR, particularly in boys. DKA was present in 25.6% of patients, and its absence was significantly higher in PR patients (82.3%) than in non-PR patients (63.5%). This effect was more pronounced in boys, who had a higher PR frequency when no DKA occurred at diagnosis. Multivariate logistic regression analysis showed that the absence of DKA at diagnosis was associated with higher chances of PR.

• The study found that lower A1c levels at diagnosis were associated with higher chances of PR, particularly in girls. Patients entering PR had a lower baseline A1c (10.1%) than patients with no subsequent PR (10.8%). This effect was evidenced in girls entering PR, who had a lower A1c at diagnosis (10.0%) than girls without PR (11.2%). Lower A1c levels at diagnosis did not correlate with PR duration when analyzed for all patients.

• The study found that A1c levels at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after diagnosis were strongly associated with PR duration. Low A1c levels (< 6%) at 3-12 months were associated with longer PR, whereas PR durations dropped for A1c levels > 6-7% and > 7-8%. With high A1c levels (> 8-9%), PR durations were negligible. A1c levels at 3 months allowed estimation of the proportion of patients who would experience PR for more than 1 year.

• The study found that C-peptide secretion was significantly different in PR versus non-PR patients from diagnosis until 3 years after diagnosis. Higher baseline C-peptide concentrations were observed in patients entering PR, particularly in boys. * Oral health is crucial for the quality of life of individuals of all age groups, and oral lesions can lead to discomfort, pain, and interference with daily activities, affecting an individual's social life. The prevalence of oral lesions in the elderly population is significant, and there is a need for geriatric healthcare to focus on this aspect.

* The study aimed to determine the prevalence of oral mucosal lesions in 5,100 geriatric patients in India, with a focus on the epidemiologic aspects of oral mucosal lesions in this population. The study found that 64% of the patients presented with various oral lesions, with males being more affected than females.

* The most common lesions found were nicotinic stomatitis (43%), denture stomatitis (34%), and oral submucous fibrosis (30%), which are often associated with tobacco use, prosthetic use, and other habits. The study also found that the prevalence of oral mucosal lesions increases with age, even after adjusting for tobacco use and other factors.

* The study highlights the importance of oral healthcare in the elderly population, particularly in India, where there is a lack of research in this area. Community programs should be enhanced to educate the elderly population and provide them with access to adequate clinical and pathological laboratory facilities.

* The study's findings can be used to plan future oral health studies and programs for the geriatric population in India, and to raise awareness about the importance of oral healthcare in this age group. The study's results can also be used to develop strategies for preventing and managing oral mucosal lesions in the elderly population.

• Chondroblastoma is a rare osseous tumor that accounts for less than 1% of all primary bone tumors, typically affecting the epiphyseal regions of tubular bones. It can occur in the head and neck region, particularly in the temporal bone or temporomandibular joint (TMJ), causing various symptoms such as occlusal abnormalities, trismus, and hearing impairments.

• Malignant changes in chondroblastoma have been observed after irradiation, so radiation therapy should not be considered as a treatment option. Instead, complete surgical removal is recommended to avoid the risk of malignant progression.

• Chondroblastoma in the temporal bone has unusual histological features that make diagnosis difficult, and incomplete resection carries a high risk of recurrence. Accurate diagnosis and complete surgical removal are crucial for curative treatment.

• The patient in this case study presented with chronic hearing impairments and progressive trismus after 5 years of unsuccessful treatment, and a tumor mass was found in the middle cranial fossa, including the TMJ and cochlea. The original diagnosis was delayed due to inadequate imaging analysis and histopathologic examination.

• The patient underwent several attempts at antibiotic therapy and treatment for Eustachian tube blockage, but his symptoms were unresponsive to both systemic antibiotic agents and tubing therapy. Endoscopic surgery and attempts to correct the malocclusion for TMJ disorder were also implemented but resulted in no significant improvement.

• The patient was further assessed, and a CT scan and pathologic examination showed the presence of a giant cell tumor in the temporal bone. However, re-examination of the CT scan revealed that the tumor mass had progressively enlarged and had widely destroyed the middle cranial fossa in the temporal lobe.

• The tumor mass invaded the right temporal lobe and destroyed the subzygomatic fossa, and the patient experienced hearing loss, trismus, and paralysis in V2. No paralysis was observed in V1 and V3, nor in the facial, glossopharyngeal, or hypoglossal nerves.

• The patient underwent surgical treatment, including subtotal resection of the temporal bone and skull base dissection with resection of TMJ using a zygomatic-extended middle fossa approach. The temporal lobe dura was resected, and reconstruction using fascia lata and covered with the pericranial flap and the temporalis muscle was performed.

• The patient had no clinical evidence of tumor recurrence 4.

<summary>
• This study found no association between objectively measured sedentary behavior and levels of visceral adipose tissue (VAT) or intrahepatic lipid (IHL), and low levels of physical activity did not predict high levels of VAT or IHL.
• The study suggests that traditional risk factors such as waist circumference, triglycerides, fasting glucose, or fasting insulin may predict the incidence of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) or high levels of VAT, but objectively quantified physical activity levels and sedentary behavior did not predict those at risk.

<summary>
*A retrospective study of 53 eyes of 45 patients with firework-related injuries during the 5-day Diwali festival over 5 years found that 90.56% had closed-globe injuries, and 33.96% required surgical management.
*The study highlights the importance of public awareness, legislation, and regulation of fireworks to reduce the preventable cause of ocular morbidity, especially in the younger economically productive population.</summary>

<summary>
* Subclinical hypothyroidism (SCH) is a common disorder characterized by elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels with normal free thyroxine (FT4) levels, and its clinical significance and treatment are still controversial. SCH is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and mortality, and it may represent a potentially modifiable risk factor. The prevalence of SCH varies according to population, age, sex, race, region, and method of TSH measurement, and it is more common in women, elderly people, and iodine-sufficient populations. The normal reference range for TSH levels needs to be standardized, and quality control procedures need to be established by each laboratory.
* SCH is associated with various adverse health outcomes, including increased body mass index (BMI), blood pressure, and lipid levels, as well as vascular problems, metabolic syndrome, and heart failure. The treatment of SCH with levothyroxine (T4) therapy may improve cardiovascular function, endothelial function, and carotid intima-media thickness, but the benefits and risks of treatment are still unclear. The European Commission has funded a randomized controlled trial, the TRUST study, to assess the effects of T4 replacement therapy on clinical outcomes in older adults with SCH. The results of this study are expected to clarify the populations that may benefit from T4 replacement and whether the benefits outweigh the potential adverse effects.

<summary>
* The study investigated patients with Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD) who had submitted stool specimens for CD toxin testing, and found that 57.4% had CD toxin-positive stool specimens, 20.6% had toxin-negative stool specimens but toxin-positive isolates, and 22.1% had both toxin-negative stool specimens and isolates. The study aimed to investigate the clinical history and need for treatment of patients with glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH)-positive and toxin-negative stool specimens.
* The study found that patients with toxin-negative stool specimens had significantly shorter diarrhea duration compared to those with toxin-positive stool specimens, despite the lack of CDAD treatment in most toxin-negative patients. This suggests that patients who tested positive for C. difficile on culture but negative for toxins in their stool had milder symptoms.
* The study also found that patients with toxin-negative stool specimens but toxin-positive isolates had shorter diarrhea duration compared to those with toxin-positive stool specimens, despite significantly fewer patients in the former group receiving treatment. This suggests that patients with toxin-negative stool specimens but toxin-positive isolates may have milder symptoms.
* The study found no significant differences among the groups with regard to number and respective administration frequencies of antimicrobial drugs received by patients within the 30 days prior to diarrhea onset. However, the study did find that some classes of antibiotics, such as clindamycin and broad-spectrum cephalosporins, are widely known risk factors for CDAD.
* The study found that the sensitivity of enzyme immunoassay (EIA) for toxin detection is far inferior to that of polymerase chain reaction (PCR), which amplifies the toxin coding regions. However, EIA directly measures the toxin proteins in stool and is thus more likely to reflect the patient's actual disease status.
* The study had several limitations, including its retrospective nature, small sample size, and absence of molecular biological testing. Further large-scale analysis is required to determine whether the patient groupings in the study reflect bacterial genetic characteristics.
* The study's results suggest a limited need for CDAD treatment for patients with GDH-positive and toxin-negative stool specimens, and highlight the importance of considering the patient's clinical history and symptoms when making treatment decisions. However, patients with toxin-negative stool specimens among the patients with EIA GDH-positive stool specimens had toxin-positive isolates, and thus require care from the perspective of preventing hospital infection.

<summary>
* The DREAM trial was a large, international, multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial that aimed to determine whether ramipril and/or rosiglitazone could prevent or delay the development of type 2 diabetes in people with impaired fasting glucose (IFG) or impaired glucose tolerance (IGT). The trial recruited 5,269 participants with IFG, IGT, or both, and followed them for a median of 3 years.

* The primary outcome variable was change in β-cell function over the course of follow-up, which was assessed using two measures: the insulinogenic index (IGI) and proinsulin (PI) concentration. Both indexes have been validated against gold-standard measures of insulin secretion and have been shown to be significant predictors of incident diabetes.

* Rosiglitazone significantly increased IGI/IR and reduced PI/C by 86% and 42%, respectively, indicating improved β-cell function. These findings were consistent across glucose tolerance subgroups, although the effect was more modest in the subgroup with isolated IFG.

* The improvement in β-cell function with rosiglitazone was seen early in the study, with significant changes observed between the baseline and 2-year visits. In contrast, there were no significant changes in β-cell function in participants receiving ramipril versus placebo.

* The impact of rosiglitazone on diabetes prevention persisted after adjustment for baseline β-cell function, suggesting that the effect of rosiglitazone on diabetes prevention is partly mediated through its effects on β-cell function. However, the modest attenuation of rosiglitazone's effect after accounting for the change in β-cell function suggests that not all of the effect is mediated through β-cell function.

* Ramipril did not significantly affect β-cell function compared with placebo, and its glucose-lowering effects may operate through other metabolic mechanisms. The improvement in β-cell function in the placebo arm of the ramipril marginal group analysis may be explained by the fact that half of the participants on ramipril placebo were receiving active rosiglitazone.

* The study's strengths include its large sample size, randomized, double-blind design, and completeness of follow-up, but a limitation is the lack of detailed measures of β-cell function, such as those obtained from the hyperglycemic clamp technique or the frequently sampled intravenous glucose tolerance test.

<summary>
* The study explores the interactions between microbial communities and individual strains, focusing on the exchange of metabolites and the emergence of cooperative growth. The researchers used a set of 46 E. coli auxotrophs, each with a specific metabolic block, and co-cultured them in all possible pairwise combinations to study their growth and interactions.
* The results show that certain pairs of auxotrophs can complement each other's growth in minimal media by cross-feeding essential metabolites, a phenomenon referred to as synthetic mutualism in trans (SMIT). The study also found that the growth of a given strain is positively correlated with the growth of its partner strain, indicating a cooperative relationship.
* The researchers developed a quantitative model that predicts the growth of co-cultures based on the metabolic network stoichiometries and the costs and benefits of metabolite exchange. The model was able to reproduce the observed growth patterns and provided insights into the efficiency of cooperation and the emergence of cooperative behavior in microbial communities.

<summary>
• Brooke-Spiegler syndrome (BSS) is a rare genodermatosis characterized by the progressive formation of adnexal skin tumors in the scalp and face, mainly trichoepiteliomas, cylindromas, and spiradenomas.
• BSS is caused by mutations in the tumor suppressor gene CYLD (cylindromatosis gene) on chromosome 16q12q13, with around 93 different mutations identified so far.
• The study of the CYLD gene in patients and their relatives can provide molecular diagnosis and appropriate genetic counseling.
• There is a low risk of malignancy, and patients require long-term follow-up.
• A 71-year-old woman was evaluated for progressive development of asymptomatic lesions on her head, which were diagnosed as spiradenomas and cylindromas through excisional biopsies.
• The patient's family history revealed an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern of the disease, with multiple affected family members.
• Genetic testing revealed a heterozygous mutation c.1628_1629delct in the CYLD gene in the patient and her two affected daughters.
• The case highlights the importance of correct diagnosis, periodic follow-up, and genetic counseling for patients with BSS, as well as the relationship between germline mutation, somatic mutation, and final phenotype.

<summary>
* Biological scaffold materials derived from dermis, pericardium, and small intestine submucosa have been used for soft tissue repair applications, but they have limitations such as high cost, variability, and immunological responses.
* Permanent, synthetic polymer mesh materials are not typically used in contaminated settings due to the risk of infection.
* Absorbable scaffold designs have been developed to address these limitations, including materials such as Dexon, Vicryl, Gore Bio-A, Tigr Matrix, and Phasix Mesh.
* Phasix Mesh is a fully resorbable polymer monofilament made of poly-4-hydroxybutyrate (P4HB) that is knitted into a flat sheet configuration.
* The study evaluated the mechanical properties, resorption profile, and histological characteristics of Phasix Mesh and P4HB plug in a porcine model.
* The results showed that Phasix Mesh had suitable tensile strength and strain values at time zero, and its burst strength and relative stiffness remained stable throughout the study duration.
* The molecular weight of Phasix Mesh decreased significantly over time, and its resorption profile was similar to that of the P4HB plug.
* The study found no evidence of hernia or diastasis in any of the animals at any of the time points, and the repair sites demonstrated significantly greater burst strength and relative stiffness compared to the native abdominal wall.
* The results suggest that Phasix Mesh and P4HB plug are promising materials for hernia repair applications.

<summary>
* The study evaluated the diagnostic accuracy and impact of the Xpert vanA/vanB assay, a rapid PCR-based test, for detecting vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE) in a hospital setting. The assay was performed directly on rectal swabs and results were available within 1 hour.
* The study found that the vanA PCR part of the assay had a high diagnostic accuracy, with a sensitivity of 87.1% and specificity of 99.7%, and was able to detect VRE in 13.8% of the samples. The vanB PCR part of the assay had a lower specificity and positive predictive value due to false-positive results.
* The rapid availability of PCR results led to a significant impact on infection control decision making, with 141 isolation days and 292 transmission risk days saved. The assay also enabled faster outbreak declaration and implementation of additional infection control measures.
* The study concluded that the Xpert vanA/vanB assay is a valuable tool for rapid detection of VRE and can have a significant impact on infection control practices, although further studies are needed to generalize the results to other settings and strains. The cost-effectiveness of the assay was also considered to be favorable.

<summary>
• The study investigates the effects of aldosterone antagonism on ischemia-reperfusion (I/R) injury in normal and diabetic hearts, using the mineralocorticoid receptor (MR) antagonist RU28318.
• The results show that RU28318 is effective in preventing and treating I/R-induced cardiac dysfunction in normal hearts, and is similarly effective as captopril and losartan in diabetic hearts.
• Combination therapies involving RU28318, captopril, and losartan were generally more effective than single therapies in preventing and treating I/R-induced cardiac dysfunction.
• In diabetic hearts, captopril + losartan dual therapy was the most effective treatment, consistent with the known overactivity of the ACE/Ang II/AT1 signaling cascade in diabetes.
• RU28318 was ineffective in improving systolic function (pmax) when given after ischemia in diabetic hearts, but was effective in improving diastolic function (dp/dt) when given after ischemia.
• The study suggests that MR signaling is detrimental for all cardiac parameters in nondiabetic hearts during I/R, but may be detrimental only during the ischemia-induced phase of I/R injury in diabetic hearts.
• The effectiveness of drugs appeared to be cardiac parameter-specific, with some drugs being better at improving one cardiac function parameter over others.
• The study implies that RU28318 may be beneficial in treating diabetes-induced diastolic dysfunction, and that early-stage RU treatment may represent a novel strategy for treating diabetes-induced diastolic dysfunction.
• The mechanisms by which RU28318 exerts its beneficial effects may include blockade of aldosterone-induced oxidative stress, endothelial dysfunction, and inflammation in the heart and coronary vasculature.
• The study suggests that combination therapies involving RU28318, captopril, and losartan may be beneficial in treating cardiac dysfunction, and that RU28318 may be particularly useful in patients with diabetes and renal damage.

<summary>

* Modern nasal surgery aims to improve both the cosmetic appearance of the nose and its natural functions, including breathing. Measurement of nasal cavity geometry is a challenge, and acoustic rhinometry (AR) is a common method used to measure nasal airway patency. AR has been shown to have a close correlation with rhinomanometry and has demonstrated significant associations between nasal cavity dimensions and nasal airflow. The technique is easy to perform and requires minimal cooperation from the subject.

* The study evaluated changes in nasal dimensions of healthy Iranian volunteers who underwent cosmetic rhinoplasty using AR. The cases were all healthy, without any prior history of nose surgery, fracture, allergy, or asthma, and sinus disorders, and they had no complaint about nasal obstruction. The surgeries were performed by a single experienced surgeon, and septoplasty was performed in cases of moderate-to-severe septal deviation. The measurements were performed before and after surgery, with and without decongestant.

* The results showed that bilateral d1, bilateral d2, and left mca2 did not change significantly after surgery without decongestant. However, bilateral d1 and both mca2 decreased significantly, while mca1 increased significantly postoperatively with decongestant. The study also found that cases with septoplasty would experience more increase in mca1 and less constriction in mca2 postoperatively. In cases of rhinoplasty without septoplasty, increase in mca1 was significant only in the group of single osteotomy without decongestant.

* The study found that double osteotomy was beneficial for patients, with a significant increase in mca1. Placing a columellar strut in group of cases of rhinoplasty plus septoplasty had a significant effect both at mca1 and mca2 levels. In cases of rhinoplasty alone, placing a columellar strut caused a greater amount of increase in mca1. Regression analysis revealed no fixed significant effect for septoplasty, osteotomy, and placing a columellar strut.

* The study's findings are consistent with previous studies that reported reduction in internal dimensions of the nasal cavity, especially the anterior dimensions. The anatomic correlate of this point is the anterior portion of the inferior turbinate, and decreasing the resistance in this region could be beneficial for patients. • Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of mortality in many economically developed nations, accounting for about 30% of all deaths, and its incidence is still increasing. Ongoing research aims to investigate and prevent the early development of cardiovascular risk factors such as atherosclerosis, hypertension, dyslipidemia, chronic inflammation, and insulin resistance. The beneficial effects of n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFAs) were proved in several observational and experimental studies. The lipid-lowering action of n-3 PUFAs was detected at the beginning, and they were used for the treatment of dyslipidemic disorders.

• Low-grade chronic inflammation is now recognized as a prominent process in the development of atherosclerosis and coronary heart disease. The induction of inflammation may well provide a link between hyperlipidemia and atherogenesis. Atherosclerosis is now considered a systemic disease featured by low-grade arterial inflammatory lesions that can develop through the disease progression. In physiological conditions, endothelial cells synthesize and release adequate amounts of nitric oxide (NO) and prostaglandins.

• There are two PUFA families, omega-3 (n-3) and omega-6 (n-6) fatty acids, which differ in the location of the last double bond relative to the terminal methyl end of the molecule. The human body can produce almost all fatty acids, except linoleic acid (LA, C18:2 n-6) and α-linolenic acid (ALA, C18:3n-3), which are named essential fatty acids because the body cannot synthesize them. Endogenous conversion of the initial C18 PUFA precursors results in the synthesis of longer-chain counterparts such as eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in the n-3 family. The biochemical pathways converting ALA to EPA and EPA to DHA are limited.

• Fish is the major food source of long-chain n-3 PUFAs, including EPA, DHA, and docosapentaenoic acid (DPA), while ALA is a plant n-3 fatty acid mainly found in seeds, nuts, and their oils. Thus, plant sources of n-3 fatty acids cannot currently be considered as a replacement for seafood-derived n-3 PUFAs. This suggests that n-3 fatty acids derived from different sources might have their own specific effects on cardiovascular risk markers. Linoleic acid is

<summary>
• Our understanding of H. pylori-induced inflammation leading to cancer is built on the work of three pioneering pathologists: Rudolf Virchow, Pelayo Correa, and Robin Warren. Virchow is considered the father of modern pathology and proposed that cancer arises from initially normal cells in response to chronic irritation or inflammation.

• Correa developed a model for gastric cancer development, proposing that it results from a stepwise process beginning with chronic atrophic gastritis and progressing to intestinal metaplasia and cancer over 30-50 years. The initial changes were thought to occur in the first decade of life, which is when H. pylori colonization occurs.

• Warren and Barry Marshall discovered H. pylori and its role in gastritis and peptic ulcer disease, and were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2005. They found that H. pylori was very common in peptic ulcer patients and caused gastritis and ulcer disease.

• Initial investigations into the association between H. pylori and gastric cancer provided weak evidence, but subsequent studies using serum banks and nested case-control designs found a significant association. The World Health Organization declared H. pylori a definite carcinogen in 1994.

• Further research has confirmed and expanded upon the early epidemiologic studies, including the finding that H. pylori is a risk factor for both intestinal and diffuse-type gastric cancer. Measuring H. pylori exposure by ELISA underestimates prior exposure and attributable risk in noncardia cancer.

• H. pylori eradication can reduce the risk of developing gastric cancer, and recent meta-analyses indicate that it decreases the risk by approximately 40% in primary prevention studies and 54% in tertiary prevention studies. The benefit of H. pylori eradication is most evident in subjects living in areas with high gastric cancer prevalence.

• The eradication of H. pylori from a community should help prevent much gastric cancer and diminish the morbidity of peptic ulcers. However, there is concern regarding the ecologic consequences of using multiple antibiotics in a large proportion of the population to prevent H. pylori-related disease.

• A pilot study of mass population screening and eradication in Taiwan has shown promising results, with a decrease in gastric cancer incidence, peptic ulcers, and gastric atrophy. Several other population-based trials are underway, including one in China with almost 100,000 subjects.

<summary>
• The study compared the functional and anatomical outcomes of bevacizumab and ranibizumab in Turkish patients with neovascular age-related macular degeneration (nAMD). The study found that both groups had significant improvements in visual acuity and central retinal thickness (CRT) at every time point. The mean best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) and CRT were similar between the two groups at all time points.

• The study included 79 patients in the bevacizumab group and 74 patients in the ranibizumab group, with similar baseline characteristics. The patients received as-needed injections of bevacizumab or ranibizumab, with a mean of 4.8 injections in the bevacizumab group and 4.7 injections in the ranibizumab group at 12 months. The mean intraocular pressure (IOP) was similar between the two groups at baseline and at the most recent follow-up.

• The study found that 43.0% of patients in the bevacizumab group and 40.5% of patients in the ranibizumab group gained 3 or more lines of visual acuity. 86.1% of patients in the bevacizumab group and 86.5% of patients in the ranibizumab group had stable or improved vision. No serious ocular or systemic complications were observed in any of the patients.

• The study's results are consistent with previous studies that found similar improvements in visual and anatomical outcomes with bevacizumab and ranibizumab. The CATT study, a multicenter noninferiority trial, also found that bevacizumab and ranibizumab had similar efficacy and safety profiles. The study's results support the use of as-needed bevacizumab or ranibizumab in patients with nAMD.

• The study's strengths include the fact that patients in both groups had similar baseline characteristics and received no other forms of treatment. The study's results suggest that both bevacizumab and ranibizumab are effective in stabilizing visual acuity in patients with nAMD. The study's findings are important for clinicians and patients considering treatment options for nAMD.

* Preeclampsia (PE) is a leading cause of maternal and neonatal mortality and morbidity, affecting 25% of all pregnancies. It is classically diagnosed by the presence of proteinuria in women with gestational hypertension. However, several studies have shown that proteinuria is not a significant predictor of adverse maternal and neonatal outcomes. The incidence of PE has increased in China since the introduction of the two-child policy.

* Hypoalbuminemia is a common complication of PE, occurring due to systemic small vessel spasm, increased secretion of angiotensin, and damaged vascular endothelial cells. This leads to a loss of plasma proteins, especially serum albumin, causing intravascular dehydration. Intravascular dehydration may accelerate the appearance of intravascular lesions, which is thought to be a predisposing factor for hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet (HELLP) syndrome and acute fatty liver of pregnancy. Hypoalbuminemia may serve as an indicator of the severity of PE.

* The study aimed to evaluate maternal and perinatal outcomes in women with PE according to different albumin levels (25 g/L and <25 g/L). A total of 299 women with singleton pregnancies were enrolled, and their serum albumin levels were measured. The women were divided into two groups: mild hypoproteinemia (MHP) and severe hypoproteinemia (SHP). The study found that SHP was a significant risk factor for cesarean section, poor maternal outcomes, and poor neonatal outcomes.

* The study found that women with SHP were delivered almost 1.5 weeks earlier than those with MHP. The percentage of cesarean section was higher, and the rate of spontaneous delivery was lower in the SHP group. Severe hypertension was more frequent in the SHP group than in the MHP group. Women with SHP were more likely to present with abnormal liver or renal function, ascites, and abruptio placenta.

* Neonatal outcomes were worse in the SHP group, with a lower average birth weight and a higher incidence of fetal growth restriction, neonatal intensive care unit admission, and preterm deliveries. The study found that SHP was a significant risk factor for cesarean section, poor maternal outcomes, and poor neonatal outcomes. The results suggest that SHP is a risk factor for women with PE, and closer surveillance is needed during pregnancy.

<summary>
• The development of humanized monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) and small-molecule protein tyrosine kinase (PTK) inhibitors has provided avenues to explore the efficacy of targeting the VEGF-A signaling pathway in cancer. The success of Avastin (bevacizumab) in treating various cancers has highlighted the potential of anti-angiogenic treatments.

• However, the withdrawal of Avastin for treating breast cancer has highlighted the limitations of anti-angiogenic treatments and the need for a careful cost-benefit analysis. The development of resistance to Avastin and the pre-existing refractoriness of some tumors suggest the role of other growth factors in sustaining tumor angiogenesis.

• Alternative ligands for the angiogenic receptor VEGFR-2, such as VEGF-C and VEGF-D, and other angiogenic factors from distinct growth factor families, such as FGF, are logical candidates for promoting resistance to Avastin. These factors may contribute to the development of resistance to anti-angiogenic treatments.

• Targeting VEGF-D signaling in cancer could involve mAbs specific to the VHD of VEGF-D, PTK inhibitors that block VEGFR-2 and VEGFR-3 signaling, or soluble forms of VEGFR-3 that could sequester both VEGF-C and VEGF-D. This approach could inhibit both tumor angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis, restricting solid tumor growth and metastatic spread.

• Further studies are required to fully understand the complex network of signaling cascades that drive angiogenesis, lymphangiogenesis, and resistance to anti-angiogenic drugs. Genome-wide functional approaches, such as those using siRNA technology, could help strategize effective targeting of growth factors, receptors, and PTKs.

<summary>
• Malaria is a significant public health concern in Iran, particularly in the south and southeast regions, with a substantial reduction in incidence in recent years due to deliberate implementation of control measures. In 2011, there were 3,239 reported cases, with P. vivax responsible for the majority of cases and P. falciparum accounting for 10-15% of cases. The Iranian government has entered the malaria pre-elimination program since 2009, aiming to reduce the incidence of locally acquired infection to zero.

• Active surveillance by precise laboratory methods in endemic areas is crucial for detection of all kinds of infections, particularly asymptomatic ones containing low parasite densities. Asymptomatic malaria infections were previously described in hyper-endemic regions following frequent infective bites and repetitive immune system response. The prevalence of asymptomatic malaria infection was determined by means of different laboratory techniques in various endemic countries.

• The study aimed to detect low parasite and asymptomatic malaria infections by means of three malaria diagnostic tests (microscopy, RDT, and nested-PCR) in a low transmission region of Bagh-e-Malek in Minab district, Hormozgan province, southern Iran. A total of 200 healthy volunteers participated in the study, with 3 ml fresh blood samples collected during July 2011. The study was approved by the ethics committee of Hormozgan University of Medical Sciences.

• The molecular detection of Plasmodium species was performed using nested-PCR amplification of 18S rRNA of the parasite. DNA was extracted from whole blood samples using Promega kit, and amplification was performed in a total volume of 25 μl including primers, dNTPs, and Taq polymerase. A sample was considered positive for P. vivax and P. falciparum if a 120 and 419 base-pair fragment was detected, respectively.

• The results showed that none of the 200 thick and thin Giemsa-stained blood smears were positive for Plasmodium parasite by microscopy, and none of the samples were diagnosed to have any malaria parasite during the 60-days follow-up protocol. RDTs were also tested as a complementary analysis for all of 200 samples, but no positive result was discovered for either P. falciparum and/or non-falciparum species. However, nested-PCR amplification detected 3 P. vivax positive samples (1.5%) using specific primers.

<summary>
* The study investigated the use of immunoglobulin G (IgG) responses to a panel of prostate tissue- and cancer-associated antigens as a diagnostic tool to evaluate immune responses elicited following immune-active therapies.
* The results showed that IgG responses to individual prostate-associated antigens were elicited as a result of therapy, with different patterns of response observed for different therapies, and recognition of specific antigens was most evident at a later time point (12 months following treatment).
* Machine learning-based Bayesian belief network (ML-BBN) modeling was used to identify biomarker cohorts associated with clinical response, and a subset of biomarkers was identified that had high information content for use in a selected subset for ML-BBN modeling.
* The study suggests that the use of ML-BBN modeling appears to provide a promising method for identifying biomarkers in complex data sets that can then be selected for further analysis, and future modeling might permit the selection of patients who would be appropriate to receive vaccine therapy based on pre-existing immunological response parameters.

<summary>
• The study explores the use of piezoelectric materials and the converse piezoelectric effect to stimulate bone growth at the bone-implant interface. The researchers developed an actuator device using polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) films and silver electrodes, which was implanted in the left hind limb of a sheep. The device was programmed to apply a 5V square wave at 1Hz and 3Hz for 15 minutes at each frequency, once every 24 hours. The control device was implanted in the right hind limb.

• The results showed that the total bone area around the actuated devices was significantly higher compared to the static controls, with an increase in new bone formation and mineral apposition rate. The bone areas surrounding the two distal thirds of the devices showed significant differences between actuated and static devices. The mineral apposition rate was significantly higher around actuated devices than around static devices. The fibrous capsule thickness was similar between the two groups.

• The study suggests that piezoelectric materials and the converse piezoelectric effect can be used to effectively stimulate bone growth at the bone-implant interface, eliciting an early response. However, the material used (PVDF) may not be biocompatible, and further studies are needed to develop a more suitable material. The results are promising, but the study has limitations, including the use of only one animal and a short implantation time. Further studies are needed to confirm the findings and to explore the potential of piezoelectric materials for clinical applications.

<summary>
• The study was conducted on 90 individuals, divided into a study group of 60 oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) patients and a control group of 30 healthy volunteers.
• The study excluded individuals with other malignancies, liver disease, tuberculosis, diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular diseases, or any other chronic systemic diseases.
• The serum L-fucose level was estimated using a clinical chemistry autoanalyzer based on the Winzler method.
• The study found a significant difference in serum L-fucose levels between OSCC patients (10.85 mg/dl) and healthy controls (3.47 mg/dl).
• The serum L-fucose level progressively increased with the stage of cancer, with the highest level in stage IV.
• There was no correlation between serum L-fucose levels and age, gender, or histopathological grading.
• The study suggests that serum L-fucose levels can be used as a non-invasive, cost-effective biochemical indicator of cancer detection, staging, therapeutic success, prognosis, and post-treatment evaluation.
• Further investigation on a large scale is needed to prove serum L-fucose as an effective tumor marker in the diagnosis and management of oral cancer.
</summary>

<summary>

* Lcn2-deficient mice were generated by gene targeting in embryonic stem cells, and their metabolic phenotypes were characterized. The mice were backcrossed onto the C57BL/6 background for 10 generations before experiments. The mice were housed in a specific pathogen-free facility and handled according to national guidelines.

* Lcn2 mice were fed either a high-fat diet (HFD) or regular chow diet (RCD) from 3 weeks of age, and their body weight and fat pad weights were measured. Lcn2 mice were significantly heavier than wild-type mice on either diet, with increased weight of white and brown fat pads. The mice also had increased liver, heart, kidney, and spleen weights.

* The fat cell size distribution of Lcn2 mice on an RCD was measured using a multisizer, and the average peak diameter of the large-cell population was significantly larger than in wild-type mice. This indicates that Lcn2 adipose tissue contains larger adipose cells. The growth curve, fat pad weight, and organ weight of Lcn2 mice were also measured.

* Food intake, ambulatory activity, VO2, and RQ were not significantly different between RCD-fed wild-type and Lcn2 mice. However, Lcn2 mice displayed cold sensitivity and could not survive when exposed to 4°C for >10 hours. The rectal temperature of Lcn2 mice dropped significantly within 3 hours compared to wild-type mice.

* The thermogenic activity of brown adipose tissue (BAT) was assessed under thermoneutral and thermal stress conditions. Lcn2 mice expressed significantly lower levels of UCP-1 and PGC-1 genes in BAT than wild-type mice. However, UCP-1 and PGC-1 expression in BAT were stimulated at an even higher level in Lcn2 mice after exposure to 4°C for 5 hours.

* The mitochondrial oxidative capacity of BAT was investigated, and a significant reduction in the expression levels of mitochondrial genes involved in mitochondrial biogenesis and oxidative function was observed in Lcn2 mice fed an HFD. The expression of transcription factors PPAR, Nrf1, and Tfam, and CPT-1 gene in skeletal muscle was also downregulated in Lcn2 mice fed an HFD.

<summary>
* The study used a rat model to investigate the role of weight bearing in the development of non-traumatic osteonecrosis of the femoral head (ONFH). The rats were divided into two groups: weight-bearing (WB) and non-weight-bearing (NWB), with the latter group having their hindlimbs suspended to prevent weight bearing.
* The results showed that ONFH developed in both WB and NWB groups, with no significant difference in the incidence of ONFH between the two groups. This suggests that weight bearing does not contribute to the development of non-traumatic ONFH in rats.
* The study also found that the histopathological appearance of the femoral head was similar in both WB and NWB groups, with empty lacunae and decreased hematopoietic cells observed in both groups. No humeral head osteonecrosis was observed in either group.
* The study's findings suggest that the rat model may be useful for elucidating the pathogenesis of ONFH, but may not be suitable for studying the mechanism of femoral head collapse. The aetiology, pathogenesis, and prognosis of non-traumatic ONFH remain unclear.

<summary>
*Nurses in Kenya have limited involvement in national policy development, with only a few nurse leaders participating in policy committees, and their input is often limited to nursing-specific issues. This lack of involvement is attributed to a top-down approach to policy-making, which excludes nurses from decision-making processes. Nurses are also hindered by their lack of knowledge and skills in policy-making, as well as their limited representation on policy-related structures. As a result, nurses' contributions to policy development are often inadequate.

*Nurses' lack of engagement in policy-making is also due to the hierarchical structure of the health care system, which favors medical doctors over nurses. The Public Health Act, which mandates doctors to head departments and programs, further perpetuates this hierarchy. Nurses are also limited by their own professional hierarchies, with senior nurses making most of the decisions and suppressing the voices of lower-level nurses. This limits the scope of nurses' policy influence at the national level.

*The study's findings suggest that nurses need to develop their knowledge and skills in policy-making, including research, advocacy, and political skills. Nurses should also be empowered to take up leadership roles in the system and diversify their knowledge to understand broader policy-related issues. Additionally, the nursing profession should incorporate policy issues into nurses' training curricula to prepare them for policy-making roles. This would enable nurses to contribute more effectively to policy development.

*To enhance nurses' participation in policy-making, the health care system needs to address its hierarchical and gendered structures. This can be achieved by enacting legislation that allows nurses to hold senior positions in the health care system and by creating mechanisms for nurses' views to be heard at the national level. Decentralization of power and governance opportunities can also provide opportunities for nurses to take up leadership roles. Furthermore, national level decision-makers should solicit the views of frontline nurses on policies that affect their work and quality of care.

*To strengthen their role in advocacy, nurses should unite to build a strong voice and collaborate with other health professionals to influence decisions. Nursing regulators and educators should also emphasize policy involvement as part of nurses' scope of practice. Nurses should be given orientation on existing national policies and how they affect their work environment and patient outcomes. By doing so, nurses can contribute more effectively to policy development and improve the health care system.
